analyzed: jāti ādi saṃsthāna saṃsthitasya eva vastunaḥ pratyakṣeṇa gṛhīta tvāt tasya eva saṃsthāna rūpa jāti ādeḥ pratiyogi apekṣayā bheda vyavahāra hetu tvāt ca
translated: Because the entity existing in the form of the universal etc. is grasped by perception, and because that form of the universal etc. is the cause of the usage of the entity as different in relation to its counter-correlate.

original: svarūpapariṇāmadoṣaś ca pūrvam evoktaḥ /
analyzed: sva rūpa pariṇāma doṣaḥ ca pūrvam eva uktaḥ
translated: And the fault of the transformation of one's own nature was stated earlier.

original: yaḥ pṛthivyāṃ tiṣṭhan pṛthivyā antaro yaṃ pṛthivī na veda yasya pṛthivī śarīraṃ yaḥ pṛthivīm antaro yamayati eṣa ta ātmāntaryāmyamṛtaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ pṛthivyām tiṣṭhan pṛthivyāḥ antaraḥ yam pṛthivī na veda yasya pṛthivī śarīram yaḥ pṛthivīm antaraḥ yamayati eṣa te ātmā antaryāmī amṛtaḥ
translated: He who, standing on the earth, is within the earth, whom the earth does not know, whose body the earth is, who controls the earth from within, He is your Self, the inner controller, the immortal.

original: ya ātmani tiṣṭhann ātmano 'ntaro ya ātmā na veda yasyātmā śarīraṃ ya ātmānam antaro yamayati eṣa ta ātmāntaryāmyamṛtaḥ /🔽yaḥ pṛthivīm antare saṃcaran yasya pṛthivī śarīraṃ yaṃ pṛthivī na vedetyādi yo 'kṣaram🔽antare saṃcaran yasyākṣaraṃ śarīraṃ akṣaraṃ na veda yo mṛtyum antare saṃcaran yasya
analyzed: yaḥ ātmani tiṣṭhan ātmanaḥ ntaraḥ yaḥ ātmā na veda yasya ātmā śarīram yaḥ ātmānam antaraḥ yamayati eṣa te ātmā antaryāmī amṛtaḥ  yaḥ pṛthivīm antare saṃcaran yasya pṛthivī śarīram yam pṛthivī na veda ityādi yaḥ u kṣaram  antare saṃcaran yasya akṣaram śarīram akṣaram na veda yaḥ mṛtyum antare saṃcaran yasya
translated: He who, standing in the Self, is within the Self, whom the Self does not know, whose body the Self is, who controls the Self from within, He is your Self, the inner controller, the immortal.

original: mṛtyuḥ śarīraṃ yaṃ mṛtyur na veda eṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmāpahatapāpmā divyo deva eko nārāyaṇaḥ /
analyzed: mṛtyuḥ śarīram yam mṛtyuḥ na veda eṣa sarva bhūta antarātmā apahata pāpmā divyaḥ devaḥ ekaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ
translated: He who moves within the earth, whose body the earth is, whom the earth does not know, etc. He who moves within the imperishable, whose body the imperishable is, the imperishable does not know. He who moves within death, whose body death is, whom death does not know, He is the inner Self of all beings, free from sin, divine, the sole God, Narayana.

original: dvā suparṇā sayujā sakhāyā samānaṃ vṛkṣaṃ pariṣasvajāte /
analyzed: dvā suparṇā sayujā sakhāyā samānam vṛkṣam pariṣasvajāte
translated: Two birds, companions, friends, cling to the same tree.

original: tayor anyaḥ pippalaṃ svādv atty anaśnann anyo 'bhicākaśīti /
analyzed: tayoḥ anyaḥ pippalam svādu atti an aśnan anyaḥ bhicākaśīti
translated: Of them, one eats the sweet fruit, the other looks on without eating.

original: antaḥ praviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānāṃ sarvātmā /
analyzed: antar praviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānām sarva ātmā
translated: The chastiser, the universal Self, has entered within.

original: tatsṛṣṭvā tad evānuprāviśat /
analyzed: tat sṛṣṭvā tat eva anuprāviśat
translated: Having created that, it entered into it.

original: tadanupraviśya sac ca tyac cānṛtaṃ ca satyam abhavat /
analyzed: tat anupraviśya sat ca tyad ca anṛtam ca satyam abhavat
translated: Having entered into that, the true and the false became true.

original: anena jīvenātmanetyādi /
analyzed: anena jīvena ātmanā ityādi
translated: By this living soul, for the self, etc.

original: pṛthagātmānaṃ preritāraṃ matvā jaṣṭas tatas tenāmṛtatvam eti /
analyzed: pṛthak ātmānam preritāram matvā jaṣṭaḥ tatas tena amṛta tvam eti
translated: Having regarded the self as the impeller, one is liberated. Then by that, one attains immortality.

original: bhoktā bhogyaṃ preritāraṃ ca matvā sarvaṃ proktaṃ trividhaṃ brahma / etat /
analyzed: bhoktā bhogyam preritāram ca matvā sarvam proktam trividham brahma etat
translated: Having regarded the enjoyer, the object of enjoyment, and the impeller, all is said to be the threefold Brahman. This.

original: nityo nityānāṃ cetanaś cetanānām eko bahūnāṃ yo vidadhāti kāmān /
analyzed: nityaḥ nityānām cetanaḥ cetanānām ekaḥ bahūnām yaḥ vidadhāti kāmān
translated: The eternal of the eternals, the conscious of the conscious, the one of the many, who grants desires,

original: pradhānakṣetrajñapatir guṇeśaḥ /
translated: The lord of Prakriti, the Kshetrajna, the lord of the qualities,

original: jñājñau dvav ajav īśānīśav ityādiśrutiśatais tadupabṛṃhaṇaiḥ
analyzed: jña ajñau dvau ajau īśāna īśau ityādi śruti śataiḥ tad upabṛṃhaṇaiḥ
translated: The known and the unknown, the two unborn, the lord and the isha, etc., by hundreds of such Upanishadic passages that expand on it.

original: jagat sarvaṃ śarīraṃ te sthairyaṃ te vasudhātalam //
analyzed: jagat sarvam śarīram te sthairyam te vasudhā talam
translated: The entire universe is your body, your firmness is the surface of the earth.

original: yat kiṃcit sṛjyate yena sattvajātena vai dvija /
analyzed: yat kiṃcid sṛjyate yena sattva jātena vai dvija
translated: Whatever is created by any being, O twice-born,

original: tasya sṛjyasya saṃbhūtau tatsarvaṃ vai hares tanuḥ //
analyzed: tasya sṛjyasya saṃbhūtau tat sarvam vai hareḥ tanuḥ
translated: In the creation of that which is to be created, all that is indeed the body of Hari.

original: aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarvabhūtāśayasthitaḥ //
analyzed: aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva bhūta āśaya sthitaḥ
translated: I am the Self, O Gudakesha, dwelling in the heart of all beings.

original: sarvasya cāhaṃ hṛdi saṃniviṣṭo
analyzed: sarvasya ca aham hṛdi saṃniviṣṭaḥ
translated: And I am seated in the heart of all,

original: mattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṃ ca //
analyzed: mattaḥ smṛtiḥ jñānam apohanam ca
translated: From Me are memory, knowledge and the power of discrimination.

original: ityādivedavidagresaravālmīkiparāśaradvaipāyanavacobhiś ca parasya brahmaṇaḥ sarvasyātmatvāvagamāc
analyzed: ityādi veda vid agresara vālmīki parāśara dvaipāyana vacobhiḥ ca parasya brahmaṇaḥ sarvasya ātma tva avagamāt
translated: And by the words of Valmiki, Parasara, and Vyasa, the leaders in the knowledge of the Vedas, etc., the supreme Brahman is understood to be the Self of all,

original: cidacidātmakasya vastunas taccharīratvāvagamāc ca śarīrasya śarīriṇaṃ prati prakāratayaiva
analyzed: cit acit ātmakasya vastunaḥ tad śarīra tva avagamāt ca śarīrasya śarīriṇam prati prakāra tayā eva
translated: and the entity consisting of the conscious and unconscious is understood to be its body, and the body, being a mere mode for the embodied Self,

original: padārthatvāc śarīraśarīriṇoś ca dharmabhede 'pi tayor asaṃkarāt sarvaśarīraṃ brahmeti🔽brahmaṇo vaibhavaṃ pratipādayadbhiḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyādibhir mukhyavṛttaiḥ sarvacetanācetanaprakāraṃ
analyzed: padārtha tvāt śarīra śarīriṇoḥ ca dharma bhede pi tayoḥ asaṃkarāt sarva śarīram brahma iti  brahmaṇaḥ vaibhavam pratipādayadbhiḥ sāmānādhikaraṇya ādibhiḥ mukhya vṛttaiḥ sarva cetana acetana prakāram
translated: is a real entity only in relation to the embodied Self, and the body and the embodied Self, though different in properties, are not confused, so it is said that the entire body is Brahman.

original: brahmaivābhidhīyate /
analyzed: brahma eva abhidhīyate
translated: And by the principal usages such as co-reference, etc., which teach the greatness of Brahman, Brahman alone is spoken of in all its aspects, conscious and unconscious.

original: sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ hi dvayoḥ padayoḥ prakāradvayamukhenaikārthaniṣṭhatvaṃ /
analyzed: sāmānādhikaraṇyam hi dvayoḥ padayoḥ prakāra dvaya mukhena ekārtha niṣṭhatvam
translated: For co-reference is the relation of two words to the same object through two aspects.

original: tasya caitasmin pakṣe mukhyatā /
analyzed: tasya ca etasmin pakṣe mukhya tā
translated: And that is primary in this view.

original: tathā hi tat tvam iti sāmānādhikaraṇye tad ityanena jagatkāraṇaṃ sarvakalyāṇaguṇagaṇākaraṃ niravadyaṃ brahmocyate /
analyzed: tathā hi tat tvam iti sāmānādhikaraṇye tat iti anena jagat kāraṇam sarva kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa ākaram niravadyam brahma ucyate
translated: Thus, in the co-reference of tat tvam asi (that thou art), by the word tat (that) the cause of the world, the faultless Brahman, the abode of all auspicious qualities, is spoken of.

original: tvam iti ca cetanasāmānādhikaraṇyavṛttena jīvāntaryānirūpi taccharīraṃ tadātmatayāvasthitaṃ tatprakāraṃ brahmocyate /
analyzed: tvam iti ca cetana sāmānādhikaraṇya vṛttena jīva antaryā nirūpi tat śarīram tad ātma tayā avasthitam tad prakāram brahma ucyate
translated: And the word “you” is used in the sense of being co-extensive with the conscious [self], and the body of the individual soul, which is the inner controller, is said to be Brahman, which exists as its self, and is of that nature.

original: itareṣu pakṣeṣu sāmānādhikaraṇyahānir brahmaṇaḥ sadeṣatā ca syāt /
analyzed: itareṣu pakṣeṣu sāmānādhikaraṇya hāniḥ brahmaṇaḥ sat eṣatā ca syāt
translated: In the other views, there would be a loss of co-extensiveness of Brahman, and Brahman would not be real.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said.

original: brahmaivam avasthitam ity atraivaṃśabdārthabhūtaprakāratayaiva vicitracetanācetanātmakaprapañcasya sthūlasya sūkṣmasya ca sadbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: brahma evam avasthitam iti atra evam śabda artha bhūta prakāra tayā eva vicitra cetanā acetana ātmaka prapañcasya sthūlasya sūkṣmasya ca sadbhāvaḥ
translated: The existence of the gross and subtle universe, consisting of the various conscious and unconscious things, is in the form of modes, which are the meaning of the word thus in the statement Brahman exists thus.

original: tathā ca bahu syāṃ prajāyeyety ayam arthaḥ saṃpanno bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca bahu syām prajāyeya iti ayam arthaḥ saṃpannaḥ bhavati
translated: And thus the meaning I will become many, I will be born becomes complete.

original: tasyaiveśvarasya kāryatayā kāraṇatayā ca nānāsaṃsthānasaṃsthitasya saṃsthānatayā cidacidvastujātam avasthitam iti / 🔽nanu ca saṃsthānarūpeṇa prakāratayaivaṃśabdārthatvam jātiguṇayor eva dṛṣṭaṃ na dravyasya /
analyzed: tasya eva īśvarasya kārya tayā kāraṇa tayā ca nānā saṃsthāna saṃsthitasya saṃsthāna tayā cit acit vastu jātam avasthitam iti  nanu ca saṃsthāna rūpeṇa prakāra tayā evam śabda artha tvam jāti guṇayoḥ eva dṛṣṭam na dravyasya
translated: The collection of conscious and unconscious things exists in the form of the various shapes of that very God, both as the effect and the cause.🔽But the meaning of the word thus is seen to be only in the form of a class or quality, not in the form of a substance.

original: svatantrasiddhiyogyasya padārthasyaivaṃśabdārthatayeśvarasya prakāramātratvam ayuktaṃ /
analyzed: svatantra siddhi yogyasya padārthasya evam śabda artha tayā īśvarasya prakāra mātra tvam ayuktam
translated: It is not proper for God, who is fit for independent existence, to be merely a mode by being the meaning of the word thus.

original: ucyate dravyasyāpi daṇḍakuṇḍalāder dravyāntaraprakāratvaṃ dṛṣṭam eva /
analyzed: ucyate dravyasya api daṇḍa kuṇḍala ādeḥ dravya antara prakāra tvam dṛṣṭam eva
translated: It is said that even a substance like a stick or an earring is seen to be a mode of another substance.

original: nanu ca daṇḍādeḥ svatantrasya dravyāntaraprakāratve matvarthīyapratyayo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca daṇḍa ādeḥ svatantrasya dravya antara prakāra tve matvarthīya pratyayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: But in the case of a stick, etc., which are independent, a possessive suffix is seen when it is a mode of another substance.

original: yathā daṇḍī kuṇḍalīti /
analyzed: yathā daṇḍī kuṇḍalī iti
translated: For example, one who has a stick, one who has earrings.

original: ato gotvāditulyatayā cetanācetanasya dravyabhūtasya vastuna īśvaraprakāratayā sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanaṃ na yujyate /🔽atrocyate gaur aśvo manuṣyo deva iti bhūtasaṃghātarūpāṇāṃ dravyāṇām eva devadatto manuṣyo jātaḥ puṇyaviśeṣeṇa yajñadatto gaurjātaḥ pāpena /
analyzed: atas go tva ādi tulya tayā cetana acetanasya dravya bhūtasya vastunaḥ īśvara prakāra tayā sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanam na yujyate  atra ucyate gauḥ aśvaḥ manuṣyaḥ devaḥ iti bhūta saṃghāta rūpāṇām dravyāṇām eva devadattaḥ manuṣyaḥ jātaḥ puṇya viśeṣeṇa yajñadattaḥ gauḥ jātaḥ pāpena
translated: Therefore, it is not proper to present the conscious and unconscious substance, which is like the universal of cowhood, as a mode of God by co-reference.

original: anyaś cetanaḥ puṇyātirekeṇa devo jāta ityādidevādiśarīrāṇāṃ cetanaprakāratayā lokadevayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: anyaḥ cetanaḥ puṇya atirekeṇa devaḥ jātaḥ iti ādi deva ādi śarīrāṇām cetana prakāra tayā loka devayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanam dṛṣṭam  /
translated: Here it is said that the co-reference of the world and God is seen by presenting the bodies of gods, etc., as modes of the conscious being. For example, a cow, a horse, a human, a god - in this way, the bodies of gods, etc., are seen to be presented by co-reference as modes of the conscious being.

original: ayam arthaḥ jātir vā guṇo vā dravyaṃ vā na tatrādaraḥ /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ jātiḥ vā guṇaḥ vā dravyam vā na tatra ādaraḥ
translated: The meaning is: whether it is a universal, a quality, or a substance, there is no regard for that.

original: kaṃcana dravyaviśeṣaṃ prati viśeṣaṇatayaiva yasya sadbhāvas tasya tadapṛthaksiddhes tatprakāratayā tatsāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanaṃ yuktam
analyzed: kaṃcana dravya viśeṣam prati viśeṣaṇatayā eva yasya sadbhāvaḥ tasya tad apṛthak siddheḥ tad prakāra tayā tad sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanam yuktam
translated: It is proper to teach that which exists only as a qualifier with respect to a particular substance, by making it a type of that [substance], in such a way that it is not established separately from that [substance].

original: yasya punar dravyasya pṛthaksiddhasyaiva kadācitkvaciddravyāntaraprakāratvam iṣyate tatra matvarthīyapratyaya iti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: yasya punar dravyasya pṛthak siddhasya eva kadācid kvacid dravya antara prakāra tvam iṣyate tatra matvarthīya pratyayaḥ iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: But in the case of a substance that is established separately, and whose nature as another substance is sometimes accepted somewhere, there is a suffix indicating possession. This is the difference.

original: evam eva sthāvarajaṅgamātmakasya sarvasya vastuna īśvaraśarīratvena tatprakāratayaiva svarūpasadbhāva iti /
analyzed: evam eva sthāvara jaṅgama ātmakasya sarvasya vastunaḥ īśvara śarīra tvena tad prakāra tayā eva svarūpa sadbhāvaḥ iti
translated: In the same way, for all things consisting of the moving and unmoving, existence is only as a type of that [Īśvara], as the body of Īśvara.

original: tatprakārīśvara eva tattacchabdenābhidhīyata iti tatsāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanaṃ yuktaṃ /
analyzed: tad prakāri īśvaraḥ eva tad tad śabdena abhidhīyate iti tad sāmānādhikaraṇyena pratipādanam yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is proper to teach by making it co-referential with that [Īśvara], by calling that Īśvara, who is of that type, by the word that.

original: tad evaitat sarvaṃ pūrvam eva nāmarūpavyākaraṇaśrutivivaraṇe prapañcitam /
analyzed: tat eva etat sarvam pūrvam eva nāma rūpa vyākaraṇa śruti vivaraṇe prapañcitam
translated: All this has been elaborated before itself in the explanation of the Vedic text on the manifestation of name and form.

original: ataḥ prakṛtipuruṣamahadahaṃkāratanmātrabhūtendriyatadārabdhacaturdaśabhuvanātmakabrahmāṇḍatadantarvartidevatiryaṅmanuṣyasthāvarādisarvaprakārasaṃsthānasaṃsthitaṃ
analyzed: atas prakṛti puruṣa mahat ahaṃkāra tanmātra bhūta indriya tad ārabdha caturdaśa bhuvana ātmaka brahmāṇḍa tad antarvarti deva tiryak manuṣya sthāvara ādi sarva prakāra saṃsthāna saṃsthitam
translated: Therefore, the universe consisting of the fourteen worlds, which are composed of primordial matter, the individual soul, intellect, ego, the subtle elements, the gross elements, and the sense organs, and which contains all kinds of arrangements such as gods, animals, humans, plants, etc.,

original: kāryam api sarvaṃ brahmaiveti kāraṇabhūtabrahmavijñānād eva sarvaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīty
analyzed: kāryam api sarvam brahma eva iti kāraṇa bhūta brahma vijñānāt eva sarvam vijñātam bhavati iti
translated: And all effects are Brahman itself. So, by the knowledge of Brahman as the cause, everything becomes known.

original: ekavijñānena sarvavijñānam upapannataram /
analyzed: eka vijñānena sarva vijñānam upapannataram
translated: So the knowledge of everything by the knowledge of one is more reasonable.

original: tad evaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvādimukhena kṛtsnasya cidacidvastunaḥ parabrahmaprakāratayā tadātmakatvam uktam /
analyzed: tat evam kārya kāraṇa bhāva ādi mukhena kṛtsnasya cit acit vastunaḥ para brahma prakāra tayā tad ātmaka tvam uktam
translated: Thus, through the relation of cause and effect, etc., the entire world of conscious and unconscious things is said to be of the nature of the highest Brahman and to be identical with it.

original: nanu ca parasya brahmaṇaḥ svarūpeṇa pariṇāmāspadatvaṃ nirvikāratvaniravadyatvaśrutivyākopaprasañgena nivāritam /
analyzed: nanu ca parasya brahmaṇaḥ sva rūpeṇa pariṇāma āspada tvam nirvikāra tva niravadya tva śruti vyākopa prasañgena nivāritam
translated: But the possibility of the highest Brahman being the substratum of transformation in its own nature has been refuted by the occurrence of the contradiction of the statements about being changeless and faultless.

original: prakṛtiś ca pratijñādṛṣṭāntānuparodhād ity ekavijñānena sarvavijñānapratijñānamṛttatkāryadṛṣṭāntābhyāṃ paramapuruṣasya jagadupādānakāraṇatvaṃ 🔽ca pratipāditam /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ ca pratijñā dṛṣṭānta an uparodhāt iti eka vijñānena sarva vijñāna pratijñāna mṛd tad kārya dṛṣṭāntābhyām paramapuruṣasya jagat upādānakāraṇa tvam  ca pratipāditam
translated: And the proposition that by the knowledge of one everything is known, and the example of clay and its effects, establish the highest Person as the material cause of the world,

original: upādānakāraṇatvaṃ ca pariṇāmāspadatvam eva /
analyzed: upādāna kāraṇa tvam ca pariṇāma āspada tvam eva
translated: and the material cause is the very substratum of transformation.

original: katham idam upapadyate /
analyzed: katham idam upapadyate
translated: How is this possible?

original: atrocyate sajīvasya prapañcasyāviśeṣeṇa kāraṇatvam uktam /
analyzed: atrā ucyate sa jīvasya prapañcasya aviśeṣeṇa kāraṇa tvam uktam
translated: To this it is said: The causehood of the living world has been stated without distinction.

original: tatreśvarasya jīvarūpapariṇāmābhyupagamena nātmā śruter nityatvāc ca tābhya iti virudhyate /
analyzed: tatra īśvarasya jīva rūpa pariṇāma abhyupagamena na ātmā śruteḥ nitya tvāt ca tābhyaḥ iti virudhyate
translated: In that case, by accepting that God transforms into the form of the individual soul, the contradiction of not from the self because of the eternality of the Veda is avoided.

original: vaiṣamyanairghṛṇyaparihāraś ca jīvanam anāditvābhyupagamena tatkarmanimittatayā pratipāditaḥ🔽vaiṣamyanairghṛṇye na sāpekṣatvān na karmavibhāgād iti cen na anāditvād upapadyate
analyzed: vaiṣamya nairghṛṇya parihāraḥ ca jīvanam anādi tva abhyupagamena tad karma nimitta tayā pratipāditaḥ  vaiṣamya nairghṛṇye na sāpekṣa tvāt na karma vibhāgāt iti ced na anādi tvāt upapadyate
translated: And the avoidance of inequality and cruelty is explained by accepting the beginninglessness of the world, and by showing that it is caused by the actions of the individual souls.🔽If it is argued that inequality and cruelty are not avoided because God is dependent on the actions of the individual souls, that is not so, because beginninglessness is possible.

original: cāpy upalabhyate cetyakṛtābhyāgamakṛtavipraṇāśaprasaṅgaś cānityatve 'bhihitaḥ /
analyzed: ca api upalabhyate ca iti akṛta abhyāgama kṛta vipraṇāśa prasaṅgaḥ ca anitya tve bhihitaḥ
translated: And it is observed. And the consequence of the acquisition of what is not done and the loss of what is done is stated in the case of non-eternality.

original: tathā prakṛter apy anāditā śrutibhiḥ pratipaditā
analyzed: tathā prakṛteḥ api anādi tā śrutibhiḥ pratipaditā
translated: Similarly, the beginninglessness of primordial matter is also shown by the scriptures.

original: ajām ekāṃ lohitaśuklakṛṣṇāṃ bahnīṃ prajāṃ janayantīṃ sarūpām /
analyzed: ajām ekām lohita śukla kṛṣṇām bahnīm prajām janayantīm sarūpām
translated: She, the one unborn, red, white and black, the mother, generating her own form in the form of progeny,

original: ajo hy eko juṣamāṇo 'nuśete jahāty enāṃ bhuktabhogām ajo 'nyaḥ //
analyzed: ajaḥ hi ekaḥ juṣamāṇaḥ nuśete jahāti enām bhukta bhogām ajaḥ nyaḥ
translated: For the unborn one, who is alone, enjoys (her); another unborn one abandons her when she has enjoyed (him).

original: iti prakṛtipuruṣayor ajatvaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti prakṛti puruṣayoḥ aja tvam darśayati
translated: Thus it shows the unborn nature of primordial matter and the spirit.

original: asmān māyī sṛjate viśvam etat tasmiṃś cānyo māyayā saṃniruddhaḥ māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyān māyinaṃ tu maheśvaram iti prakṛtir eva svarūpeṇa vikārāspadam
analyzed: asmāt māyī sṛjate viśvam etat tasmin ca anyaḥ māyayā saṃniruddhaḥ māyām tu prakṛtim vidyāt māyinam tu maheśvaram iti prakṛtiḥ eva sva rūpeṇa vikāra āspadam  /
translated: Thus it shows that primordial nature itself is the basis of modifications in its own form.

original: iti ca darśayati /
analyzed: iti ca darśayati
translated: And it is also shown by the statement:

original: gaur anādyantavatī sā janitrī bhūtabhāvinīti ca /
analyzed: gauḥ anādi antavatī sā janitrī bhūta bhāvinī iti ca
translated: The cow is beginningless and endless, she is the mother, the cause of past and future.

original: smṛtiś ca bhavati
analyzed: smṛtiḥ ca bhavati
translated: And there is also a Smṛti:

original: prakṛtiṃ puruṣaṃ caiva viddhy anādī ubhav api /
analyzed: prakṛtim puruṣam ca eva viddhi anādī ubhau api
translated: Know that both primordial nature and the individual soul are beginningless.

original: vikārāṃś ca guṇāṃś caiva viddhi prakṛtisaṃbhavān //🔽bhūmir āpo 'nalo vāyuḥ khaṃ mano buddhir eva ca /
analyzed: vikārān ca guṇān ca eva viddhi prakṛti saṃbhavān  bhūmiḥ āpaḥ nalaḥ vāyuḥ kham manaḥ buddhiḥ eva ca
translated: And know that the modifications and the qualities originate from primordial nature.

original: ahaṃkāra itīyaṃ me bhinnā prakṛtir aṣṭadhā //
analyzed: ahaṃkāraḥ iti iyam me bhinnā prakṛtiḥ aṣṭadhā
translated: Earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, intellect, and ego - thus my nature is divided into eight.

original: apareyam itas tv anyāṃ prakṛtiṃ viddhi me parām /
analyzed: aparā iyam itas tu anyām prakṛtim viddhi me parām
translated: But know that this other, higher nature of mine is different from this,

original: jīvabhūtāṃ mahābāho yayedaṃ dhāryate jagat //
analyzed: jīva bhūtām mahā bāho yayā idam dhāryate jagat
translated: which is the source of life, O mighty-armed, by which this world is sustained.

original: prakṛtiṃ svām avaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punaḥ punaḥ /
analyzed: prakṛtim svām avaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punar punar
translated: Relying on my own nature, I create again and again.

original: mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram //
analyzed: mayā adhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram
translated: With me as the overseer, primordial nature produces the moving and unmoving world.

original: ityādikā /
analyzed: ityādikā
translated: And so on.

original: evaṃ ca prakṛter apīśvaraśarīratvāt prakṛtiśabdo 'pi tadātmabhūtasyeśvarasya tatprakārasaṃsthitasya vācakaḥ /
analyzed: evam ca prakṛteḥ api īśvara śarīra tvāt prakṛti śabdaḥ api tad ātma bhūtasya īśvarasya tad prakāra saṃsthitasya vācakaḥ
translated: And thus, since the Prakṛti also is the body of the Lord, the word Prakṛti denotes the Lord who is identical with that [Prakṛti], or who is situated in that form.

original: puruṣaśabdo 'pi tadātmabhūtasyeśvarasya puruṣaprakārasaṃsthitasya vācakaḥ /
analyzed: puruṣa śabdaḥ api tad ātma bhūtasya īśvarasya puruṣa prakāra saṃsthitasya vācakaḥ
translated: And the word Puruṣa also denotes the Lord who is identical with that [Puruṣa], or who is situated in that form.

original: atas tadvikārāṇām api tatheśvara evātmā / tad āha
analyzed: atas tad vikārāṇām api tathā īśvaraḥ eva ātmā tat āha
translated: Therefore, the individual souls also have the Lord as their Self. Thus it is said:

original: vyaktaṃ viṣṇus tathāvyaktaṃ puruṣaḥ kāla eva ca /
analyzed: vyaktam viṣṇuḥ tathā avyaktam puruṣaḥ kālaḥ eva ca
translated: The manifest, Viṣṇu, the unmanifest, and time,

original: sā eva kṣobhako brahman kṣobhyaś ca parameśvaraḥ //
analyzed: sā eva kṣobhakaḥ brahman kṣobhyaḥ ca parameśvaraḥ
translated: That very one is the agitator and the agitated Supreme Lord, O Brahman.

original: iti / ataḥ prakṛtiprakārasaṃsthite paramātmani prakārabhūtaprakṛtyaṃse vikāraḥ prakāryaṃse cāvikāraḥ /
analyzed: iti atas prakṛti prakāra saṃsthite paramātmani prakāra bhūta prakṛti aṃse vikāraḥ prakāri aṃse ca avikāraḥ
translated: Thus, in the Supreme Self situated in the form of Prakṛti, the manifest is in the part that is of the nature of Prakṛti, and the unmanifest is in the part that is of the nature of the Puruṣa.

original: evam eva jīvaprakārasaṃsthite paramātmani ca prakārabhūtajīvāṃśe sarve cāpuruṣārthāḥ prakāryaṃśo niyantā niravadyaḥ sarvakalyāṇaguṇākaraḥ satyasaṃkalpa
analyzed: evam eva jīva prakāra saṃsthite paramātmani ca prakāra bhūta jīva aṃśe sarve ca apuruṣa arthāḥ prakāri aṃśaḥ niyantā niravadyaḥ sarva kalyāṇa guṇa ākaraḥ satya saṃkalpa
translated: In the same way, in the Supreme Self situated in the form of the individual souls, all the goals of human life are in the part that is of the nature of the individual souls, and the controller in the part that is of the nature of the Puruṣa. He is faultless, the source of all auspicious qualities, and His resolve is true.

original: eva /
analyzed: eva
translated: He is the Supreme Lord.

original: tathā ca sati kāraṇāvastha īśvara eveti tadupādānakajagatkāryāvastho 'pi sa eveti kāryakāraṇayor ananyatvaṃ sarvaśrutyavirodhaś ca bhavati
analyzed: tathā ca sati kāraṇa avasthaḥ īśvaraḥ eva iti tad upādānaka jagat kārya avasthā u pi saḥ eva iti kārya kāraṇayoḥ ananya tvam sarva śruti avirodhaḥ ca bhavati
translated: And if this is so, then God in His causal state. And so also in His effect-state, in which He is the universe, which is produced from Him. Thus there is non-difference between cause and effect, and there is no contradiction with any Vedic text.

original: tad evaṃ nāmarūpavibhāgānarhasūkṣmadaśāpannaprakṛtipuruṣaśarīraṃ brahma kāraṇāvasthaṃ /
analyzed: tat evam nāma rūpa vibhāga anarha sūkṣma daśā āpanna prakṛti puruṣa śarīram brahma kāraṇa avastham
translated: Thus Brahman, in its causal state, has a body consisting of Prakriti and Purusha, which are in a subtle state not yet divided into name and form.

original: jagatas tadāpattir eva ca pralayaḥ /
analyzed: jagataḥ tad āpattiḥ eva ca pralayaḥ
translated: And the dissolution of the universe is just its return to that state.

original: nāmarūpavibhāgavibhaktasthūlacidacidvastuśarīraṃ brahma kāryatvaṃ /
translated: Brahman, in its effect-state, has a body consisting of gross conscious and non-conscious entities divided into name and form.

original: brahmaṇas tathāvidhasthūlabhāva eva jagataḥ sṛṣṭir ity ucyate /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ tathāvidha sthūla bhāvaḥ eva jagataḥ sṛṣṭiḥ iti ucyate
translated: And the creation of the universe is said to be just Brahman's assuming such a gross state.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā parāśareṇa
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā parāśareṇa
translated: As has been said by the revered Parashara:

original: pradhānapuṃsor ajayoḥ kāraṇaṃ kāryabhūtayoḥ / iti /
analyzed: pradhāna puṃsoḥ ajayoḥ kāraṇam kārya bhūtayoḥ iti
translated: The cause of Prakriti and Purusha, which are unmanifest and are effects.

original: tasmād īśvaraprakārabhūtasarvāvasthaprakṛtipuruṣavācinaḥ śabdās tatprakāraviśiṣṭatayāvasthite paramātmani mukhyatayā vartante /
analyzed: tasmāt īśvara prakāra bhūta sarva avastha prakṛti puruṣa vācinaḥ śabdāḥ tad prakāra viśiṣṭa tayā avasthite paramātmani mukhya tayā vartante
translated: Therefore, words denoting Prakriti and Purusha, which are of the nature of God, primarily apply to the supreme Self, which exists with those as its distinguishing features.

original: jīvātmavācidevamanuṣyaśabdavat /
analyzed: jīva ātma vāci deva manuṣya śabda vat
translated: Like the words god and man, which denote individual souls.

original: yathā devamanuṣyādiśabdā devamanuṣyādiprakṛtipariṇāmaviśeṣāṇāṃ jīvātmaprakāratayaiva padārthatvāt prakāriṇi jīvātmani mukhyatayā vartante /
analyzed: yathā deva manuṣya ādi śabdāḥ deva manuṣya ādi prakṛti pariṇāma viśeṣāṇām jīvātma prakāra tayā eva padārtha tvāt prakāriṇi jīvātmani mukhya tayā vartante
translated: For instance, the words ‘god’, ‘man’, etc., are primarily applicable to the individual soul, which is the substratum of the particular modifications of the ‘primordial matter’ in the shape of ‘god’, ‘man’, etc.

original: tasmāt sarvasya cidacidvastunaḥ paramātmaśarīratayā tatprakāratvāt paramātmani mukhyatayā vartante sarve vācakāḥ śabdāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt sarvasya cit acit vastunaḥ paramātma śarīra tayā tad prakāra tvāt paramātmani mukhya tayā vartante sarve vācakāḥ śabdāḥ
translated: Thus, all words are primarily applicable to the supreme self, because all things, conscious as well as non-conscious, are of the nature of modifications of that self.

original: ayam eva cātmaśarīrabhāvaḥ pṛthaksiddhyanarhādhārādheyabhāvo niyantṛniyāmyabhāvaḥ śeṣaśeṣibhāvaś ca /
analyzed: ayam eva ca ātma śarīra bhāvaḥ pṛthak siddhi anarha ādhāra ādheya bhāvaḥ niyantṛ niyāmya bhāvaḥ śeṣa śeṣi bhāvaḥ ca
translated: And this relation of the self to its body consists in the relation of the inseparable substratum and the inseparable object, the relation of the controller and the controlled, and the relation of the principal and the secondary.

original: sarvātmanādhāratayā niyantṛtayā śeṣitayā ca āpnotīty ātmā sarvātmanādheyatayā niyāmyatayā śeṣatayā ca apṛthaksiddhaṃ prakārabhūtam ity ākāraḥ
analyzed: sarva ātmanā ādhāra tayā niyantṛ tayā śeṣi tayā ca āpnoti iti ātmā sarva ātmanā ādheya tayā niyāmya tayā śeṣa tayā ca apṛthak siddham prakāra bhūtam iti ākāraḥ
translated: The self is the substratum in its entirety, the controller in its entirety, and the principal in its entirety; while the body is the object in its entirety, the controlled in its entirety, and the secondary in its entirety. Thus, the body is inseparable from the self, being of the nature of a modification of it.

original: śarīram iti cocyate /
analyzed: śarīram iti ca ucyate
translated: And this is what is meant by the term ‘śarīra’, ‘body’.

original: evam eva hi jīvātmanaḥ svaśarīrasaṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: evam eva hi jīvātmanaḥ sva śarīra saṃbandhaḥ
translated: In the same way, the individual soul is related to its own body.

original: evam eva paramātmanaḥ sarvaśarīratvena sarvaśabdavācyatvam /
analyzed: evam eva paramātmanaḥ sarva śarīra tvena sarva śabda vācya tvam
translated: In the same way, the supreme self is denoted by the word ‘all’ because it is the body of all.

original: tad āha śrutigaṇaḥ sarve vedā yatpadam āmananti sarve vedā yatraikaṃ bhavantīti /
analyzed: tat āha śruti gaṇaḥ sarve vedāḥ yat padam āmananti sarve vedāḥ yatra ekam bhavanti iti
translated: This is stated by the group of scriptures, all the Vedas declare that one reality, all the Vedas become one there.

original: tasyaikasya vācyatvād ekārthavācino bhavantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ekasya vācya tvāt ekārtha vācinaḥ bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they become expressive of one meaning because that one is to be expressed.

original: eko devo bahudhā niviṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: ekaḥ devaḥ bahudhā niviṣṭaḥ
translated: The one God is distributed in many ways.

original: sahaiva santaṃ na vijānanti devā ityādi /
analyzed: saha eva santam na vijānanti devāḥ ityādi
translated: The gods do not know him who exists along with them, etc.

original: devā indriyāṇi /
analyzed: devāḥ indriyāṇi
translated: The gods are the sense organs.

original: devamanuṣyādīnām antaryāmitayātmatvena niviśya sahaiva santaṃ teṣām indriyāṇi manaḥparyantāni na vijānantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: deva manuṣya ādīnām antaryāmi tayā ātma tvena niviśya saha eva santam teṣām indriyāṇi manaḥ paryantāni na vijānanti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that having entered as the inner controller of gods, humans, etc., they do not know him who exists along with them, whose sense organs end with the mind.

original: tathā ca paurāṇikāni vacāṃsi
analyzed: tathā ca paurāṇikāni vacāṃsi
translated: And thus the Puranic statements

original: natāḥ sma sarvavacasāṃ pratiṣṭhā yatra śaśvatī /
analyzed: natāḥ sma sarva vacasām pratiṣṭhā yatra śaśvatī
translated: We bow to the eternal abode of all words,

original: vācye hi vacasaḥ pratiṣṭhā /
analyzed: vācye hi vacasaḥ pratiṣṭhā
translated: For the abode of words is in what is to be expressed.

original: kāryāṇāṃ kāraṇāṃ pūrvaṃ vacasāṃ vācyam uttamam /
analyzed: kāryāṇām kāraṇām pūrvam vacasām vācyam uttamam
translated: The cause of effects, the supreme of what is to be expressed by words,

original: vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyaḥ /
analyzed: vedaiḥ ca sarvaiḥ aham eva vedyaḥ
translated: And by all the Vedas I am to be known.

original: ityādīni sarvāṇi hi vacāṃsi saśarīrātmaviśiṣṭam antaryāmiṇam evācakṣate /
analyzed: ityādīni sarvāṇi hi vacāṃsi sa śarīra ātma viśiṣṭam antaryāmiṇam eva ācakṣate
translated: All these statements speak of the inner controller who is distinguished by the embodied self.

original: hantāham imās tisro devatā anena jīvenātmānupraviśya nāmarūpe vyākaravāṇīti hi śrutiḥ /
analyzed: hanta aham imāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ anena jīvena ātmā anupraviśya nāma rūpe vyākaravāṇi iti hi śrutiḥ
translated: For the scripture says: Having entered these three deities with this living self, I shall create names and forms.

original: tathā ca mānavaṃ vacaḥ
analyzed: tathā ca mānavam vacaḥ
translated: And thus the words of Manu:

original: praśāsitāraṃ sarveṣām aṇīyāṃsam aṇīyasām
analyzed: praśāsitāram sarveṣām aṇīyāṃsam aṇīyasām
translated: The ruler of all, the smallest of the small,

original: rukmābhaṃ svapnadhīgamyaṃ vidyāt taṃ puruṣaṃ param //
analyzed: rukma ābham svapna dhī gamyam vidyāt tam puruṣam param
translated: The golden-hued, to be known through the intellect accessible in dreams - know that to be the supreme Person.

original: antaḥ praviśyāntaryāmitayā sarveṣāṃ praśāsitāraṃ niyantāram aṇīyāṃsa ātmānaḥ kṛtsnasyācetanasya
analyzed: antar praviśya antaryāmi tayā sarveṣām praśāsitāram niyantāram aṇīyāṃsaḥ ātmānaḥ kṛtsnasya acetanasya
translated: Having entered within, as the inner controller, the ruler of all, the controller, the smallest, the selves of the entire insentient universe,

original: vyāpakatayā sūkṣmabhūtās te teṣām api vyāpakatvāt tebhyo 'pi sūkṣmatara ityarthaḥ
analyzed: vyāpaka tayā sūkṣma bhūtāḥ te teṣām api vyāpaka tvāt tebhyaḥ pi sūkṣmataraḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: being all-pervading, are subtle. Since He is all-pervading even of those, He is subtler than them. This is the meaning.

original: rukmābhaḥ ādityavarṇaḥ svapnakalpabuddhiprāpyaḥ /
analyzed: rukma ābhaḥ āditya varṇaḥ svapna kalpa buddhi prāpyaḥ
translated: Golden-hued: having the color of the sun. To be attained through the intellect accessible in dreams.

original: viśadatamapratyakṣatāpannānudhyānaikalabhya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: viśadatama pratyakṣa tā āpanna anudhyāna eka labhyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: to be attained only through meditation that has attained the state of the clearest and most intense perception.

original: enam eke vadanty agniṃ māruto 'nye prajāpatim /
analyzed: enam eke vadanti agnim mārutaḥ nye prajāpatim
translated: Some call Him Agni, others the wind, others Prajapati,

original: indram eke pare pramāṇam apare brahma śāśvatam //
analyzed: indram eke pare pramāṇam apare brahma śāśvatam
translated: Some Indra, others the eternal Brahman.

original: iti / eke vedā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti eke vedāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: some Vedas.

original: uktarītyā parasyaiva brahmaṇaḥ sarvasya praśāsitṛtvena sarvāntarātmatayā praviśyāvasthitatvād agnyādayaḥ śabdā api śāśvatabrahmaśabdavat tasyaiva
analyzed: ukta rītyā parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ sarvasya praśāsitṛ tvena sarva antarātma tayā praviśya avasthita tvāt agni ādayaḥ śabdāḥ api śāśvata brahma śabda vat tasya eva
translated: By the stated method, since the supreme Brahman alone, as the ruler of all and as the inner self of all, exists having entered, the words Agni and so on, like the word eternal Brahman,

original: vācakā bhavantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: vācakāḥ bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: are the denotators of Him alone. This is the meaning.

original: tathā ca smṛtyantaram
analyzed: tathā ca smṛti antaram
translated: And so another Smṛti text says:

original: ye yajanti pitQn devān brāhmaṇān sahutāśanān /
analyzed: ye yajanti pitqn devān brāhmaṇān sa hutāśanān
translated: Those who worship the ancestors, gods, brāhmaṇas, and the fire,

original: sarvabhūtāntarātmānaṃ viṣṇum eva yajanti te //
analyzed: sarva bhūta antarātmānam viṣṇum eva yajanti te
translated: they worship only Viṣṇu, the inner self of all beings.

original: iti / pitṛdevabrāhmaṇahutāśanādiśabdās tanmukhena tadantarātmabhūtasya viṣṇor eva vācakā ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iti pitṛ deva brāhmaṇa hutāśana ādi śabdāḥ tad mukhena tad antarātma bhūtasya viṣṇoḥ eva vācakāḥ iti uktam bhavati  /
translated: This means that the words ancestors, gods, brāhmaṇas, fire, etc. are said to be the words of Viṣṇu himself, who is the inner self of those [ancestors, etc.].

original: atredaṃ sarvaśāstrahṛdayam jīvātmānaḥ svayam asaṃkucitāparicchinnanirmalajñānasvarūpāḥ santaḥ karmarūpāvidyāveṣṭitās tattatkarmānurūpajñānasaṃkocam
analyzed: atrā idam sarva śāstra hṛdayam jīvātmānaḥ svayam asaṃkucita aparicchinna nirmala jñāna svarūpāḥ santaḥ karma rūpa avidyā veṣṭitāḥ tad tad karma anurūpa jñāna saṃkocam
translated: Here is the heart of all the scriptures: The individual selves, being themselves unshrunk, unlimited, pure knowledge, when enveloped by ignorance in the form of actions,

original: brahmādistambaparyantavividhavicitradeheṣu praviśṭās tattaddehocitalabdhajñānaprasarās
analyzed: brahma ādi stamba paryanta vividha vicitra deheṣu praviśṭāḥ tad tad deha ucita labdha jñāna prasarāḥ
translated: enter into various wonderful bodies ranging from Brahmā to a blade of grass, with the expansion of knowledge obtained suitable to that and that body,

original: tattaddehātmābhimāninas taducitakarmāṇi kurvāṇās tadanuguṇasukhaduḥkhopabhogarūpasaṃsārapravāhaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: tad tad deha ātma abhimāninaḥ tad ucita karmāṇi kurvāṇāḥ tad anuguṇa sukha duḥkha upabhoga rūpa saṃsāra pravāham pratipadyante
translated: conceiving themselves to be the self of that and that body, performing the actions appropriate to it, and thus undergo the current of worldly existence in the form of the experience of happiness and sorrow in accordance with that.

original: eteṣāṃ saṃsāramocanaṃ bhagavatprapattim antareṇa nopapadyata iti tadarthaḥ prathamam eṣāṃ devādibhedarahitajñānaikākāratayā sarveṣāṃ sāmyaṃ
analyzed: eteṣām saṃsāra mocanam bhagavat prapattim antareṇa nā upapadyate iti tad arthaḥ prathamam eṣām deva ādi bheda rahita jñāna eka ākāra tayā sarveṣām sāmyam
translated: The liberation of these from the cycle of birth and death is not possible without devotion to the Lord, therefore, for that purpose, first, their identity in all respects is taught through the form of knowledge devoid of distinctions such as gods etc.

original: tasyāpi svarūpasya bhagavaccheṣataikarasatayā bhagavadātmakatām api pratipādya /
analyzed: tasya api svarūpasya bhagavat śeṣa tā ekarasa tayā bhagavat ātmaka tām api pratipādya
translated: Even that nature is taught to be of the nature of the Lord through the single essence of being subordinate to the Lord.

original: bhagavatsvarūpaṃ ca heyapratyanīlakalyāṇaikatānatayā sakaletaravisajātīyam anavadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇagaṇāśrayaṃ
analyzed: bhagavat svarūpam ca heya pratyanīla kalyāṇa ekatāna tayā sakala itara visajātīyam anavadhika atiśaya asaṃkhyeya kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa āśrayam
translated: And the nature of the Lord is of a different kind from all other complete [entities] through being solely intent on the auspicious, which is the opposite of the undesirable, and is the abode of an infinite, excessive, innumerable multitude of auspicious qualities.

original: svasaṃkalpapravṛttasamastacidacidvastujātatayā sarvasyātmabhūtaṃ pratipādya /
analyzed: sva saṃkalpa pravṛtta samasta cit acit vastu jātatayā sarvasya ātma bhūtam pratipādya
translated: And it is taught that all things, consisting of both conscious and unconscious entities, are of the nature of the self through being engaged in one's own volition.

original: tadupāsana sāṅgaṃ tatprāpakaṃ pratipadayanti śāstrāṇīti /
analyzed: tad upāsana sa aṅgam tad prāpakam pratipadayanti śāstrāṇi iti
translated: And the scriptures teach the means of attaining that, along with its auxiliaries, which leads to the attainment of that.

original: yathoktam
analyzed: yathā uktam
translated: As it is said:

original: nirvāṇamaya evāyam ātmā jñānamayo 'malaḥ /
analyzed: nirvāṇa mayaḥ eva ayam ātmā jñāna mayaḥ malaḥ
translated: This self is indeed made of liberation, made of knowledge, and pure.

original: duḥkhājñānamalā dharmā prakṛtes te na cātmanaḥ /
analyzed: duḥkha ajñāna malāḥ dharmāḥ prakṛteḥ te na ca ātmanaḥ
translated: The qualities of pain, ignorance, and impurity belong to prakṛti, not to the self.

original: iti prakṛtisaṃsargakṛtakarmamūlatvān nātmadvarūpaprayuktā dharmā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti prakṛti saṃsarga kṛta karma mūla tvāt na ātma dva rūpa prayuktāḥ dharmāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the qualities are not produced by the nature of the self, because they are rooted in actions produced by the association with prakṛti.

original: prāptāprāptavivekena prakṛter eva dharmā ityuktam /
analyzed: prāpta aprāpta vivekena prakṛteḥ eva dharmāḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that the qualities belong to Prakṛti itself, by distinguishing what is attained and what is not attained.

original: vidyāvinayasaṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini /
analyzed: vidyā vinaya saṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
translated: In a Brahmin endowed with knowledge and humility, in a cow, in an elephant,

original: śuni caiva śvapāke ca pāṇḍitāḥ samadarśinaḥ /
analyzed: śuni ca eva śvapāke ca pāṇḍitāḥ sama darśinaḥ
translated: in a dog, and even in an outcaste, the wise see the same.

original: iti / devatiryaṅmanuṣyasthāvararūpaprakṛtisaṃsṛṣṭasyātmanaḥ svarūpavivecanī buddhir eṣāṃ te paṇḍitāḥ /
analyzed: iti deva tiryak manuṣya sthāvara rūpa prakṛti saṃsṛṣṭasya ātmanaḥ svarūpa vivecanī buddhiḥ eṣām te paṇḍitāḥ
translated: Thus, they have the intellect that distinguishes the nature of the Self mixed with the forms of gods, animals, humans, and inanimate objects. They are the wise ones.

original: tattat prakṛtiviśeṣaviyuktātmayāthātmyajñānavantas tatra tatrātyantaviṣamākāre vartamānam ātmānaṃ samānākāraṃ paśyantīti samadarśina ity uktam
analyzed: tat tat prakṛti viśeṣa viyukta ātma yāthātmya jñānavantaḥ tatra tatra atyanta viṣama ākāre vartamānam ātmānam samāna ākāram paśyanti iti sama darśinaḥ iti uktam
translated: They possess the knowledge of the true nature of the Self, which is free from the various specific natures. It is said that they see the Self, which appears in various extremely dissimilar forms, as having the same form.

original: tad idam āha
analyzed: tat idam āha
translated: This is what is being said:

original: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṃ sāmye sthitaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: iha eva taiḥ jitaḥ sargaḥ yeṣām sāmye sthitam manaḥ
translated: Those whose minds are established in equality have conquered birth and death right here.

original: nirdoṣaṃ hi samaṃ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ //
analyzed: nirdoṣam hi samam brahma tasmāt brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
translated: For Brahman is free from faults and equal. Therefore, they abide in Brahman.

original: iti / nirdoṣaṃ devādiprakṛtiviśeṣasaṃsargarūpadoṣarahitaṃ svarūpeṇāvasthitaṃ sarvam ātmavastu nirvāṇarūpajñānaikākāratayā samam ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti nirdoṣam deva ādi prakṛti viśeṣa saṃsarga rūpa doṣa rahitam sva rūpeṇa avasthitam sarvam ātma vastu nirvāṇa rūpa jñāna eka ākāra tayā samam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that all things that are the Self, which abide in their own nature, free from faults in the form of contact with specific natures such as gods, are equal in the form of the knowledge that is the nature of liberation.

original: tasyaivaṃbhūtasyātmano bhagavaccheṣataikarasatā tanniyāmyatā tadekādhāratā ca taccharīratattanuprabhṛtibhiḥ
analyzed: tasya evaṃbhūtasya ātmanaḥ bhagavat śeṣa tā ekarasa tā tad niyāmya tā tad eka ādhāra tā ca tad śarīra tad tanu prabhṛtibhiḥ
translated: The Lord's supremacy, control over it, and being its sole basis are expressed by His body, His form, etc.

original: śabdais tatsamānādhikaraṇyena ca śrutismṛtītihāsapurāṇeṣu pratipādyata iti pūrvam evoktam /
analyzed: śabdaiḥ tad samāna adhikaraṇyena ca śruti smṛti itihāsa purāṇeṣu pratipādyate iti pūrvam eva uktam  /
translated: It has been said before that this kind of Self is taught in the scriptures, Puranas, Itihasas, Smritis, and in the Upanishads, by words like the body of that, the form of that, etc., as being of the nature of being the remainder of the Lord, as being governed by Him, and as having Him as its sole support.

original: daivī hy eṣā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā /
analyzed: daivī hi eṣā guṇa mayī mama māyā duratyayā
translated: For this, My divine Maya, consisting of the gunas, is hard to cross without resorting to Me.

original: mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etāṃ taranti te //
analyzed: mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etām taranti te
translated: Those who resort to Me alone cross over this Maya.

original: iti tasyātmanaḥ karmakṛtavicitraguṇamayaprakṛtisaṃsargarūpāt saṃsārān mokṣo bhagavatprapattim antareṇa nopapadayata ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iti tasya ātmanaḥ karma kṛta vicitra guṇa maya prakṛti saṃsarga rūpāt saṃsārāt mokṣaḥ bhagavat prapattim antareṇa na upapadayate iti uktam bhavati
translated: Thus, it is said that liberation from the world, which is of the nature of contact with the Prakṛti consisting of various gunas created by karma, of that Self, is not possible without devotion to the Lord.

original: nānyaḥ panthā ayanāya vidyata ityādiśrutibhiś ca /
analyzed: na anyaḥ panthāḥ ayanāya vidyate ityādi śrutibhiḥ ca
translated: And by the Upanishadic texts like There is no other path for going (to Brahman) etc.

original: mayā tatam idaṃ sarvaṃ jagad avyaktamūrtinā /
analyzed: mayā tatam idam sarvam jagat avyakta mūrtinā
translated: This entire world is pervaded by Me, having an unmanifest form.

original: matsthāni sarvabhūtāni na cāhaṃ teṣu avasthitaḥ //
analyzed: mad sthāni sarva bhūtāni na ca aham teṣu avasthitaḥ
translated: All beings abide in Me, but I do not abide in them.

original: na ca matsthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogam aiśvaram //
analyzed: na ca mad sthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogam aiśvaram
translated: And the beings do not abide in Me. See My divine Yoga.

original: iti sarvaśaktiyogāt svāiśvaryavaicitryam uktam / tad āha
analyzed: iti sarva śakti yogāt sva aiśvarya vaicitryam uktam tat āha
translated: Thus, the diversity of one's own lordship is stated by the Yoga of all powers. That is said (in the following verse):

original: viṣṭabhyāham idaṃ kṛtsnam ekāṃśena sthito jagat /🔽iti anantavicitramahāścaryarūpaṃ jagan mamāyutāṃśenātmatayā praviśya sarvaṃ matsaṃkalpena
analyzed: viṣṭabhya aham idam kṛtsnam eka aṃśena sthitaḥ jagat  iti ananta vicitra mahā āścarya rūpam jagat mama ayuta aṃśena ātma tayā praviśya sarvam mad saṃkalpena
translated: I am supporting this entire world with one of My parts.🔽Thus, the world, which has an infinite variety of great wonders, having entered into it as the Self with a thousandth part of Myself,

original: viṣṭabhyānena rūpeṇānantamahāvibhūtiparimitodāraguṇasāgaro niratiśayāścaryabhūtaḥ
analyzed: viṣṭabhya anena rūpeṇa ananta mahā vibhūti parimita udāra guṇa sāgaraḥ niratiśaya āścarya bhūtaḥ
translated: supporting it with this form, being limited by My infinite great glory and ocean of abundant qualities, being of an incomparable wonder,

original: sthito 'ham ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: sthitaḥ ham iti arthaḥ
translated: I remain. This is the meaning.

original: tad idam āha
analyzed: tat idam āha
translated: This is said:

original: ekatve sati nānātvaṃ nānātve sati caikatā /
analyzed: eka tve sati nānātvam nānātve sati ca ekatā
translated: In unity there is diversity, and in diversity there is unity.

original: acintyaṃ brahmaṇo rūpaṃ kutas tadveditum arhati //
analyzed: acintyam brahmaṇaḥ rūpam kutas tat veditum arhati
translated: The form of Brahman is inconceivable. How can one know it?

original: iti / praśāsitṛtvenaika eva sanvicitracidacidvastuṣv antarātmatayā praviśya tattadrūpeṇa vicitraprakāro vicitrakarma kārayan nānārūpāṃ bhajate
analyzed: iti praśāsitṛ tvena ekaḥ eva san vicitra cit acit vastuṣu antarātma tayā praviśya tad tad rūpeṇa vicitra prakāraḥ vicitra karma kārayan nānā rūpām bhajate
translated: Thus, being the sole ruler, having entered into the various conscious and unconscious things as the inner Self, causing various kinds of actions to be done in those forms, He assumes various forms.

original: evaṃ svalpāṃśena tu sarvāścaryaṃ nānārūpaṃ jagattadantarātmatayā praviśya viṣṭabhya
analyzed: evam su alpa aṃśena tu sarva āścaryam nānā rūpam jagat tad antarātma tayā praviśya viṣṭabhya
translated: In this way, with a small part, the world with its various wonders, having entered into it as the inner Self, supporting it,

original: nānātvenāvasthito 'pi sann anavadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇagaṇaḥ sarveśvaraḥ
analyzed: nānātvena avasthitaḥ san anavadhika atiśaya asaṃkhyeya kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇaḥ sarveśvaraḥ
translated: though remaining in various forms, He is the Lord of all, with an unlimited, extraordinary, innumerable collection of auspicious qualities.

original: parabrahmabhūtaḥ puruṣottamo nārāyaṇo niratiśayāścaryabhūto nīlatoyadasaṃkāśaḥ puṇḍarīkadalāmalāyatekṣaṇaḥ
analyzed: para brahma bhūtaḥ puruṣottamaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ niratiśaya āścarya bhūtaḥ nīla toyada saṃkāśaḥ puṇḍarīka dala amala āyata īkṣaṇaḥ
translated: The Supreme Brahman, the best of men, Narayana, of incomparable wonder, resembling a dark raincloud, with eyes pure like lotus petals,

original: sahasrāṃśusahasrakiraṇaḥ parame vyomni yo veda nihitaṃ guhāyāṃ parame vyomaṃs tadakṣare
analyzed: sahasra aṃśu sahasra kiraṇaḥ parame vyomni yaḥ veda nihitam guhāyām parame vyoman tat akṣare
translated: who is known to be hidden in the highest heaven, in the highest sky, in the imperishable,

original: parame vyomann ityādiśrutisiddha eka evātiṣṭhate /
analyzed: parame vyoman ityādi śruti siddhaḥ ekaḥ eva ātiṣṭhate
translated: the one who is established as proved by scriptures like in the highest sky etc.

original: brahmavyatiriktasya kasyacid api vastuna ekasvabhāvasyaikakāryaśaktiyuktasyaikarūpasya rūpāntarayogaḥ svabhāvāntarayogaḥ śaktyantarayogaś ca
analyzed: brahma vyatiriktasya kasyacid api vastunaḥ eka svabhāvasya eka kārya śakti yuktasya eka rūpasya rūpa antara yogaḥ svabhāva antara yogaḥ śakti antara yogaḥ ca
translated: For anything other than Brahman, which is of one nature, endowed with the power of one effect, and of one form, the connection with another form, the connection with another nature, and the connection with another power

original: na ghaṭate /
analyzed: na ghaṭate
translated: are not possible.

original: tasyaitasya parabrahmaṇaḥ sarvavastuvijātīyatayā sarvasvabhāvatvaṃ sarvaśaktiyogaś
analyzed: tasya etasya para brahmaṇaḥ sarva vastu vijātīya tayā sarva svabhāva tvam sarva śakti yogaḥ
translated: This Supreme Brahman, being of a different kind from all things, has the nature of all and is endowed with all powers,

original: cety ekasyaiva vicitrānantarūpatā ca punar apy anantāparimitāścaryayogenaikarūpatā
analyzed: ca iti ekasya eva vicitra ananta rūpatā ca punar api ananta aparimita āścarya yogena eka rūpatā
translated: and has the variegated infinite forms of just one, and again the oneness with the connection of infinite and immeasurable wonders

original: ca na viruddheti vastumātrasāmyād virodhacintā na yuktetyarthaḥ / yathoktaṃ
analyzed: ca na viruddhā iti vastu mātra sāmyāt virodha cintā na yuktā iti arthaḥ yathā uktam
translated: is not contradictory. The meaning is that the consideration of contradiction is not proper due to the similarity of mere things, as stated:

original: śaktayaḥ sarvabhāvānām acintyajñānagocarāḥ /
analyzed: śaktayaḥ sarva bhāvānām acintya jñāna gocarāḥ
translated: The powers of all things are the domain of inconceivable knowledge.

original: yato 'to brahmaṇas tās tu sargādyā bhāvaśaktayaḥ //
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ tāḥ tu sarga ādyāḥ bhāva śaktayaḥ
translated: Therefore, O best of ascetics, these powers of creation etc. of Brahman

original: bhavanti tapasāṃ śreṣṭa pāvakasya yathoṣṇatā //iti /
analyzed: bhavanti tapasām śreṣṭa pāvakasya yathā uṣṇa tāḥ iti
translated: exist, like the heat of fire.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati sarveṣām agnijalādīnāṃ bhāvānām ekasminn api bhāve dṛṣṭaiva śaktis
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati sarveṣām agni jala ādīnām bhāvānām ekasmin api bhāve dṛṣṭā eva śaktiḥ
translated: This is what is said: The power is seen in every single entity, such as fire, water, etc.,

original: tadvijātīyabhāvāntare 'pīti na cintayituṃ yuktā jalādāv adṛṣṭāpi tadvijātīyapāvake
analyzed: tad vijātīya bhāva antare pi iti na cintayitum yuktā jala ādau adṛṣṭā api tad vijātīya pāvake
translated: and it is not proper to think that even though not seen in water etc., the power of luminosity, heat, etc. of that dissimilar entity fire

original: bhāsvaratvoṣṇatādiśaktir yathā dṛśyate /
analyzed: bhāsvara tva uṣṇa tā ādi śaktiḥ yathā dṛśyate
translated: is seen.

original: evam eva sarvavastuvisajātīye brahmaṇi sarvasāmyaṃ nānumātuṃ yuktam iti /
analyzed: evam eva sarva vastu visajātīye brahmaṇi sarva sāmyam na anumātum yuktam iti
translated: In the same way, it is not proper to infer complete similarity in Brahman, which is dissimilar to all entities.

original: ato vicitrānantaśaktiyuktaṃ brahmaivetyarthaḥ tad āha
analyzed: atas vicitra ananta śakti yuktam brahma eva iti arthaḥ tat āha
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that Brahman alone possesses various infinite powers. He says this:

original: jagad etan mahāścaryaṃ rūpaṃ yasya mahātmanaḥ /
analyzed: jagat etat mahā āścaryam rūpam yasya mahātmanaḥ
translated: This world is the great wonder, the form of that great soul.

original: tenāścaryavareṇāhaṃ bhavatā kṛṣṇa saṃgataḥ //
analyzed: tena āścarya vareṇa aham bhavatā kṛṣṇa saṃgataḥ
translated: Therefore, O Krishna, I am united with you, the best of wonders.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: tad etan nānāvidhānantaśrutinikaraśiṣṭaparigṛhītatadvyākhyānapariśramād avadhāritam /
analyzed: tat etat nānāvidha ananta śruti nikara śiṣṭa parigṛhīta tad vyākhyāna pariśramāt avadhāritam
translated: This is understood from the effort of comprehending the various explanations accepted by the learned based on the multitude of scriptures of various kinds and the infinite number of scriptures.

original: tathā hi pramāṇāntarāparidṛṣṭāparimitapariṇāmān ekatattvaniyatakramaviśiṣṭau sṛṣṭipralayau
analyzed: tathā hi pramāṇa antara aparidṛṣṭa aparimita pariṇāmān eka tattva niyata krama viśiṣṭau sṛṣṭi pralayau
translated: For thus, the scriptures declare the creation and dissolution of Brahman, which are distinguished by a definite order of the one reality, and which are not seen or measured by other means of knowledge.

original: brahmaṇo 'nekavidhāḥ śrutayo vadanti niravadyaṃ nirañjanaṃ vijñānam ānandaṃ nirvikāraṃ

original: niṣkalaṃ niṣkriyaṃ śāntaṃ nirguṇam ity ādikāḥ nirguṇaṃ jñānasvarūpaṃ brahmeti kāścana🔽śrutayo 'bhidadhati /

translated: Some scriptures declare that Brahman is of the nature of pure consciousness.

analyzed: na iha nānā asti kiṃcana mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaḥ iha nānā iva paśyati yatra tu asya  sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet tat kena kam vijātīyāt iti ādikāḥ nānātva niṣedha vādinyaḥ

original: vimṛtyur viśoko vijaghatso 'pipāsaḥ satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpa iti sarvasmiñ jagati

translated: He is free from death, sorrow, hunger, thirst, has truth as his desire and truth as his resolve. In the entire world,

original: heyatayāvagataṃ sarvaguṇaṃ pratiṣidhya niratiśayakalyāṇaguṇānantyaṃ sarvajñatā sarvaśaktiyogaṃ
analyzed: heya tayā avagatam sarva guṇam pratiṣidhya niratiśaya kalyāṇa guṇa ānantyam sarvajña tā sarva śakti yogam
translated: He is free from death, free from sorrow, free from hunger, free from thirst, having truth for his desire, and truth for his resolve. Thus, having denied all the qualities that are considered undesirable in the entire world, some scriptures declare that Brahman has infinite and supreme auspicious qualities, omniscience, union with all powers,

original: sarvanāmarūpavyākaraṇaṃ sarvasyāvadhāratāṃ ca kāścana śrutayo bruvate /
analyzed: sarvanāma rūpa vyākaraṇam sarvasya avadhāra tām ca kāścana śrutayaḥ bruvate
translated: the designation of all names and forms, and the knowledge of all things.

original: sarvaṃ khalv idaṃ brahma tajjalān iti aitadātmyam idaṃ sarvaṃ ekaḥ san bahudhā vicāra ityādikā brahmasṛṣṭaṃ jagan nānākāraṃ pratipādya tadaikyaṃ 🔽ca pratipādayanti kāścana /🔽pṛthagātmānaṃ preritāraṃ ca matvā bhoktā bhogyaṃ preritāraṃ ca matvā prajāpatir akāmayata
analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma tat jalān iti aitadātmyam idam sarvam ekaḥ san bahudhā vicāraḥ iti ādikā brahma sṛṣṭam jagat nānā ākāram pratipādya tat aikyam  ca pratipādayanti kāścana  pṛthak ātmānam preritāram ca matvā bhoktā bhogyam preritāram ca matvā prajāpatiḥ akāmayata
translated: Having taught that the world created by Brahman is of various forms, some scriptures teach its oneness, saying, Verily, all this is Brahman, that is born of water, This all is that Self, He, being one, became many by reflection, and so on.🔽Some scriptures teach that the individual soul is different from the impelling force, and that Prajapati, having considered the enjoyer, the object of enjoyment, and the impelling force,

original: prajāḥ sṛjeyeti patiṃ viśvasyātmeśvaraṃ śvāstaṃ śivam acyutaṃ tam īśvarāṇāṃ paraṃ
analyzed: prajāḥ sṛjeya iti patim viśvasya ātma īśvaram śva astam śivam acyutam tam īśvarāṇām param
translated: desired, Let me create progeny. He, the lord of the universe, the Self, the supreme, the auspicious, the imperishable, the highest of the lords,

original: maheśvaraṃ taṃ devatānāṃ paraṃ ca daivataṃ sarvasya vaśī sarvasyeśāna ityādikā brahmaṇaḥ
analyzed: maheśvaram tam devatānām param ca daivatam sarvasya vaśī sarvasya īśānaḥ iti ādikāḥ brahmaṇaḥ
translated: the great lord, the highest divinity of the deities, the controller of all, the lord of all, and so on.

original: sarvasmād anyatvaṃ sarvasyeśitavyam īśvaratvaṃ ca brahmaṇaḥ sarvasya śeṣatāṃ patitvaṃ🔽ceśvarasya kāścana /
analyzed: sarvasmāt anya tvam sarvasya īśitavyam īśvara tvam ca brahmaṇaḥ sarvasya śeṣatām patitvam  ca īśvarasya kāścana
translated: The difference of Brahman from all else, the fact of Brahman being the Lord of all, and the fact of all things being subordinate to Brahman,🔽and the fact of the Lord being the inner controller of all, are declared in some passages.

original: antaḥ praviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānāṃ sarvātmā eṣa ta ātmāntaryāmy amṛtaḥ yasya pṛthivī śarīraṃ yasyāpaḥ śarīraṃ
analyzed: antar praviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānām sarva ātmā eṣa te ātmā antaryāmī amṛtaḥ yasya pṛthivī śarīram yasya āpaḥ śarīram
translated: The inner controller of all, the soul of all, He is your self, the inner controller, the immortal, of whom the earth is the body, of whom the waters are the body,

original: yasya tejaḥ śarīram ityādi yasyāvyaktaṃ śarīraṃ yasyākṣaraṃ śarīraṃ yasya mṛtyuḥ
analyzed: yasya tejaḥ śarīram ityādi yasya avyaktam śarīram yasya akṣaram śarīram yasya mṛtyuḥ
translated: of whom fire is the body, etc., of whom the unmanifest is the body, of whom the imperishable is the body, of whom death is the body,

original: śarīraṃ yasyātmā śarīram iti brahmavyatiriktasya sarvasya vastuno brahmaṇaś ca śarīrātmabhāvaṃ
analyzed: śarīram yasya ātmā śarīram iti brahma vyatiriktasya sarvasya vastunaḥ brahmaṇaḥ ca śarīra ātma bhāvam
translated: of whom the self is the body, thus some passages declare the state of being the body and the self of all things other than Brahman, and of Brahman itself.

original: darśayanti kāścaneti / 🔽nānārūpāṇāṃ vākyānām avirodho mukhyārthāparityāgaś ca yathā saṃbhavati tathā varṇanīyam /🔽varṇitaṃ ca avikāraśrutayaḥ svarūpapariṇāmaparihārād eva mukhyārthāḥ /
analyzed: darśayanti kāścana iti  nānā rūpāṇām vākyānām avirodhaḥ mukhya artha aparityāgaḥ ca yathā saṃbhavati tathā varṇanīyam  varṇitam ca avikāra śrutayaḥ svarūpa pariṇāma parihārāt eva mukhya arthāḥ
translated: Some passages declare this.🔽The non-contradiction of the various forms of statements and the avoidance of abandoning the primary meaning should be explained as far as possible.🔽And it has been explained that the statements about immutability are primary in meaning itself, by avoiding the transformation of the nature.

original: nirguṇavādāś ca prākṛtaheyaguṇaniṣedhaparatayā vyavasthitāḥ /
analyzed: nirguṇa vādāḥ ca prākṛta heya guṇa niṣedha para tayā vyavasthitāḥ
translated: And the teachings about the attributeless are established as having the purpose of negating the attributes that are to be abandoned by the unmanifest.

original: nānātvaniṣedhavādāś caikasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīratayā prakārabhūtaṃ sarvaṃ cetanācetanaṃ vastv iti sarvasyātmatayā sarvaprakāraṃ brahmaivāvasthitam
analyzed: nānātva niṣedha vādāḥ ca ekasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīra tayā prakāra bhūtam sarvam cetana acetanam vastu iti sarvasya ātma tayā sarva prakāram brahma eva avasthitam  /
translated: And the doctrines of the denial of diversity are well-guarded, because all the various things, both conscious and unconscious, are of the nature of Brahman as its body, and Brahman alone abides in all forms as the Self of all.

original: iti surakṣitāḥ /🔽sarvaprakāravilakṣaṇatvapatitveśvaratvasarvakalyāṇaguṇagaṇākāratvasatyakāmatvasatyasaṃkalpatvādivākyaṃ tadabhyupagamād eva surakṣitam /
analyzed: iti su rakṣitāḥ  sarva prakāra vilakṣaṇa tva patitva īśvara tva sarva kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa ākāra tva satya kāma tva satya saṃkalpa tva ādi vākyam tad abhyupagamāt eva su rakṣitam
translated: Thus they are well-guarded.🔽The statements about being unlike all forms, being the Lord, having the nature of all auspicious qualities, having true desires, having true intentions, and so on, are well-guarded by the acceptance of that very thing.

original: jñānānandamātravādi ca sarvasmād anyasya sarvakalyāṇaguṇagaṇāśrayasya sarveśvarasya
analyzed: jñāna ānanda mātra vādi ca sarvasmāt anyasya sarva kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa āśrayasya sarva īśvarasya
translated: And the doctrine that Brahman is mere knowledge and bliss is well-maintained, because it teaches that Brahman, which is the abode of all auspicious qualities, the Lord of all,

original: sarvaśeṣiṇaḥ sarvādhārasya sarvotpattisthitipralayahetubhūtasya niravadyasya nirvikārasya🔽sarvātmabhūtasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ svarūpanirūpakadharmo malapratyanīkānandarūpajñānam
analyzed: sarva śeṣiṇaḥ sarva ādhārasya sarva utpatti sthiti pralaya hetu bhūtasya niravadyasya nirvikārasya  sarva ātma bhūtasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ svarūpa nirūpaka dharmaḥ mala pratyanīka ānanda rūpa jñānam
translated: the remainder of all, the support of all, the cause of the origin, sustenance, and dissolution of all, the faultless, the changeless,🔽the Brahman that is the Self of all, has as its nature the knowledge that has the form of bliss, which is the opposite of impurity.

original: eveti svaprakāśatayā svarūpam api jñānam eveti ca pratipādanād anupālitam /
analyzed: eva iti sva prakāśa tayā sva rūpam api jñānam eva iti ca pratipādanāt anupālitam
translated: And because it teaches that its own nature is also knowledge, since it is self-luminous and is Brahman itself.

original: aikyavādāś ca śarīrātmabhāvena sāmānādhikaraṇyamukhyārthatopapādanād eva susthitāḥ /
analyzed: aikya vādāḥ ca śarīra ātma bhāvena sāmānādhikaraṇya mukhya artha tā upapādanāt eva susthitāḥ
translated: And the doctrines of identity are quite well established, because they are explained as having the primary meaning of co-reference through the identity of the body and the self.

original: evaṃ ca saty abhedo vā bhedo vā dvyātmakatā vā vedāntavedyaḥ ko 'yam arthaḥ samarthito bhavati /
analyzed: evam ca sati abhedaḥ vā bhedaḥ vā dvi ātmaka tā vā vedānta vedyaḥ kaḥ yam arthaḥ samarthitaḥ bhavati
translated: And thus, what is this meaning that is to be established, whether non-difference, difference, or duality, as the object of knowledge of the Vedanta?

original: sarvasya vedavedyatvāt sarvaṃ samarthitam /
analyzed: sarvasya veda vedya tvāt sarvam samarthitam
translated: Since everything is to be known from the Vedas, everything is established.

original: sarvaśarīratayā sarvaprakāraṃ brahmaivāvasthitam ity abhedaḥ samarthitaḥ /
analyzed: sarva śarīra tayā sarva prakāram brahma eva avasthitam iti abhedaḥ samarthitaḥ
translated: It is established that there is non-difference, since Brahman alone exists in all bodies and in all ways.

original: ekam eva brahma nānābhūtacidacidvastuprakāraṃ nānātvenāvasthitam iti bhedābhedau /
analyzed: ekam eva brahma nānā bhūta cit acit vastu prakāram nānātvena avasthitam iti bheda abhedau
translated: It is established that there is difference and non-difference, since Brahman alone exists in many ways as the various entities of the manifest and unmanifest.

original: acidvastunaś cidvastunaś ceśvarasya ca svarūpasvabhāvavailakṣaṇyād asaṃkarāc ca bhedaḥ samarthitaḥ /
analyzed: acit vastunaḥ cit vastunaḥ ca īśvarasya ca svarūpa svabhāva vailakṣaṇyāt asaṃkarāt ca bhedaḥ samarthitaḥ
translated: It is established that there is difference, because the unmanifest entities and the conscious entity, the Lord, have different natures and forms, and because there is no confusion.

original: nanu ca tat tvam asi śvetaketo tasya tāvad eva ciram ity aikyajñānam eva paramapuruṣārthalakṣaṇamokṣasādhanam iti gamyate /
analyzed: nanu ca tat tvam asi śvetaketo tasya tāvat eva ciram iti aikya jñānam eva parama puruṣa artha lakṣaṇa mokṣa sādhanam iti gamyate
translated: But it is understood that the knowledge of identity alone, as in That thou art, O Śvetaketu, and For him, it is only for a long time, is the means to liberation, which is characterized as the highest human goal.

original: naitad evam /
analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

original: pṛthagātmānaṃ preritāraṃ ca matvā juṣṭas tatas tenāmṛtatvam etīty ātmānaṃ preritāraṃ🔽cāntaryāmiṇaṃ pṛthag matvā tataḥ pṛthaktvajñānād dhetos tena paramātmanā juṣṭo 'mṛtatvam
analyzed: pṛthak ātmānam preritāram ca matvā juṣṭaḥ tatas tena amṛta tvam eti iti ātmānam preritāram  ca antaryāmiṇam pṛthak matvā tatas pṛthaktva jñānāt hetoḥ tena paramātmanā juṣṭaḥ mṛta tvam
translated: Having known the Self and the impeller to be different, he becomes united with Him and attains immortality. Having known the Self and the inner controller to be different,🔽from that knowledge of difference, he becomes united with the Supreme Self and attains immortality.

original: etīti sākṣādamṛtatvaprāptisādhanam ātmano niyantuś ca pṛthagbhāvajñānam evety avagamyate /
analyzed: eti iti sākṣāt amṛta tva prāpti sādhanam ātmanaḥ niyantuḥ ca pṛthagbhāva jñānam eva iti avagamyate
translated: Having known the Self and the impeller to be separate, he is then satisfied by that and attains immortality. Thus it is understood that the knowledge of the separateness of the Self, the controller, and the inner controller is itself the means of directly attaining immortality.

original: aikyavākyavirodhād etadaparamārthasaguṇabrahmaprāptiviṣayam ity abhyupagantavyam iti cet /
analyzed: aikya vākya virodhāt etat a parama artha saguṇa brahma prāpti viṣayam iti abhyupagantavyam iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this should be accepted as referring to the attainment of the supreme Brahman with qualities, because it contradicts the statements about identity,

original: pṛthaktvajñānasyaiva sākṣādamṛtatvaprāptisādhanatvaśravaṇād viparītaṃ kasmān na bhavati /
analyzed: pṛthaktva jñānasya eva sākṣāt amṛta tva prāpti sādhana tva śravaṇāt viparītam kasmāt na bhavati
translated: why should it not be the opposite, since the knowledge of separateness alone is heard to be the means of directly attaining immortality?

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati
translated: This is what is said:

original: dvayor tulyayor virodhe saty avirodhena tayor viṣayo vivecanīya iti /
analyzed: dvayoḥ tulyayoḥ virodhe sati avirodhena tayoḥ viṣayaḥ vivecanīyaḥ iti
translated: When there is a contradiction between two equals, their objects should be distinguished without contradiction.

original: katham avirodha iti cet /
analyzed: katham avirodhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there is non-contradiction,

original: antaryāmirūpeṇāvasthitasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīratayā prakāratvāj jīvātmanas tatprakāraṃ brahmaiva tvam iti śabdenābhidhīyate /
analyzed: antaryāmi rūpeṇa avasthitasya parasya brahmaṇaḥ śarīra tayā prakāra tvāt jīvātmanaḥ tad prakāram brahma eva tvam iti śabdena abhidhīyate
translated: it is because the individual soul, being a mode of Brahman in the form of the inner controller, is denoted by the word you as being Brahman itself, which is that mode.

original: tathaiva jñātavyam iti tasya vākyasya viṣayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā eva jñātavyam iti tasya vākyasya viṣayaḥ
translated: The purport of that statement is that it should be known in the same way.

original: evaṃbhūtāj jīvāt tadātmatayāvasthitasya paramātmano nikhiladoṣarahitatayā satyasaṃkalpatvād
analyzed: evaṃbhūtāt jīvāt tad ātma tayā avasthitasya paramātmanaḥ nikhila doṣa rahita tayā satya saṃkalpa tvāt
translated: In this way, the individual soul, which exists as the Self of the Supreme Self, is to be understood as having a separate nature due to being free from all faults,

original: anavadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇagaṇākaratvena ca yaḥ pṛthagbhāvaḥ so 'nusaṃdheya
analyzed: anavadhika atiśaya asaṃkhyeya kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa ākara tvena ca yaḥ pṛthak bhāvaḥ saḥ nusaṃdheya
translated: having true intentions, and being the source of an inexhaustible, immeasurable, and innumerable collection of auspicious qualities.

original: ity asya vākyasya viṣaya ity ayam arthaḥ pūrvam asakṛduktaḥ /
analyzed: iti asya vākyasya viṣayaḥ iti ayam arthaḥ pūrvam asakṛt uktaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of this statement, which has been stated many times before.

original: bhoktā bhogyaṃ preritāraṃ ca matveti bhogyarūpasya vastuno 'cetanatvaṃ paramārthatvaṃ satataṃ vikārāspadatvam ityādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ /
analyzed: bhoktā bhogyam preritāram ca matvā iti bhogya rūpasya cetana tvam parama artha tvam satatam vikāra āspada tvam ityādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ
translated: The purport of the statement having known the enjoyer, the object of enjoyment, and the impeller is that the nature of the object of enjoyment is insentience, ultimate reality, and being the basis of constant change, etc.

original: bhoktur jīvātmanaś cāmalāparicchinnajñānānandasvabhāvasyaivānādikarmarūpāvidyākṛtanānāvidhajñānasaṃkocavikāsau
analyzed: bhoktuḥ jīvātmanaḥ ca amala aparicchinna jñāna ānanda svabhāvasya eva anādi karma rūpa avidyā kṛta nānāvidha jñāna saṃkoca vikāsau
translated: The nature of the individual soul, which is the enjoyer, is pure, unlimited knowledge and bliss, and the contraction and expansion of knowledge in various ways due to beginningless ignorance in the form of karma,

original: bhogyabhūtācidvastusaṃsargaś ca paramātmopāsanān mokṣaś cetyādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ /
analyzed: bhogya bhūta a cit vastu saṃsargaḥ ca paramātma upāsanāt mokṣaḥ ca ityādayaḥ svabhāvāḥ
translated: the association with the object of enjoyment, which is the sentient reality, and liberation through the worship of the Supreme Self, etc.

original: evaṃbhūtabhoktṛbhogyayor antaryāmirūpeṇāvasthānaṃ svarūpeṇa cāparimitaguṇaughāśrayatvenāvasthānam iti parasya brahmas trividhāvasthānaṃ jñātavyam
analyzed: evaṃbhūta bhoktṛ bhogyayoḥ antaryāmi rūpeṇa avasthānam svarūpeṇa ca aparimita guṇa ogha āśraya tvena avasthānam iti parasya brahmaḥ trividha avasthānam jñātavyam  /
translated: Thus, the Supreme Brahman should be known to have three states: as the inner controller of the existent enjoyer and the enjoyed, and as the abode of an unlimited multitude of qualities in its own nature.

original: ityarthaḥ //
analyzed: iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: tat tvam asīti sadvidyāyām upāsyaṃ brahma saguṇaṃ saguṇabrahmaprāptiś ca phalam ity abhiyuktaiḥ pūrvācāryair vyākhyātam /
analyzed: tat tvam asi iti sat vidyāyām upāsyam brahma sa guṇam sa guṇa brahma prāptiḥ ca phalam iti abhiyuktaiḥ pūrva ācāryaiḥ vyākhyātam
translated: In the Sāddhavidyā, the Brahman to be meditated upon is with qualities, and the attainment of Brahman with qualities is the fruit, thus it has been explained by the ancient teachers who are experts.

original: yathoktaṃ vākyakāreṇa yuktaṃ tadguṇakopāsanād iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam vākyakāreṇa yuktam tad guṇaka upāsanāt iti
translated: As it has been said by the author of the Vākyas: It is proper to attain it by meditating on it with its qualities.

original: vyākhyātaṃ ca dramiḍācāryeṇa vidyāvikalpaṃ vadatā yady api saccito na nirbhugnadaivataṃ🔽guṇagaṇaṃ manasānudhāvet tathāpy antarguṇām eva devatāṃ bhajata iti tatrāpi saguṇaiva
analyzed: vyākhyātam ca dramiḍa ācāryeṇa vidyā vikalpam vadatā yadi api saccitaḥ na nirbhugna daivatam  guṇa gaṇam manasā anudhāvet tathā api antar guṇām eva devatām bhajate iti tatra api sa guṇā eva
translated: And it has been explained by the Dramiḍa teacher who speaks of the option of knowledge: Even though one who is devoted to the Sāddhavidyā may not mentally pursue the multitude of qualities of the manifest deity,

original: devatā prāpyata iti /
analyzed: devatā prāpyate iti
translated: still he worships the deity with internal qualities. Even there, the deity with qualities is attained.

original: saccittaḥ sadvidyāniṣṭhaḥ /
translated: One who is devoted to the Sāddhavidyā is one whose mind is fixed on the Sāddhavidyā.

original: na nirbhugnadaivataṃ guṇagaṇaṃ manasānudhāvet apahatapāpmatvādikalyāṇaguṇagaṇaṃ daivatād vibhaktaṃ yady api daharavidyāniṣṭha iva saccito na
analyzed: na nirbhugna daivatam guṇa gaṇam manasā anudhāvet apahata pāpma tva ādi kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇam daivatāt vibhaktam yadi api dahara vidyā niṣṭhaḥ iva saccitaḥ na
translated: Even though one who is devoted to the Sāddhavidyā may not mentally pursue the multitude of qualities of the manifest deity, the multitude of auspicious qualities such as being free from sin, even though separate from the deity like one devoted to the small-shell knowledge,

original: smaret /
analyzed: smaret
translated: One should remember.

original: tathāpy antarguṇām eva devatāṃ bhajate devatāsvarūpānubandhitvāt sakalakalyāṇaguṇagaṇasya
analyzed: tathā api antar guṇām eva devatām bhajate devatā svarūpa anubandhi tvāt sakala kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇasya
translated: Even so, one worships the deity as having internal qualities, because all the multitude of auspicious qualities are connected with the form of the deity.

original: kenacid paradevatāsādhāraṇena nikhilajagatkāraṇatvādinā guṇenopāsyamānāpi devatā
analyzed: kenacid para devatā sādhāraṇena nikhila jagat kāraṇa tva ādinā guṇena upāsyamānā api devatā
translated: Even if the deity is worshipped with a quality common to other deities, such as being the cause of the entire world,

original: vastutaḥ svarūpānubandhi sarvakalyāṇaguṇagaṇaviśiṣṭaivopāsyate /
analyzed: vastutas svarūpa anubandhi sarva kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa viśiṣṭā eva upāsyate
translated: in reality, it is worshipped as endowed with all the multitude of auspicious qualities that are connected with its own form.

original: ataḥ saguṇam eva brahma tatrāpi prāpyam iti sadvidyādaharavidyayor vikalpa ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: atas sa guṇam eva brahma tatra api prāpyam iti sadvidyā daharavidyayoḥ vikalpaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, Brahman with qualities is what is to be attained there also. The meaning is that there is an option between the knowledge of the existent and the knowledge of the non-existent.

original: nanu ca sarvasya jantoḥ paramātmāntaryāmī tanniyāmyaṃ ca sarvam evety uktam /
analyzed: nanu ca sarvasya jantoḥ paramātmā antaryāmī tad niyāmyam ca sarvam eva iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the Supreme Self is the inner controller of all beings, and everything is to be controlled by It.

original: evaṃ ca sati vidhiniṣedhaśāstrāṇām adhikārī na dṛśyate /
analyzed: evam ca sati vidhi niṣedha śāstrāṇām adhikārī na dṛśyate
translated: And if this is so, no one is seen to be eligible for the injunctions and prohibitions.

original: yaḥ svabuddhyaiva pravṛttinivṛttiśaktaḥ sa evaṃ kuryān na kuryād iti vidhiniṣedhayogyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ sva buddhyā eva pravṛtti nivṛtti śaktaḥ saḥ evam kuryāt na kuryāt iti vidhi niṣedha yogyaḥ
translated: One who is capable of engaging in and abstaining from actions by his own intellect alone is fit for injunctions and prohibitions, such as he should do this or he should not do that.

original: na caiṣa dṛśyate /
analyzed: na ca eṣa dṛśyate
translated: But this is not seen.

original: sarvasmin pravṛttijāte sarvasya prerakaḥ paramātmā kārayiteti tasya sarvaniyamanaṃ pratipāditam /
analyzed: sarvasmin pravṛtti jāte sarvasya prerakaḥ paramātmā kārayitā iti tasya sarva niyamanam pratipāditam
translated: It has been explained that the Supreme Self is the instigator of all kinds of engagement and the employer of all, and therefore It controls everything.

original: tathā ca śrūyate eṣa eva sādhu karma kārayati te yam ebhyo lokebhya unninīṣati /
analyzed: tathā ca śrūyate eṣaḥ eva sādhu karma kārayati te yam ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ unninīṣati
translated: And it is heard thus: He makes one do good deeds whom he wishes to raise up from these worlds.

original: eṣa evāsādhu karma kārayati taṃ yam adho ninīṣatīti /
analyzed: eṣaḥ eva asādhu karma kārayati tam yam adhas ninīṣati iti
translated: He makes one do evil deeds whom he wishes to lead down.

original: sādhvasādhukarmakārayitṛtvān nairghṛṇyaṃ ca /
analyzed: sādhu asādhu karma kārayitṛ tvāt nairghṛṇyam ca
translated: And there is cruelty in making one do good and evil deeds.

original: atrocyate sarveṣām eva cetanānāṃ cicchaktiyogaḥ pravṛttiśaktiyoga ityādi sarvaṃ pravṛttinivṛttiparikaraṃ
analyzed: atrā ucyate sarveṣām eva cetanānām cit śakti yogaḥ pravṛtti śakti yogaḥ ityādi sarvam pravṛtti nivṛtti parikaram
translated: To this it is said: The connection of all conscious beings with the power of consciousness, the connection with the power of activity, etc. - all this equipment for activity and cessation,

original: sāmānyena saṃvidhāya tannirvahaṇāya tadādhāro bhūtvāntaḥ praviśyānumantṛtayā ca niyamanaṃ
analyzed: sāmānyena saṃvidhāya tad nirvahaṇāya tad ādhāraḥ bhūtvā antar praviśya anumantṛ tayā ca niyamanam
translated: having arranged in general, for the accomplishment of that, becoming the basis of that, entering within as the witness,🔽regulating by the nature of the witness,

original: kurvañ śeṣitvenāvasthitaḥ paramātmaitadāhitaśaktiḥ sanpravṛttinivṛttyādi svayam eva kurute /
