analyzed: śeṣi tvena avasthitaḥ paramātmā etad āhita śaktiḥ san pravṛtti nivṛtti ādi svayam eva kurute
translated: the supreme self, having placed this power, itself performs activity, cessation, etc.

original: evaṃ kurvāṇam īkṣamāṇaḥ paramātmodāsīna āste /
analyzed: evam kurvāṇam īkṣamāṇaḥ paramātmā udāsīnaḥ āste
translated: The supreme self, observing one acting thus, remains indifferent.

original: ataḥ sarvam upapannam /
analyzed: atas sarvam upapannam
translated: Therefore, everything is reasonable.

original: sādhvasādhukarmaṇoḥ kārayitṛtvaṃ tu vyavasthitaviṣayaṃ na sarvasādhāraṇam /
analyzed: sādhu asādhu karmaṇoḥ kārayitṛ tvam tu vyavasthita viṣayam na sarva sādhāraṇam
translated: But the agency in good and evil deeds has a limited scope, not common to all.

original: yas tu sarvaṃ svayam evātimātram ānukūlye pravṛttas taṃ prati prītaḥ svayam eva bhagavān kalyāṇabuddhiyogadānaṃ kurvan kalyāṇe pravartayati
analyzed: yaḥ tu sarvam svayam eva atimātram ānukūlye pravṛttaḥ tam prati prītaḥ svayam eva bhagavān kalyāṇa buddhi yoga dānam kurvan kalyāṇe pravartayati
translated: But he who is engaged in excessive favoritism all by himself, to him the Blessed One, being pleased, himself bestowing the gift of a wholesome mind, engages him in what is wholesome.

original: yaḥ punar atimātraṃ prātikūlye pravṛttas tasya krūrāṃ buddhiṃ dadan svayam eva krūreṣv eva karmasu prerayati bhagavān /
analyzed: yaḥ punar atimātram prātikūlye pravṛttaḥ tasya krūrām buddhim dadan svayam eva krūreṣu eva karmasu prerayati bhagavān
translated: But he who is engaged in excessive opposition, to him the Blessed One, bestowing a cruel mind, himself impels him to cruel actions alone.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā
translated: As it is said by the Blessed One:

original: teṣāṃ satatayuktānāṃ bhajatāṃ prītipūrvakam /
analyzed: teṣām satata yuktānām bhajatām prīti pūrvakam
translated: To those who are constantly devoted, who worship with love,

original: dadāmi buddhiyogaṃ taṃ yena mām upayānti te //🔽teṣām evānukampārtham aham ajñānajaṃ tamaḥ /
analyzed: dadāmi buddhi yogam tam yena mām upayānti te  teṣām eva anukampā artham aham ajñāna jam tamaḥ
translated: I give the yoga of wisdom by which they come to Me.🔽For the sake of compassion for them alone, I, dwelling in the body,

original: nāśayāmy ātmabhāvastho jñānadīpena bhāsvatā //
analyzed: nāśayāmi ātma bhāva sthaḥ jñāna dīpena bhāsvatā
translated: destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the shining lamp of knowledge.

original: tān ahaṃ dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu narādhamān /
analyzed: tān aham dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu nara adhamān
translated: Those who hate, are cruel, are the lowest of men in the cycles of existence,

original: kṣipāmy ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣv eva yoniṣu // iti /
analyzed: kṣipāmi ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣu eva yoniṣu iti
translated: I constantly cast the inauspicious ones into the wombs of demons alone.

original: so 'yaṃ parabrahmabhūtaḥ puruṣottamo niratiśayapuṇyasaṃcayakṣīṇāśeṣajanmopacitapāparāśeḥ
analyzed: saḥ yam para brahma bhūtaḥ puruṣottamaḥ niratiśaya puṇya saṃcaya kṣīṇa aśeṣa janma upacita pāpa rāśeḥ
translated: This Supreme Person, who is the highest Brahman, of him, whose heap of sins accumulated in births exhausted by the accumulation of unsurpassed merit,

original: paramapuruṣacaraṇāravindaśaraṇāgatijanitatadabhimukhyasya🔽sadācāryopadeśopabṛṃhitaśāstrādhigatatattvayāthātmyāvabodhapūrvakāharaharupacīyamānaśamadamatapaḥśaucakṣamārjavabhayābhayasthānavivekadayāhiṃsādyātmaguṇopetasya
analyzed: sat ācārya upadeśa upabṛṃhita śāstra adhigata tattva yāthātmya avabodha pūrvaka aharahar upacīyamāna śama dama tapaḥ śauca kṣamā ārjava bhaya abhaya sthāna viveka dayā hiṃsā ādi ātma guṇa upetasya
translated: For one who has taken refuge in the lotus feet of the Supreme Person and is thus inclined towards Him,🔽who possesses the qualities of tranquility, self-control, austerity, purity, patience, simplicity, fearlessness, discrimination between what is to be feared and what is not, compassion, non-violence, and so on, which increase day by day, preceded by the understanding of the true nature of reality obtained through the scriptures enriched by the instructions of a true teacher,

original: varṇāśramocitaparamapuruṣārādhanaveṣanityanaimittikakarmopasaṃhṛtiniṣiddhaparihāraniṣṭasya
analyzed: varṇa āśrama ucita parama puruṣa ārādhana veṣa nitya naimittika karma upasaṃhṛti niṣiddha parihāra niṣṭasya
translated: who is devoted to the worship of the Supreme Person through the duties prescribed for his caste and stage of life, who performs the obligatory and occasional duties, and who avoids what is prohibited,

original: paramapuruṣacaraṇāravindayugalanyastātmātmīyasya🔽tadbhaktikāritānavaratastutismṛtinamaskṛtivandanayatanakīrtanaguṇaśravaṇavacanadhyānārcanapraṇāmādiprītaparamakāruṇikapuruṣottamaprasādavidhvastasvāntadhvāntasyānanyaprayojanānavarataniratiśayapriyaviśadatamapratyakṣatāpannānudhyānarūpabhaktyekalabhyaḥ
analyzed: paramapuruṣa caraṇa aravinda yugala nyasta ātma ātmīyasya 🔽
translated: whose self and possessions are dedicated to the pair of lotus feet of the Supreme Person,🔽whose internal darkness is dispelled by the grace of the supremely compassionate Supreme Person, who is pleased by constant praise, remembrance, bowing down, worship, glorification, hearing of His qualities, speaking, meditation, worship, prostration, and so on,🔽who has attained the direct perception of the supremely blissful and pure Supreme Person, which is the only goal of life and is obtained through devotion alone, which is in the form of constant meditation.

original: tad uktaṃ paramagurubhir bhagavadyāmunācāryapādaiḥ ubhayaparikarmitasvāntasyaikāntikātyantikabhaktiyogalabhya iti /
analyzed: tat uktam parama gurubhiḥ bhagavat yāmuna ācārya pādaiḥ ubhaya parikarmita svāntasya aikāntika ātyantika bhakti yoga labhyaḥ iti
translated: That has been said by the great teacher, the venerable Yamuna, For one whose mind is purified by both, it is attained by the yoga of devotion that is exclusive and ultimate.

original: jñānayogakarmayogasaṃskṛtāntaḥkaraṇasyetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: jñāna yoga karma yoga saṃskṛta antaḥkaraṇasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: for one whose internal organ is refined by the yoga of knowledge and the yoga of action.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And so says the Śruti:

original: vidyāṃ cāvidyāṃ ca yas tad vedobhyaṃ saha /
analyzed: vidyām ca avidyām ca yaḥ tat vedobhyam saha
translated: He who knows both learning and ignorance,

original: avidyayā mṛtyuṃ tīrtvā vidyayāmṛtam aśnute //
analyzed: avidyayā mṛtyum tīrtvā vidyayā amṛtam aśnute
translated: having crossed death by ignorance, enjoys immortality by learning.

original: iti/ atrāvidyāśabdena vidyetaratvād varṇāśramācārādi pūrvoktaṃ karmocyate vidyāśabdena ca bhaktirūpāpannaṃ dhyānam ucyate / yathoktam
analyzed: iti atra avidyā śabdena vidyā itara tvāt varṇa āśrama ācāra ādi pūrva uktam karma ucyate vidyā śabdena ca bhakti rūpa āpannam dhyānam ucyate yathā uktam
translated: Here, by the word ignorance, the previously mentioned action such as the conduct of caste and stage of life, etc., which is the opposite of learning, is meant. And by the word learning, meditation that has become of the nature of devotion is meant. As it is said:

original: ijāya so 'pi subahūny ajñāñ jñānavyapāśrayaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ pi su bahūni ajñām jñāna vyapāśrayaḥ
translated: He, though performing many sacrifices, is ignorant, relying on knowledge,

original: brahmavidyām adhiṣṭhāya tartuṃ mṛtyum avidyayā //
analyzed: brahma vidyām adhiṣṭhāya tartum mṛtyum avidyayā
translated: in order to cross death by ignorance, based on the knowledge of Brahman.

original: iti / tam evaṃ vidvān amṛta iha bhavati nānyaḥ panthā ayanāya vidyate /
analyzed: iti tam evam vidvān amṛtaḥ iha bhavati na anyaḥ panthāḥ ayanāya vidyate
translated: One who knows thus becomes immortal in this world, there is no other path for going.

original: ya enaṃ vidur amṛtās te bhavanti /🔽brahmavid āpnoti param /
analyzed: ye enam viduḥ amṛtāḥ te bhavanti  brahma vid āpnoti param
translated: Those who know Him become immortal.🔽One who knows Brahman attains the highest.

original: so yo ha vai tat paraṃ veda brahma veda brahmaiva bhavatītyādi /
analyzed: saḥ yaḥ ha vai tat param veda brahma veda brahmā eva bhavati ityādi
translated: He who knows that highest Brahman, he becomes Brahman itself, and so on.

original: vedanaśabdena dhyānam evābhihitam /
analyzed: vedana śabdena dhyānam eva abhihitam
translated: By the word 'experience' meditation alone is indicated.

original: nididhyāsitavya ityādināikārthyāt /
analyzed: nididhyāsitavyaḥ ityādinā aikārthyāt
translated: Because of the meaning of 'should be meditated upon' etc.

original: tad eva dhyānaṃ punar api viśinaṣṭi nāyam ātmā pravacanena labhyo na medhayā na bahudhā śrutena /
analyzed: tat eva dhyānam punar api viśinaṣṭi na ayam ātmā pravacanena labhyaḥ na medhayā na bahudhā śrutena
translated: That same meditation is again specified: 'This Self is not to be attained by mere learning, nor by intelligence, nor by much hearing.

original: yam evaiṣa vṛṇute tena labhyas tasyaiṣa ātmā vivṛṇute tanūṃ svām iti /
analyzed: yam eva eṣa vṛṇute tena labhyaḥ tasya eṣaḥ ātmā vivṛṇute tanūm svām iti
translated: He is to be attained only by him whom He chooses. To him He reveals His own true nature.'

original: bhaktirūpāpannānudhyānenaiva labhyate na kevala / /
analyzed: bhakti rūpa āpanna anudhyānena eva labhyate na kevala
translated: It is attained only by meditation accompanied by devotion, not by mere

original: vedanāmātreṇa na medhayeti kevalasya niṣiddhatvāt /
analyzed: vedanā mātreṇa na medhayā iti kevalasya niṣiddha tvāt
translated: experience. Because mere [meditation] is prohibited by the word 'nor'.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati yo 'yaṃ mumukṣur vedāntavihitavedanarūpadhyānādiniṣṭho yadā tasya tasminn evānudhyāne niravadhikātiśayā prītir jāyate tadaiva
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati yaḥ yam mumukṣuḥ vedānta vihita vedana rūpa dhyāna ādi niṣṭhaḥ yadā tasya tasmin eva anudhyāne niravadhika atiśayā prītiḥ jāyate tadā eva
translated: This is what is meant: When this seeker of liberation, established in the experience-form of meditation enjoined by the Vedanta, when in that very meditation there arises an unlimited and extraordinary joy, then

original: tena labhyate paraḥ puruṣa iti /
analyzed: tena labhyate paraḥ puruṣaḥ iti
translated: he attains the Supreme Person.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā
translated: As it is said by the Lord:

original: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyas tv ananyayā /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyaḥ tu ananyayā
translated: 'That Supreme Person, O Partha, is to be attained by devotion that is exclusive.

original: bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakyo 'ham evaṃvidho 'rjuna /
analyzed: bhaktyā tu ananyayā śakyaḥ ham evaṃvidhaḥ rjuna
translated: But by devotion that is exclusive, O Arjuna, I, who am such,

original: jñātuṃ draṣṭuṃ ca tattvena praveṣṭaṃ ca paraṃtapa //
analyzed: jñātum draṣṭum ca tattvena praveṣṭam ca paraṃtapa
translated: can be known, seen truly, and entered into, O scorcher of enemies.'

original: bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ /🔽tato māṃ tattvato jñātvā viśate tadanantaram //
analyzed: bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaḥ ca asmi tattvataḥ  tatas mām tattvataḥ jñātvā viśate tad anantaram
translated: He who knows Me in truth, as far as I extend and what I am,🔽through devotion, then, after knowing Me in truth, he enters into Me.

original: iti / tadanantaraṃ tata eva bhaktito viśata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti tad anantaram tatas eva bhaktitaḥ viśataḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that after that, he enters into Me through that very devotion.

original: bhaktir api niratiśayapriyānanyaprayojanasakaletaravaitṛṇyāvahajñānaviśeṣa eveti /
analyzed: bhaktiḥ api niratiśaya priya ananya prayojana sakala itara vaitṛṇya āvaha jñāna viśeṣaḥ eva iti
translated: And devotion is also a special knowledge that brings about complete detachment from all other things, which is extremely dear and has no other purpose.

original: tad yukta eva tena pareṇātmanā varaṇīyo bhavatīti tena labhyata iti śrutyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat yuktaḥ eva tena pareṇa ātmanā varaṇīyaḥ bhavati iti tena labhyate iti śruti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the scripture is that he becomes fit to be chosen by that supreme Self, and so he is attained by that.

original: evaṃvidhaparabhaktirūpajñānaviśeṣasyotpādakaḥ pūrvoktāharaharupacīyamānajñānapūrvakakarmānugṛhītabhaktiyoga eva /
analyzed: evaṃvidha para bhakti rūpa jñāna viśeṣasya utpādakaḥ pūrva ukta aharahar upacīyamāna jñāna pūrvaka karma anugṛhīta bhaktiyogaḥ eva
translated: The means of producing that special knowledge in the form of supreme devotion is the yoga of devotion, which is aided by the previously mentioned karma that is preceded by the knowledge that increases every day.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā parāśareṇa🔽varṇāśramācāravatā puruṣeṇa paraḥ pumān /
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā parāśareṇa  varṇa āśrama ācāravatā puruṣeṇa paraḥ pumān
translated: As it has been said by the revered Parashara:

original: viṣṇur ārādhyate panthā nānyas tattoṣakārakaḥ //
analyzed: viṣṇuḥ ārādhyate panthāḥ na anyaḥ tad toṣa kārakaḥ
translated: By a man who follows the duties of his caste and stage of life, the supreme Person, Vishnu, is worshipped. There is no other path that brings about His satisfaction.

original: iti / nikhilajagaduddhāraṇāyāvanitale 'vatīrṇaḥ parabrahmabhūtaḥ puruṣottamaḥ svayam evaitaduktavān
analyzed: iti nikhila jagat uddhāraṇāya avani tale vatīrṇaḥ para brahma bhūtaḥ puruṣottamaḥ svayam eva etat uktavān
translated: Thus, the Supreme Brahman, the best of beings, who descended to the earth for the sake of uplifting the entire world, has Himself said this:

original: svakarmanirataḥ siddhiṃ yathā vindati tacchṛṇu //
analyzed: sva karma nirataḥ siddhim yathā vindati tat śṛṇu
translated: Listen to how one who is engaged in one's own duty attains perfection.

original: yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānāṃ yena sarvam idaṃ tatam /
analyzed: yatas pravṛttiḥ bhūtānām yena sarvam idam tatam
translated: From which there is the origin of beings, by which all this is pervaded,

original: svakarmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhiṃ vindati mānavaḥ //
analyzed: sva karmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhim vindati mānavaḥ
translated: having worshipped him with one's own duty, a man attains perfection.

original: iti / yathoditakramapariṇatabhaktyekalabhya eva / 🔽bodhāyanaṭaṅkadramiḍaguhadevakapardibhāruciprabhṛtyavigītaśiṣṭaparigṛhītapurātanavedavedāntavyākhyānasuvyaktārthaśrutinikaranidarśito 'yaṃ
analyzed: iti yathā udita krama pariṇata bhakti eka labhyaḥ eva  bodhāyana ṭaṅka dramiḍa guha deva kapardi bhāruci prabhṛti avigīta śiṣṭa parigṛhīta purātana veda vedānta vyākhyāna su vyakta artha śruti nikara nidarśitaḥ yam
translated: Thus, he is to be attained only through devotion that has reached perfection in the sequence as stated.🔽This [Brahman] is indicated by a multitude of Vedic passages whose meaning is clearly stated, such as the ancient explanations of the Vedas and Vedanta accepted by the unopposed learned, beginning with Bodhāyana, Aṅgiras, Dāmiḍa, Guha, Deva, Kapardi, Bhāruci, etc.

original: anena cārvākaśākyāulūkyākṣapādakṣapaṇakakapilapatañjalimatānusāriṇo vedabāhyā vedāvalambikudṛṣṭibhiḥ saha nirastāḥ /
analyzed: anena cārvāka śākya āulūkya akṣapāda kṣapaṇaka kapila patañjali mata anusāriṇaḥ veda bāhyāḥ veda avalambi kudṛṣṭibhiḥ saha nirastāḥ
translated: And by this [Brahman], the followers of the Cārvāka, Śākya, Ūluka, Akṣapāda, Kṣapaṇaka, Kapila, and Patañjali, who are outside the Vedas, along with those who hold false views that rely on the Vedas, are refuted.

original: vedāvalambinām api yathāvasthitavastuviparyayas tāḍṛśāṃ bāhyasāmyaṃ manunaivoktam
analyzed: veda avalambinām api yathā avasthita vastu viparyayaḥ tāḍṛśām bāhya sāmyam manunā evā uktam
translated: Even those who rely on the Vedas, whose false views contradict the true nature of things, are similar to outsiders, as Manu himself has said:

original: yo vedabāhyāḥ smṛtayo yāś ca kāś ca kudṛṣṭayaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ veda bāhyāḥ smṛtayaḥ yāḥ ca kāḥ ca kudṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: Those Smṛtis and all the false views that are outside the Veda,

original: sarvas tā niṣphalāḥ pretya tamoniṣṭhā hi tāḥ smṛtāḥ //
analyzed: sarvaḥ tāḥ niṣphalāḥ pretya tamaḥ niṣṭhāḥ hi tāḥ smṛtāḥ
translated: all of them are fruitless after death, for they are declared to be in the darkness [of ignorance].

original: iti / rajastamobhyām aspṛṣṭam uttamaṃ sattvam eva yeṣāṃ svābhāviko guṇas teṣām eva vaidikī rucir vedārthayāthātmyāvabodhaś cetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti rajaḥ tamobhyām a spṛṣṭam uttamam sattvam eva yeṣām svābhāvikaḥ guṇaḥ teṣām eva vaidikī ruciḥ veda artha yāthātmya avabodhaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: That is, those whose natural quality is the highest sattva untouched by rajas and tamas, for them alone there is Vedic interest and understanding of the truth of the meaning of the Vedas.

original: yathoktaṃ mātsye
analyzed: yathā uktam mātsye
translated: As it is said in the Matsya Purana:

original: saṃkīrṇāḥ sāttvikāś caiva rājasās tāmasās tathā /
analyzed: saṃkīrṇāḥ sāttvikāḥ ca eva rājasāḥ tāmasāḥ tathā
translated: Mixed, of sattva, of rajas, and of tamas.

original: iti / kecid brahmakalpāḥ saṃkīrṇāḥ kecit sattvaprāyāḥ kecid rajaḥprāyā kecit tamaḥprāyā
analyzed: iti kecid brahma kalpāḥ saṃkīrṇāḥ kecid sattva prāyāḥ kecid rajaḥ prāyā kecid tamaḥ prāyā
translated: Some are like Brahma, mixed, some are mostly sattva, some are mostly rajas, some are mostly tamas.

original: iti kalpavibhāgam uktvā sattvarajastamomayānāṃ tattvānāṃ māhātmyavarṇanaṃ ca tattatkalpaproktapurāṇeṣu
analyzed: iti kalpa vibhāgam uktvā sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ mayānām tattvānām māhātmya varṇanam ca tad tad kalpa prokta purāṇeṣu
translated: Having stated the division of kalpas in this way, the greatness of the principles consisting of sattva, rajas, and tamas is described in the Puranas spoken in those kalpas.

original: sattvādiguṇamayena brahmaṇā kriyata iti coktam
analyzed: sattva ādi guṇa mayena brahmaṇā kriyate iti ca uktam
translated: And it is said that it is created by Brahma consisting of the qualities of sattva and so on.

original: yasmin kalpe tu yat proktaṃ purāṇaṃ brahmaṇā purā /
analyzed: yasmin kalpe tu yat proktam purāṇam brahmaṇā purā
translated: In whatever kalpa the Purana was spoken by Brahma in the past,

original: tasya tasya tu māhātmyaṃ tatsvarūpeṇa varṇyate //
analyzed: tasya tasya tu māhātmyam tad svarūpeṇa varṇyate
translated: The greatness of that is described in its own form.

original: iti / viśeṣataś coktam
analyzed: iti viśeṣataḥ ca uktam
translated: And in particular it is said:

original: agneḥ śivasya māhātmyaṃ tāmaseṣu prakīrtyate /
analyzed: agneḥ śivasya māhātmyam tāmaseṣu prakīrtyate
translated: The greatness of Agni and Shiva is proclaimed in the tamasic ones,

original: rājaseṣu ca māhātmyam adhikaṃ brahmaṇo viduḥ //
analyzed: rājaseṣu ca māhātmyam adhikam brahmaṇaḥ viduḥ
translated: And in the rajasic ones, the greatness of Brahma is known to be greater.

original: sāttvikeṣu ca kalpeṣu māhātmyam adhikaṃ hareḥ /
analyzed: sāttvikeṣu ca kalpeṣu māhātmyam adhikam hareḥ
translated: And in the Satvika kalpas, the greatness of Hari is more.

original: teṣv eva yogasaṃsiddhā gamiṣyanti parāṃ gatim //
analyzed: teṣu eva yoga saṃsiddhāḥ gamiṣyanti parām gatim
translated: In those very ones, the Yogins will attain the highest goal.

original: saṃkīrṇeṣu sarasvatyāḥ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / //
analyzed: saṃkīrṇeṣu sarasvatyāḥ
translated: In the mixed ones, of Sarasvatī...

original: ityādi / etaduktaṃ bhavati ādikṣetrajñatvād brahmaṇas tasyāpi keṣucid ahassu sattvamudrikaṃ keṣucid rajaḥ keṣucit tamaḥ /
analyzed: ityādi etat uktam bhavati ādi kṣetrajña tvāt brahmaṇaḥ tasya api keṣucid ahassu sattva mudrikam keṣucid rajaḥ keṣucid tamaḥ
translated: This is what is said: Because of being the first individual soul, even for that Brahman, in some days sattva predominates, in some rajas, in some tamas.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā
translated: As it is said by the Lord:

original: na tad asti pṛthivyāṃ vā divi deveṣu vā punaḥ /
analyzed: na tat asti pṛthivyām vā divi deveṣu vā punar
translated: There is nothing on earth or in heaven or among the gods,

original: sattvaṃ prakṛtijair muktaṃ yad ebhiḥ syāt tribhir guṇaiḥ //
analyzed: sattvam prakṛti jaiḥ muktam yat ebhiḥ syāt tribhiḥ guṇaiḥ
translated: which is free from the three qualities born of nature.

original: iti / yo brahmaṇaṃ vidadhati pūrvaṃ yo vai vedāṃś ca prahiṇoti tasmā iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: iti yaḥ vidadhati pūrvam yaḥ vai vedān ca prahiṇoti tasmai iti śruteḥ
translated: Thus, because of the Vedic text: He who first ordains Brahman, and from whom the Vedas are transmitted to him,

original: brahmaṇo 'pi sṛjyatvena śāstravaśyatvena ca kṣetrajñatvaṃ gamyate /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ u pi sṛjya tvena śāstra vaśya tvena ca kṣetrajña tvam gamyate
translated: it is understood that even Brahman is an individual soul because of being created and being subject to the scriptures.

original: sattvaprāyeṣv ahassu taditareṣu yāni purāṇāni brahmaṇā proktāni teṣāṃ parasparavirodhe
analyzed: sattva prāyeṣu ahassu tad itareṣu yāni purāṇāni brahmaṇā proktāni teṣām paraspara virodhe
translated: In the days predominated by sattva, in the others, the Puranas that were spoken by Brahman, in their mutual contradictions,

original: sati sāttvikāhaḥproktam eva purāṇaṃ yathārthaṃ tadvirodhyanyad ayathārtham iti purāṇanirṇayāyaivedaṃ
analyzed: sati sāttvika ahar proktam eva purāṇam yathārtham tad virodhi anyat ayathārtham iti purāṇa nirṇayāya eva idam
translated: When there is a day of Sattva, the Purana that was previously stated is true, and what contradicts that is false. This is only for the determination of the Puranas.

original: sattvaniṣṭhena brahmaṇābhihitam iti vijñāyata iti /
analyzed: sattva niṣṭhena brahmaṇā abhihitam iti vijñāyate iti
translated: When there is existence, the Purana spoken of as Sattvika is true to its meaning, and what contradicts that is false. This is understood to be stated by Brahma himself, who is devoted to Sattva, for the very purpose of determining the Puranas.

original: sattvādīnāṃ kāryaṃ ca bhagavataivoktam🔽sattvāt saṃjāyate jñānaṃ rajaso lobha eva ca /
analyzed: sattva ādīnām kāryam ca bhagavatā evā uktam  sattvāt saṃjāyate jñānam rajasaḥ lobhaḥ eva ca
translated: The effect of Sattva and others has also been stated by the Lord himself:🔽From Sattva arises knowledge, and from Rajas, greed alone.

original: pramādamohau tamaso bhavato 'jñānam eva ca //
analyzed: pramāda mohau tamasaḥ bhavataḥ jñānam eva ca
translated: From Tamas arise error, delusion, and ignorance itself.

original: pravṛttiṃ ca nivṛttiṃ ca kāryākārye bhayābhaye /
analyzed: pravṛttim ca nivṛttim ca kārya akārye bhaya abhaye
translated: That intellect which knows activity and inactivity, what should be done and what should not be done, fear and fearlessness,

original: bandhaṃ mokṣaṃ ca yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī //
analyzed: bandham mokṣam ca yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
translated: bondage and liberation, O son of Prtha, is of the quality of Sattva.

original: yathā dharmam adharmaṃ ca kāryaṃ cākāryam eva ca /
analyzed: yathā dharmam adharmam ca kāryam ca akāryam eva ca
translated: As that intellect which knows Dharma and Adharma, what should be done and what should not be done,

original: ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī //
analyzed: ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
translated: not as they are, O son of Prtha, is of the quality of Rajas.

original: adharmaṃ dharmam iti yā manyate tamasāvṛtā /
analyzed: adharmam dharmam iti yā manyate tamasā āvṛtā
translated: That intellect which, enveloped in darkness, considers Adharma as Dharma,

original: sarvārthān viparītāṃś ca buddhiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī //
analyzed: sarva arthān viparītān ca buddhiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī
translated: and all objects in a contrary way, O son of Prtha, is of the quality of Tamas.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: sarvān purāṇārthān brahmaṇaḥ sakāśād adhigamyaiva sarvāṇi purāṇāni purāṇakārāś cakruḥ / yathoktam
analyzed: sarvān purāṇa arthān brahmaṇaḥ sakāśāt adhigamya eva sarvāṇi purāṇāni purāṇa kārāḥ cakruḥ yathā uktam
translated: Having learned all the meanings of the Puranas from Brahma himself, the authors of the Puranas composed all the Puranas. As stated:

original: kathayāmi yathā pūrvaṃ dakṣādyair munisattamaiḥ /
analyzed: kathayāmi yathā pūrvam dakṣa ādyaiḥ muni sattamaiḥ
translated: I shall narrate as formerly the lotus-born grandfather Brahma, when asked by Daksha and other best of sages,

original: pṛṣṭaḥ provāca bhagavān abjayoniḥ pitāmahaḥ //
analyzed: pṛṣṭaḥ provāca bhagavān abjayoniḥ pitāmahaḥ
translated: recited.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: apauruṣeyeṣu vedavākyeṣu parasparaviruddheṣu katham iti cet /
analyzed: apauruṣeyeṣu veda vākyeṣu paraspara viruddheṣu katham iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there is no contradiction in the Vedic statements that are not of human origin and are mutually contradictory,

original: tātparyaniścayād avirodhaḥ pūrvam evoktaḥ /
analyzed: tātparya niścayāt avirodhaḥ pūrvam eva uktaḥ
translated: it has been said earlier that there is no contradiction due to the ascertainment of the intended meaning.

original: yad api ced evaṃ viruddhavad dṛśyate prāṇaṃ manasi saha kāraṇair nādānte paramātmani saṃpratiṣṭhāya dhyāyītavyaṃ pradhyāyītavyaṃ sarvam idaṃ /
analyzed: yat api ced evam viruddha vat dṛśyate prāṇam manasi saha kāraṇaiḥ na adānte paramātmani saṃpratiṣṭhāya dhyāyītavyam pradhyāyītavyam sarvam idam
translated: And even if it appears as if contradictory in this way, one should meditate on the prāṇa, the mind, along with the causes, being established in the supreme self at the end of the nada, that everything should be meditated upon and contemplated.

original: brahmaviṣṇurudrās te sarve saṃprasūyante /
analyzed: brahma viṣṇu rudrāḥ te sarve saṃprasūyante
translated: All of them, Brahmā, Viṣṇu, Rudra, are born from that.

original: na kāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: na kāraṇam
translated: It is not the cause.

original: kāraṇaṃ tu dhyāyaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇam tu dhyāyaḥ
translated: But the cause is the meditation.

original: sarvāiśvaryasaṃpannaḥ sarveśvaraḥ śaṃbhur ākāśamadhye dhyeyaḥ yasmāt paraṃ nāparam
analyzed: sarva aiśvarya saṃpannaḥ sarva īśvaraḥ śaṃbhuḥ ākāśa madhye dhyeyaḥ yasmāt param na aparam
translated: The all-powerful lord Śambhu, endowed with all opulence, should be meditated upon in the middle of space, from whom there is nothing higher,

original: asti kiṃcid yasmān nāṇīyo na jyāyo 'sti kaścit vṛkṣa iva stabdho divi tiṣṭhaty ekas
analyzed: asti kiṃcid yasmāt na aṇīyaḥ na jyāyaḥ sti kaścid vṛkṣaḥ iva stabdhaḥ divi tiṣṭhati ekaḥ
translated: from whom there is nothing smaller or greater, who stands alone in heaven like a firm tree.

original: tenedaṃ pūrṇaṃ puruṣeṇa sarvam tato yaduttarataraṃ tadarūpam anāmayaṃ ya etadvidur amṛtās te bhavanti /
analyzed: tena idam pūrṇam puruṣeṇa sarvam tatas yat uttarataram tat arūpam anāmayam ye etat viduḥ amṛtāḥ te bhavanti
translated: This entire universe is filled with that Puruṣa. What is beyond that is formless and free from disease. Those who know this become immortal.

original: athetare duḥkham evāpiyanti
analyzed: atha itare duḥkham eva apiyanti
translated: But others attain only misery.

original: sarvānanaśirogrīvaḥ sarvabhūtaguhāśayaḥ /
translated: He who has faces, heads, and necks everywhere, who is the abode of all beings,

original: sarvavyāpī ca bhagavāṃs tasmāt sarvagataḥ śivaḥ //
analyzed: sarvavyāpī ca bhagavān tasmāt sarva gataḥ śivaḥ
translated: and who is all-pervading, that Blessed One is therefore all-pervading and auspicious.

original: yadā tamas tan na divā na rātrir na san na cāsac chiva eva kevalaḥ /
analyzed: yadā tamaḥ tat na divā na rātriḥ na sat na ca asat śivaḥ eva kevalaḥ
translated: When there is only darkness, not day or night, not being or non-being, only auspiciousness,

original: tadakṣaraṃ tatsavitur vareṇyaṃ prajñā ca tasmāt prasṛtā purāṇī //
analyzed: tat akṣaram tat savituḥ vareṇyam prajñā ca tasmāt prasṛtā purāṇī
translated: that is the imperishable, that is the most excellent Savita, and from that has flowed forth the ancient wisdom.

original: ityādi nārāyaṇaḥ paraṃ brahmeti ca pūrvam eva pratipāditaṃ /
analyzed: ityādi nārāyaṇaḥ param brahma iti ca pūrvam eva pratipāditam
translated: Thus it has been taught earlier that Narayana is the supreme Brahman.

original: tenāsya katham avirodhaḥ /
analyzed: tena asya katham avirodhaḥ
translated: How then is there no contradiction with this?

original: atyalpam etat🔽vedavitpravaraproktavākyanyāyopabṛṃhitāḥ /
analyzed: ati alpam etat
translated: This is very little.🔽The Vedas, along with the statements and reasoning of the foremost knowers of the Vedas,

original: vedāḥ sāṅgā hariṃ prāhur jagajjanmādikāraṇaṃ //
analyzed: vedāḥ sāṅgāḥ harim prāhuḥ jagat janma ādi kāraṇam
translated: declare Hari to be the cause of the creation etc. of the world.

original: janmādyasya yataḥ yato vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante /
analyzed: janma ādyasya yatas yatas vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante
translated: From which is the origin of this, from which indeed are these beings born.

original: yena jātāni jīvanti /
analyzed: yena jātāni jīvanti
translated: By which, when born, they live.

original: yat prayanty abhisaṃviśanti /
analyzed: yat prayanti abhisaṃviśanti
translated: Into which, when departing, they enter.

original: tad vijijñānasva tad brahmeti jagajjanmādikāraṇaṃ brahmety avagamyate /
analyzed: tat vijijñānasva tat brahma iti jagat janma ādikāraṇam brahma iti avagamyate
translated: That should be known, that is Brahman. Thus it is understood that Brahman is the cause of the creation etc. of the world.

original: tac ca jagatsṛṣṭipralayaprakaraṇeṣv avagantavyam /
analyzed: tat ca jagat sṛṣṭi pralaya prakaraṇeṣu avagantavyam
translated: And that should be understood in the sections on the creation and dissolution of the world.

original: sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam iti jagadupādānatājagannimittatājagadantaryāmitādimukhena paramakāraṇaṃ sacchabdena praitpāditaṃ
analyzed: sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam iti jagat upādāna tā jagat nimitta tā jagat antaryāmi tā ādi mukhena parama kāraṇam sat śabdena prait pāditam
translated: It is declared in the Upanishad: This world, my dear, existed in the beginning as Being, one only, without a second (Ch. Up. VI. 2. 1), by means of the terms Being, cause of the world, pervading the world, etc., that Brahman is the highest cause.

original: brahmety avagatam /
analyzed: brahma iti avagatam
translated: It is understood that Brahman is denoted by the word Being.

original: ayam evārthaḥ brahma vā idam ekam evāgra āsīd iti śākhāntare brahmaśabdena pratipaditaḥ /🔽anena sacchabdenābhihitaṃ brahmety avagatam /
analyzed: ayam eva arthaḥ brahma vai idam ekam eva agre āsīt iti śākhā antare brahma śabdena pratipaditaḥ  anena sat śabdena abhihitam brahma iti avagatam
translated: This very meaning is stated in another branch of the Veda by the word Brahman: This world existed as Brahman, one only in the beginning (Ch. Up. VII. 25. 2).🔽It is understood that the Brahman mentioned by the word Being is the same as Brahman.

original: ayam evārthas tathā śākhāntara ātmā vā idam eka evāgra āsīn nānyat kiṃcana miṣad iti sadbrahmaśabdābhyām ātmaivābhihita ity avagamyate /🔽tathā ca śākhāntara eko ha vai nārāyaṇa āsīn na brahma neśāno neme dyāvapṛthivī na nakṣatrāṇīti sadbrahmātmādiparamakāraṇavādibhiḥ śabdair
analyzed: ayam eva arthaḥ tathā śākhā antare ātmā vai idam ekaḥ eva agre āsīt na anyat kiṃcana miṣat iti sat brahma śabdābhyām ātmā eva abhihitaḥ iti avagamyate  tathā ca śākhā antare ekaḥ ha vai nārāyaṇaḥ āsīt na brahma na īśānaḥ na ime dyāva pṛthivī na nakṣatrāṇi iti sat brahma ātma ādi parama kāraṇa vādibhiḥ śabdaiḥ
translated: This very meaning is understood in another branch of the Veda by the words Being and Brahman: This world existed as the Self, one only in the beginning, there was nothing else moving (Ch. Up. VII. 23. 1). It is understood that the Self alone is denoted by the words Being and Brahman.

original: nārāyaṇa evābhidhīyata iti niścīyate /
analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ eva abhidhīyate iti niścīyate
translated: And in another branch of the Veda, it is thus: Narayana alone existed in the beginning, not Brahman, not Ishana, not these heaven and earth, not the stars (Ch. Up. VII. 24. 1). It is ascertained that Narayana alone is spoken of by the words denoting the highest cause such as Being, Brahman, Atman, etc.

original: yam antaḥ samudre kavayo vayantītyādi nainam ūrdhvaṃ na tiryañcaṃ na madhye parijagrabhat /
analyzed: yam antar samudre kavayaḥ vayanti ityādi na enam ūrdhvam na tiryañcam na madhye parijagrabhat
translated: It is said: The wise meditate on Him within the ocean (Ch. Up. VII. 25. 2), etc. He is not grasped above, not across, not in the middle.

original: na tasyeśe kaścana tasya nāma mahadyaśaḥ //
analyzed: na tasya īśe kaścana tasya nāma mahat yaśaḥ
translated: No one has power over him. His name is Great Glory.

original: na saṃdṛśe tiṣṭhati rūpam asya na cakṣuṣā paśyati kaścanainam /
analyzed: na saṃdṛśe tiṣṭhati rūpam asya na cakṣuṣā paśyati kaścana enam
translated: His form is not seen, it does not stand. No one sees him with the eye.

original: hṛdā manīṣā manasābhikḷpto ya evaṃ vidur amṛtās te bhavantīti sarvasmāt paratvam asya pratipādya /
analyzed: hṛdā manīṣā manasā abhikḷptaḥ ye evam viduḥ amṛtāḥ te bhavanti iti sarvasmāt para tvam asya pratipādya
translated: The thought in the heart, formed by the mind, - those who know him thus, they become immortal. Having taught his supremacy over everything,

original: na tasyeśe kaścaneti tasmāt paraṃ kim api na vidyata iti ca pratiṣidhya /
analyzed: na tasya īśe kaścana iti tasmāt param kim api na vidyate iti ca pratiṣidhya
translated: saying No one has power over him, he denies that there is anything superior to him.

original: adbhyaḥ sambhūto hiraṇyagarbha ityaṣṭāv iti tenaikavākyatāṃ gamayati /
analyzed: adbhyaḥ sambhūtaḥ hiraṇya garbhaḥ iti aṣṭau iti tena ekavākyatām gamayati
translated: Hiranyagarbha arose from the waters - these are the eight. He connects them into one sentence.

original: tac ca mahāpuruṣaprakaraṇaṃ hrīś ca te lakṣmīś ca patnyāv iti ca nārāyaṇa eveti dyotayati /
analyzed: tat ca mahāpuruṣa prakaraṇam hrīḥ ca te lakṣmīḥ ca patnyau iti ca nārāyaṇaḥ eva iti dyotayati  /
translated: And that section on the Great Person, and Hri and Lakshmi are his wives - this indicates that he is Narayana alone.

original: ayam artho nārāyaṇānuvāke prapañcitaḥ /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ nārāyaṇa anuvāke prapañcitaḥ
translated: This meaning is elaborated in the Narayana hymn.

original: sahasraśīrṣaṃ devam ityārabhya sa brahma sa śivaḥ sendraḥ so 'kṣaraḥ paramaḥ svarāḍ iti /
analyzed: sahasra śīrṣam devam iti ārabhya sa brahma sa śivaḥ sa indraḥ saḥ u kṣaraḥ paramaḥ svarāj iti
translated: Beginning with The thousand-headed god..., ending with He is Brahman, he is Shiva, he is Indra, he is the imperishable, the supreme, the self-existent.

original: sarvaśākhāsu paratattvapratipādanaparān akṣaraśivaśaṃbhuparabrahmaparajyotiḥparatattvaparāyaṇaparamātmādisarvaśabdāṃs
analyzed: sarva śākhāsu para tattva pratipādana parān akṣara śiva śaṃbhu para brahma para jyotiḥ para tattva parāyaṇa paramātma ādi sarva śabdān
translated: In all the branches, the words imperishable, Shiva, Shambhu, supreme Brahman, supreme light, supreme truth, supreme self and all such words are devoted to teaching the supreme truth.

original: tattadguṇayogena nārāyaṇa eva prayujya tadvyatiriktasya samastasya tadādhāratāṃ tanniyāmyatāṃ
analyzed: tad tad guṇa yogena nārāyaṇe eva prayujya tad vyatiriktasya samastasya tad ādhāra tām tad niyāmya tām
translated: By the connection with those qualities, Nārāyaṇa alone is employed. After establishing that everything else apart from that is the support of that, is governed by that,

original: taccheṣatām tadātmakatāṃ ca pratipādya brahmaśivayor apīndrādisamānākāratayā tadvibhūtitvaṃ ca pratipāditam /
analyzed: tad śeṣa tām tad ātmaka tām ca pratipādya brahma śivayoḥ api indra ādi samāna ākāra tayā tad vibhūti tvam ca pratipāditam
translated: is subordinate to that, and is of the nature of that, it is also shown that even Brahmā and Śiva are the manifestations of that, having the same form as Indra and others.

original: idaṃ ca vākyaṃ kevalaparatattvapratipādanaikaparam anyat kiṃcid apy atra na vidhīyate /
analyzed: idam ca vākyam kevala para tattva pratipādana eka param anyat kiṃcid api atra na vidhīyate
translated: And this statement is solely devoted to the exposition of the supreme truth; nothing else is enjoined here.

original: asmin vākye pratipāditasya sarvasmāt paratvenāvasthitasya brahmaṇo vākyāntareṣu brahmavid āpnoti param ityādiṣūpāsanādi vidhīyate /
analyzed: asmin vākye pratipāditasya sarvasmāt para tvena avasthitasya brahmaṇaḥ vākya antareṣu brahma vid āpnoti param ityādiṣu upāsana ādi vidhīyate
translated: In this statement, when Brahman, which exists as superior to everything, is expounded, meditation etc. are enjoined in other statements such as The knower of Brahman attains the supreme.

original: ataḥ prāṇaṃ manasi saha karaṇair ityādi vākyaṃ sarvakāraṇe paramātmani karaṇaprāṇādi
analyzed: atas prāṇam manasi saha karaṇaiḥ ityādi vākyam sarva kāraṇe paramātmani karaṇa prāṇa ādi
translated: Therefore, the statement beginning with The vital air along with the mind and the organs etc. withdraws all the created beings such as the organs, vital airs etc. into the supreme Self, which is the cause of all,🔽and enjoins the meditation on that supreme Self alone as the Lord of all.

original: sarvaṃ vikārajātam upasaṃhṛtya tam eva paramātmānaṃ sarvasyeśānaṃ dhyāyīteti parabrahmabhūtanārāyaṇasyaiva dhyānaṃ vidadhāti /
analyzed: sarvam vikāra jātam upasaṃhṛtya tam eva paramātmānam sarvasya īśānam dhyāyīta iti para brahma bhūta nārāyaṇasya eva dhyānam vidadhāti
translated: Thus, it enjoins the meditation on Nārāyaṇa alone, who is the supreme Brahman.

original: patiṃ viśvasyeti na tasyeśe kaścaneti ca tasyaiva sarvasyeśānatā pratipāditā /
analyzed: patim viśvasya iti na tasya īśe kaścana iti ca tasya eva sarvasya īśāna tā pratipāditā
translated: The passage the lord of the universe and none is his lord sets forth the lordship of that (Narayana) over all.

original: ata eva sarvāiśvaryasaṃpannaḥ sarveśvaraḥ śaṃbhurākāśamadhye dhyeya iti nārāyaṇasyaiva paramakāraṇasya śaṃbhuśabdavācyasya dhyānaṃ vidhīyate
analyzed: atas eva sarva aiśvarya saṃpannaḥ sarva īśvaraḥ śaṃbhuḥ ākāśa madhye dhyeyaḥ iti nārāyaṇasya eva parama kāraṇasya śaṃbhu śabda vācyasya dhyānam vidhīyate
translated: For this very reason, the meditation on Narayana alone, the supreme cause, denoted by the word Shambhu, is enjoined, as He is endowed with all lordship and is the lord of all, and is to be meditated upon in the middle of space.

original: kaś ca dhyeya ityārabhya kāraṇaṃ tu dhyeya iti kāryasyādhyeyatāpūrvakakāraṇaikadhyeyatāparatvād vākyasya /
analyzed: kaḥ ca dhyeyaḥ iti ārabhya kāraṇam tu dhyeyaḥ iti kāryasya adhyeya tā pūrvaka kāraṇa eka dhyeya tā paratvāt vākyasya
translated: And the sentence, beginning with What is to be meditated upon?, ends with the cause alone is to be meditated upon, indicating that the effect is to be meditated upon first, and then the cause alone is to be meditated upon.

original: tasyaiva nārāyaṇasya paramakāraṇatā śaṃbhuśabdavācyatā ca paramakāraṇapratipādanaikapare🔽nārāyaṇānuvāka eva pratipanneti tadvirodhyarthāntaraparikalpanaṃ kāraṇasyaiva dhyeyatvena
analyzed: tasya eva nārāyaṇasya parama kāraṇa tā śaṃbhu śabda vācya tā ca parama kāraṇa pratipādanā eka pare  nārāyaṇa anuvāke eva pratipannā iti tad virodhi artha antara parikalpanam kāraṇasya eva dhyeya tvena
translated: The statement that Narayana alone is the supreme cause and is denoted by the word Shambhu is for the sole purpose of establishing the supreme cause.

original: vidhivākye na yujyate /
analyzed: vidhi vākye na yujyate
translated: When the Narayana section itself is accepted, it is not proper in the injunctive sentence to imagine a different meaning contrary to it, by making the cause alone to be meditated upon.

original: yad api tato yaduttaram ity atra puruṣād anyasya parataratvaṃ pratīyata ityabhyadhāyi
analyzed: yat api tatas yat uttaram iti atra puruṣāt anyasya paratara tvam pratīyate iti abhyadhāyi
translated: And what was said that in the passage what is beyond that?, the existence of something superior to the Purusha is understood,

original: tad api yasmāt paraṃ nāparam asti kiṃcid yasmān nāṇīyo na jyāyo 'sti kaścit yasmād
analyzed: tat api yasmāt param na aparam asti kiṃcid yasmāt na aṇīyaḥ na jyāyaḥ sti kaścid yasmāt
translated: that also is not proper, because in the passage there is nothing higher than which there is something else, there is nothing smaller than which there is something greater,

original: aparaṃ yasmād anyat kiṃcid api paraṃ nāsti kenāpi prakāreṇa puruṣavyatiriktasya paratvaṃ nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: aparam yasmāt anyat kiṃcid api param na asti kena api prakāreṇa puruṣa vyatiriktasya paratvam na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: And because there is nothing greater than it, i.e., in no way is there anything greater than the Person.

original: aṇīyastvaṃ sūkṣmatvam /
analyzed: aṇīyaḥ tvam sūkṣma tvam
translated: Smallness means subtlety.

original: jyāyastvaṃ sarveśvaratvam /
analyzed: jyāyaḥ tvam sarva īśvara tvam
translated: Greatness means being the Lord of all.

original: sarvavyāpitvāt sarveśvaratvād asyaitadvyatirikitasya kasyāpy aṇīyastvaṃ jyāyastvaṃ ca nāstītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: sarvavyāpi tvāt sarva īśvara tvāt asya etad vyatirikitasya kasya api aṇīyaḥ tvam jyāyaḥ tvam ca na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: Because He pervades everything and is the Lord of all, there is no one else apart from Him who is smaller or greater. This is the meaning.

original: yasmān nāṇīyo na jyāyo 'sti kaścid iti puruṣād anyasya kasyāpi jyāyastvaṃ niṣiddham iti tasmād anyasya paratvaṃ na yujyata iti pratyuktam /
analyzed: yasmāt na aṇīyaḥ na jyāyaḥ sti kaścid iti puruṣāt anyasya kasya api jyāyaḥ tvam niṣiddham iti tasmāt anyasya paratvam na yujyate iti pratyuktam
translated: Since there is no one smaller or greater than Him, the greatness of anyone other than the Person is denied. Therefore, the supremacy of anything else is not tenable. This is the reply.

original: kas tarhy asya vākyasyārthaḥ /🔽asya prakaraṇasyopakrame tam eva viditvātimṛtyum eti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate 'yanāyāiti
analyzed: kaḥ tarhi asya vākyasya arthaḥ  asya prakaraṇasya upakrame tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate
translated: Then what is the meaning of this statement?🔽At the beginning of this chapter, it is declared that knowing Him alone one goes beyond death, there is no other path for going

original: puruṣavedanasyāmṛtatvahetutāṃ tadvyatiriktasyāpathatāṃ ca pratijñāya yasmāt paraṃ
analyzed: puruṣa vedanasya amṛta tva hetutām tad vyatiriktasya apathatām ca pratijñāya yasmāt param
translated: and that the knowledge of the Person is the cause of immortality, and that anything other than that is not the path. Then, from since there is nothing greater than Him

original: nāparam asti kiṃcit tenedaṃ pūrṇaṃ puruṣeṇa sarvam ity etad antena sarvasmāt paratvaṃ pratipāditam /
analyzed: na aparam asti kiṃcid tena idam pūrṇam puruṣeṇa sarvam iti etat antena sarvasmāt para tvam pratipāditam
translated: up to therefore this whole world is full of that Person, it is taught that He is supreme over everything.

original: yataḥ puruṣatattvam evottarataraṃ tato yaduttarataraṃ puruṣatattvaṃ tad evārūpam anāmayaṃ ya etadvidur amṛtās te bhavanti /
analyzed: yatas puruṣa tattvam eva uttarataram tatas yat uttarataram puruṣa tattvam tat eva arūpam anāmayam ye etat viduḥ amṛtāḥ te bhavanti
translated: Since the truth of the Purusha is superior, that which is superior, the truth of the Purusha, that alone is the formless, the undecaying. Those who know this become immortal.

original: athetare duḥkham evāpiyantīti puruṣavedanasyāmṛtatvahetutvaṃ taditarasyāpathatvaṃ pratijñātaṃ sahetukam upasaṃhṛtam /
analyzed: atha itare duḥkham eva apiyanti iti puruṣa vedanasya amṛta tva hetu tvam tad itarasya apatha tvam pratijñātam sa hetukam upasaṃhṛtam
translated: Others, on the other hand, attain only misery. Thus the cause of immortality is declared to be the knowledge of the Purusha, and the cause of misery is declared to be the opposite of that.

original: anyathopakramagatapratijñābhyāṃ virudhyate /
analyzed: anyathā upakrama gata pratijñābhyām virudhyate
translated: Otherwise, it would contradict the declaration made at the beginning.

original: puruṣasyaiva śuddhiguṇayogena śivaśabdābhiprāyatvaṃ śāśvataṃ śivam acyutam ityādinā jñātam eva /
analyzed: puruṣasya eva śuddhi guṇa yogena śiva śabda abhiprāya tvam śāśvatam śivam acyutam ityādinā jñātam eva
translated: It is known that the word 'Shiva' refers to the Purusha alone by its association with the quality of purity, as stated in such passages as 'The eternal, auspicious, undecaying'.

original: puruṣa eva śivaśabdābhidheya ityanantaram eva vadati mahān prabhur vai puruṣaḥ sattvasyaiṣa pravartaka iti /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ eva śiva śabda abhidheyaḥ iti anantaram eva vadati mahān prabhuḥ vai puruṣaḥ sattvasya eṣa pravartakaḥ iti
translated: Immediately after stating that the Purusha alone is denoted by the word 'Shiva', it is said that 'The great Lord is the Purusha, He is the impeller of Sattva'.

original: uktenaiva nyāyena na san na cāsac chiva eva kevala ityādi sarvaṃ neyam /
analyzed: uktena eva nyāyena na sat na ca asat śivaḥ eva kevalaḥ ityādi sarvam na iyam
translated: By the same reasoning stated above, everything such as 'Shiva is neither existent nor non-existent, He is alone' should be understood.

original: kiṃca na tasyeśe kaścaneti nirastasamābhyadhikasaṃbhāvanasya puruṣasyāṇor aṇīyānityasminn
analyzed: kiṃca na tasya īśe kaścana iti nirasta sama abhyadhika saṃbhāvanasya puruṣasya aṇoḥ aṇīyān iti asmin
translated: Moreover, in the statement 'Of Him there is no controller', the possibility of equality or superiority is refuted. The Purusha, the atom, is smaller than the smallest.

original: anuvāke vedādyantarūpatayā vedabījabhūtapraṇavasya prakṛtibhūtākāravācyatayā maheśvaratvaṃ
analyzed: anuvāke veda ādi anta rūpa tayā veda bīja bhūta praṇavasya prakṛti bhūta ākāra vācya tayā maheśvara tvam
translated: In the Anuvaka, by the form of the beginning and end of the Veda, it is stated that the Praṇava, which is the seed of the Veda, is Maheśvara by being the denoter of the form that is its nature,

original: pratipādya daharapuṇḍarīkamadhyasthākāśāntarvartitayopāsyatvam uktam /
analyzed: pratipādya dahara puṇḍarīka madhya stha ākāśa antar varti tayā upāsya tvam uktam
translated: and that it should be meditated upon as existing within the space in the middle of the small lotus of the heart.

original: ayam arthaḥ sarvasya vedajātasya prakṛtiḥ praṇava uktaḥ /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ sarvasya veda jātasya prakṛtiḥ praṇavaḥ uktaḥ
translated: The meaning is this: The Praṇava is said to be the nature of all the Vedas.

original: praṇavasya ca prakṛtir akāraḥ /
analyzed: praṇavasya ca prakṛtiḥ akāraḥ
translated: And the nature of the Praṇava is the letter a.

original: praṇavavikāro vedaḥ svaprakṛtibhūte praṇave līnaḥ /
translated: The Veda, which is a modification of the Praṇava, is merged in the Praṇava, which is its own nature.

original: praṇavo 'py akāravikārabhūtaḥ svaprakṛtāv akāre līnaḥ /
analyzed: praṇavaḥ api akāra vikāra bhūtaḥ sva prakṛtau akāre līnaḥ
translated: The Praṇava, which is a modification of the letter a, is merged in the letter a, which is its own nature.

original: tasya praṇavaprakṛtibhūtasyākārasya yaḥ paro vācyaḥ sa eva maheśvara iti sarvavācakajātaprakṛtibhūtākāravācyaḥ sarvavācyajātaprakṛtibhūtanārāyaṇo
analyzed: tasya praṇava prakṛti bhūtasya ākārasya yaḥ paraḥ vācyaḥ saḥ eva maheśvaraḥ iti sarva vācaka jāta prakṛti bhūta ākāra vācyaḥ sarva vācya jāta prakṛti bhūta nārāyaṇaḥ
translated: That which is the supreme denotable object of that letter a, which is the nature of the Praṇava, is indeed Maheśvara. The denotable object of the letter a, which is the nature of all the denotative classes, is Nārāyaṇa, who is the nature of all the denotable classes.

original: yaḥ sa maheśavara ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ sa maheśa varaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is Maheśvara.

original: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā
analyzed: yathā uktam bhagavatā
translated: As it is said by the Blessed Lord:

original: ahaṃ kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayas tathā /
analyzed: aham kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ tathā
translated: I am the origin and dissolution of the entire world.

original: mattaḥ parataraṃ nānyatkiṃcid asti dhanaṃjaya //
analyzed: mattaḥ parataram na anyat kiṃcid asti dhanaṃjaya
translated: There is nothing else higher than Me, O Dhananjaya.

original: akṣaraṇām akāro 'smi //
analyzed: akṣaraṇām akāraḥ smi
translated: I am the letter 'a' of the imperishable ones.

original: iti / a iti brahmeti ca śruteḥ /
analyzed: iti a iti brahma iti ca śruteḥ
translated: Thus. And because of the Vedic text, A is Brahman.

original: akāro vai sarvā vāg iti ca /
analyzed: akāraḥ vai sarvā vāc iti ca
translated: And because of the text, The letter A is indeed all speech.

original: vācakajātasyākāraprakṛtitvaṃ vācyajātasya brahmaprakṛtitvaṃ ca suspaṣṭam /
analyzed: vācaka jātasya ākāra prakṛti tvam vācya jātasya brahma prakṛti tvam ca su spaṣṭam
translated: It is very clear that the class of words has A as its source, and the class of objects denoted has Brahman as its source.

original: ato brahmaṇo 'kāravācyatāpratipādanād akāravācyo nārāyaṇa eva maheśvara iti siddham /
analyzed: atas kāra vācya tā pratipādanāt akāra vācyaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ eva maheśvaraḥ iti siddham  /
translated: Therefore, because it is established that Brahman is denoted by the letter A, it is established that Maheśvara is none other than Nārāyaṇa, who is denoted by the letter A.

original: tasyaiva sahasraśīrṣaṃ devam iti kevalaparatattvaviśeṣapratipādanapareṇa nārāyaṇānuvākena sarvasmāt paratvaṃ prapañcitam /
analyzed: tasya eva sahasra śīrṣam devam iti kevala para tattva viśeṣa pratipādana pareṇa nārāyaṇa anuvākena sarvasmāt paratvam prapañcitam
translated: The Nārāyaṇa Āraṇyaka, which is devoted to teaching the nature of the supreme reality alone, elaborates on how he is supreme over everything by calling him the thousand-headed god.

original: anenānanyapareṇa pratipāditam eva paratattvam anyapareṣu sarvavākyeṣu kenāpi śabdena
analyzed: anena ananya pareṇa pratipāditam eva para tattvam anya pareṣu sarva vākyeṣu kena api śabdena
translated: The author of the aphorism has determined that the supreme reality, which is taught by this text that is not devoted to anything else, is understood to be the same as that which is understood by any word in all the texts that are devoted to something else.

original: pratīyamānaṃ tad evety avagamya iti śāstradṛṣtyā tūpadeśo vāmadevavad iti sūtrakāreṇa nirṇītam /
analyzed: pratīyamānam tat eva iti avagamyaḥ iti śāstra dṛṣtyā tu upadeśaḥ vāmadeva vat iti sūtrakāreṇa nirṇītam
translated: Therefore, the teaching is by the view of scripture, like in the case of Vāmadeva.

original: tad etat paraṃ brahma kvacid brahmaśivādiśabdād avagatam iti kevalabrahmaśivayor na paratvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tat etat param brahma kvacid brahma śiva ādi śabdāt avagatam iti kevala brahma śivayoḥ na para tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: This supreme Brahman is understood in some places by words like Brahman, Śiva, etc. Therefore, only Brahman and Śiva are not considered supreme.

original: asminn ananyapare 'nuvāke tayor indrāditulyatayā tadvibhūtitvapratipādanāt /
analyzed: asmin an anya pare nuvāke tayoḥ indra ādi tulya tayā tad vibhūti tva pratipādanāt
translated: In this anuvāka, which is not devoted to anything else, by the statement of their being equal to Indra and Āditya, their being endowed with those powers is taught.

original: kvacid ākāśaprāṇādiśabdena paraṃ brahmābhihitam iti bhūtākāśaprāṇāder yathā na paratvam /
analyzed: kvacid ākāśa prāṇa ādi śabdena param brahma abhihitam iti bhūtākāśa prāṇa ādeḥ yathā na paratvam
translated: In some places, the highest Brahman is spoken of by the words space, vital breath, etc. Just as space, vital breath, etc., are not supreme,

original: yat punar idam āśaṅkitam atha yad idam asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma
analyzed: yat punar idam āśaṅkitam atha yat idam asmin brahmapure daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma
translated: Now, this is suspected: That which is this small lotus-like house in this city of Brahman,

original: daharo 'sminn antarākāśas tasmin yad antas tad anveṣṭavyaṃ tad vā va vijijñāsitavyam
analyzed: daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ tasmin yat antar tat anveṣṭavyam tat vā vaḥ vijijñāsitavyam
translated: the small space within it, what is within that should be sought, that should be desired to be known.

original: ity atrākāśaśabdena jagadupādānakāraṇaṃ pratipādya tadantarvartinaḥ kasyacit tattvaviśeṣasyānveṣṭavyatā pratipādyate /
analyzed: iti atra ākāśa śabdena jagat upādānakāraṇam pratipādya tad antarvartinaḥ kasyacid tattva viśeṣasya anveṣṭavya tā pratipādyate
translated: Here, having taught by the word space the material cause of the world, the necessity of seeking a certain specific reality existing within that is taught.

original: asyākāśasya nāmarūpayor nivoḍhṛtvaśravaṇāt puruṣasūkte puruṣasya nāmarūpayoḥ kartṛtvadarśanāc
analyzed: asya ākāśasya nāma rūpayoḥ nivoḍhṛ tva śravaṇāt puruṣasūkte puruṣasya nāma rūpayoḥ kartṛ tva darśanāt
translated: Because it is heard that this space is the bearer of names and forms, and because in the Puruṣa Sūkta the Puruṣa is seen to be the maker of names and forms,

original: cākāśaparyāyabhūtāt puruṣād anyasyānveṣṭavyatayopāsyatvaṃ pratīyata ityanadhītavedānām
analyzed: ca ākāśa paryāya bhūtāt puruṣāt anyasya anveṣṭavya tayā upāsya tvam pratīyate iti anadhīta vedānām
translated: it is understood that something other than Puruṣa, which is synonymous with space, is to be sought and meditated upon. This is the doubt of those who have not studied the Vedas

original: adṛṣṭaśāstrāṇām idaṃ codyaṃ /
analyzed: adṛṣṭa śāstrāṇām idam codyam
translated: and have not seen the scriptures.

original: yatas tatra śrutir evāsya parihāram āha /🔽vākyakāraś ca daharo 'sminn antarākāśaḥ kiṃ tad atra vidyate yad anveṣṭavyaṃ yad
analyzed: yatas tatra śrutiḥ eva asya parihāram āha  vākya kāraḥ ca daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ kim tat atra vidyate yat anveṣṭavyam yat
translated: For there the Veda itself gives the answer.🔽And the author of the Brahmasutra, having stated that the small space within is to be sought and

original: vā va vijijñāsitavyam iti codite yāvān vā ayam ākāśas tāvān eṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśa
analyzed: vā vaḥ vijijñāsitavyam iti ca udite yāvān vai ayam ākāśaḥ tāvān eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśa
translated: to be known, what is it that is to be sought here, what is to be known? - having stated this, by passages such as As great as is this space, so great is that space within the heart,

original: ityādināsyākāśaśabdavācyasya paramapuruṣasyānavadhikamahattvaṃ sakalajagadādhāratvaṃ
analyzed: ityādinā asya ākāśa śabda vācyasya paramapuruṣasya anavadhika mahā tvam sakala jagat ādhāra tvam
translated: he teaches that this Supreme Person, denoted by the word space, is of unlimited greatness and is the support of the entire world,

original: ca pratipādya tasmin kāmāḥ samāhitā iti kāmaśabdenāpahatapāpmatvādisatyasaṃkalpaparyantaguṇāṣṭakaṃ
analyzed: ca pratipādya tasmin kāmāḥ samāhitāḥ iti kāma śabdena apahata pāpma tva ādi satya saṃkalpa paryanta guṇa aṣṭakam
translated: and having placed the eight qualities beginning with freedom from sin and ending with true resolve in the word desire in the passage In him are all desires collected,

original: nihitam iti paramapuruṣavat paramapuruṣaguṇāṣṭakasyāpi pṛthivijijñāsitavyatāpratipādayiṣayā🔽tasmin yad antas tadanveṣṭavyam ityuktam iti śrutyaiva sarvaṃ parihṛtam /
analyzed: nihitam iti parama puruṣa vat parama puruṣa guṇa aṣṭakasya api pṛthivī jijñāsitavya tā pratipādayiṣayā  tasmin yat antar tat anveṣṭavyam iti uktam iti śrutyā eva sarvam parihṛtam
translated: he teaches that the eight qualities of the Supreme Person are to be sought and known, just as the Supreme Person is.🔽Therefore, in him, what is within, that is to be sought - thus everything is answered by the Veda itself.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati kiṃ tad atra vidyate yad aneṣṭavyam ity asya codyasya tasmin sarvasya
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati kim tat atra vidyate yat an iṣṭavyam iti asya codyasya tasmin sarvasya
translated: This is what is said: To the question What is there within that is to be sought?

original: jagataḥ sraṣṭṛtvam ādhāratvaṃ niyantṛtvaṃ śeṣitvam apahatapāpmatvādayo guṇāś ca vidyanta iti parihāra iti /
analyzed: jagataḥ sraṣṭṛ tvam ādhāra tvam niyantṛ tvam śeṣi tvam apahata pāpma tva ādayaḥ guṇāḥ ca vidyante iti parihāraḥ iti
translated: The answer is that the qualities of being the creator, the support, the controller, the remainder, being free from sin, etc. exist in the world.

original: tathā ca vākyakāravacanam tasmin yad antar iti kāmavyapadeśa iti /
analyzed: tathā ca vākyakāra vacanam tasmin yat antar iti kāma vyapadeśaḥ iti
translated: And thus the statement of the author of the commentary: That which is within it is spoken of as desire.

original: kāmyanta iti kāmāḥ /
analyzed: kāmyante iti kāmāḥ
translated: Desires are that which is desired.

original: apahatapāpmatvādayo guṇā ityarthaḥ /🔽etad uktaṃ bhavati yad etad daharākāśaśabdābhidheyaṃ nikhilajagadudayavaibhavalayalīlaṃ
analyzed: apahata pāpma tva ādayaḥ guṇāḥ iti arthaḥ  etat uktam bhavati yat etat daharākāśa śabda abhidheyam nikhila jagat udaya vaibhava laya līlam
translated: The meaning is that the qualities such as being free from sin, etc. are desires.🔽This is what is said: That supreme Brahman, which is the abode of the sport of the manifestation and dissolution of the entire world,

original: paraṃ brahma tasmin yad antar nihitam anavadhikātiśayam apahatapāpmatvādiguṇāṣṭakaṃ
analyzed: param brahma tasmin yat antar nihitam anavadhika atiśayam apahata pāpma tva ādi guṇa aṣṭakam
translated: and which is denoted by the word inner space in the small ether, that which is hidden within it, the group of eight qualities such as being free from sin, etc., which is of unlimited excellence,

original: tad ubhayam apy anveṣṭavyaṃ vijijñāsitavyam iti /
analyzed: tat ubhayam api anveṣṭavyam vijijñāsitavyam iti
translated: both of these should be sought and desired to be known.

original: yathāha atha ya ihātmānam anuvidya vrajanty etāṃś ca satyān kāmāṃs teṣāṃ sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāro bhavantīti /
analyzed: yathā āha atha ye iha ātmānam anuvidya vrajanti etān ca satyān kāmān teṣām sarveṣu lokeṣu kāmacāraḥ bhavanti iti
translated: As it is said: And those who, having understood the self here, depart to these true desires, for them there is freedom to go as they wish in all the worlds.

original: yaḥ punaḥ kāraṇasyaiva dhyeyatāpratipādanapare vākye viṣṇor ananyaparavākyapratipāditaparatattvabhūtasya
analyzed: yaḥ punar kāraṇasya eva dhyeya tā pratipādana pare vākye viṣṇoḥ ananya para vākya pratipādita para tattva bhūtasya
translated: But one who, in a statement whose purpose is to teach the meditability of the cause itself, of Vishnu, who is the supreme reality taught by statements not having any other purpose,

original: kāryamadhye niveśaḥ sa svakāryabhūtatattvasaṃkhyāpūraṇaṃ kurvataḥ svalīlayā jagadupakārāya
analyzed: kārya madhye niveśaḥ sa sva kārya bhūta tattva saṃkhyā pūraṇam kurvataḥ sva līlayā jagat upakārāya
translated: Its placement within the effect is the filling of the number of principles that are its own effects, which it does with its own play for the benefit of the world.

original: svecchāvatāra ity avagantavyaḥ /🔽yathā līlayā devasaṃkhyāpūrṇaṃ kurvata upendratvaṃ parasyaiva /
analyzed: svecchā avatāraḥ iti avagantavyaḥ  yathā līlayā deva saṃkhyā pūrṇam kurvataḥ upendra tvam parasya eva
translated: His incarnation is to be understood as being for the benefit of the world, by his own will, while filling up the number of his own effects, among the effects to be accomplished.🔽For example, the incarnation of the Supreme Lord as Upendra, while filling up the number of gods with ease.

original: yathā ca sūryavaṃśodbhavarājasaṃkhyāpūrṇaṃ kurvataḥ parasyaiva brahmaṇo dāśarathirūpeṇa svecchāvatāraḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca sūrya vaṃśa udbhava rāja saṃkhyā pūrṇam kurvataḥ parasya eva brahmaṇaḥ dāśarathi rūpeṇa sva icchā avatāraḥ
translated: And the incarnation of the Supreme Brahman itself in the form of Dasha-ratha, while filling up the number of kings born in the solar dynasty.

original: yathā ca somavaṃśasaṃkhyāpūraṇaṃ kurvato bhagavato bhūbhārāvatāraṇāya svecchayā vasudevagṛhe 'vatāraḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca soma vaṃśa saṃkhyā pūraṇam kurvataḥ bhagavataḥ bhū bhāra avatāraṇāya sva icchayā vasudeva gṛhe vatāraḥ
translated: And the incarnation of the Lord in the house of Vasudeva out of his own will, for the purpose of relieving the earth of her burden, while filling up the number of the lunar dynasty.

original: sṛṣṭipralayaprakaraṇeṣu nārāyaṇa eva paramakāraṇatayā pratipādyata iti pūrvam evoktam /
analyzed: sṛṣṭi pralaya prakaraṇeṣu nārāyaṇaḥ eva parama kāraṇatayā pratipādyate iti pūrvam eva uktam
translated: It has already been stated that in the sections on creation and dissolution, Narayana alone is taught as the supreme cause.

original: yat punar atharvaśirasi rudreṇa svasarvāiśvaryaṃ prapañcitaṃ tat so 'ntarād antaraṃ prāviśad iti paramātmapraveśād uktam iti śrutyaiva vyaktam
analyzed: yat punar atharvaśirasi rudreṇa sva sarva aiśvaryam prapañcitam tat saḥ ntarāt antaram prāviśat iti paramātma praveśāt uktam iti śrutyā eva vyaktam
translated: And what is elaborated by Rudra in the Atharva-shiras about his own all-pervasiveness is stated to be due to his entering into the innermost of the innermost, as stated by the Upanishad itself.

original: śāstradṛṣṭyā tūpadeśo vāmadevavad iti sūtrakāreṇaivaṃvādinām arthaḥ pratipāditaḥ /
analyzed: śāstra dṛṣṭyā tu upadeśaḥ vāmadeva vat iti sūtrakāreṇa evaṃvādinām arthaḥ pratipāditaḥ
translated: But the author of the aphorisms has taught the meaning of those who say thus, that the teaching is according to the view of scripture, like that of Vamadeva.

original: yathoktaṃ prahlādenāpi
analyzed: yathā uktam prahlādena api
translated: As it has been said by Prahlada also:

original: sarvagatvād anantarasya sa evāham avasthitaḥ /
analyzed: sarva ga tvāt anantarasya saḥ eva aham avasthitaḥ
translated: Because He is all-pervading, I am that very one who abides.

original: mattaḥ sarvam ahaṃ sarvaṃ mayi sarvaṃ sanātane //
analyzed: mattaḥ sarvam aham sarvam mayi sarvam sanātane
translated: From Me is all, all is in Me, all is in the eternal One.

original: ityādi / atra sarvagatvād anantasyeti hetur uktaḥ /
analyzed: ityādi atra sarvaga tvāt anantasya iti hetuḥ uktaḥ
translated: And so on. Here the reason is stated: because He is all-pervading and infinite.

original: svaśarīrabhūtasya sarvasya cidacidvastuna ātmatvena sarvagaḥ paramātmeti sarve śabdāḥ sarvaśarīraṃ paramātmānam evābhidadhatīty uktam /
analyzed: sva śarīra bhūtasya sarvasya cit acit vastunaḥ ātma tvena sarvagaḥ paramātmā iti sarve śabdāḥ sarva śarīram paramātmānam eva abhidadhati iti uktam
translated: It has been said that all words refer to the Supreme Self alone, which is the body of all, of the conscious and unconscious things that are its own body, as the Supreme Self is all-pervading as the Self of all.

original: ato 'ham iti śabdaḥ svātmaprakāraprakāriṇaṃ paramātmānam evācaṣṭe /
analyzed: atas ham iti śabdaḥ sva ātma prakāra prakāriṇam paramātmānam eva ācaṣṭe
translated: Therefore, the word I denotes the Supreme Self, which is the object of the notion of one's own Self.

original: ata idam ucyate /
analyzed: atas idam ucyate
translated: Therefore, this is said:

original: ātmety eva tu gṛhṇīyāt sarvasya tanniṣpatter ityādināhaṃgrahaṇopāsanaṃ vākyakāreṇa
analyzed: ātmā iti eva tu gṛhṇīyāt sarvasya tad niṣpatteḥ ityādinā ahaṃgrahaṇa upāsanam vākya kāreṇa
translated: But one should grasp only as the Self, because everything is accomplished in that, and so on. The author of the aphorisms has said that the meditation on the grasping of I

original: kāryāvasthaḥ kāraṇāvasthaś ca sthūlasūkṣmacidacidvastuśarīraḥ paramātmaiveti sarvasya
analyzed: kārya avasthaḥ kāraṇa avasthaḥ ca sthūla sūkṣma cit acit vastu śarīraḥ paramātmā eva iti sarvasya
translated: is the Supreme Self alone, in the state of effect and in the state of cause, with the body of gross, subtle, conscious and unconscious things, because everything

original: tanniṣpatter ity uktam /
analyzed: tad niṣpatteḥ iti uktam
translated: is accomplished in that.

original: ātmeti tūpagacchanti grāhayanti ceti sūtrakāreṇa ca /
analyzed: ātmā iti tu upagacchanti grāhayanti ca iti sūtrakāreṇa ca
translated: But the author of the Sūtras [i.e., Jaimini] and [the followers of the Sāṃkhya system] maintain that [the individual soul is the Self].

original: mahābhārate ca brahmarudrasaṃvāde brahmā rudraṃ prayāha
analyzed: mahābhārate ca brahma rudra saṃvāde brahmā rudram prayāha
translated: And in the Mahābhārata, in the dialogue between Brahmā and Rudra, Brahmā says to Rudra:

original: tavāntarātmā mama ca ye cānye dehisaṃjñitāḥ /
analyzed: tava antarātmā mama ca ye ca anye dehi saṃjñitāḥ
translated: You are the inner Self of me and of others who are called embodied beings.

original: iti / rudrasya brahmaṇaś cānyeṣāṃ ca dehināṃ parameśvaro nārāyaṇo 'ntarātmatayāvasthita iti /
analyzed: iti rudrasya brahmaṇaḥ ca anyeṣām ca dehinām parameśvaraḥ nārāyaṇaḥ ntarātma tayā avasthitaḥ iti
translated: Thus, the highest Lord Nārāyaṇa abides as the inner Self of Rudra, Brahmā, and other embodied beings.

original: tathā tatraiva
analyzed: tathā tatra eva
translated: Similarly, in the same [text]:

original: viṣṇur ātmā bhagavato bhavasyāmitatejasaḥ /
analyzed: viṣṇuḥ ātmā bhagavataḥ bhavasya amita tejasaḥ
translated: Viṣṇu is the Self of the blessed one, Rudra of immeasurable splendor.

original: tasmād dhanurjyāsaṃsparśaṃ sa viṣehe maheśvaraḥ //
analyzed: tasmāt dhanuḥ jyā saṃsparśam sa viṣehe maheśvaraḥ
translated: Therefore, Maheśvara [i.e., Śiva] can endure the touch of the bowstring.

original: iti / tatraiva
analyzed: iti tatra eva
translated: In the same [text]:

original: etau dvau vibudhaśreṣṭhau prasādakrodhajau smṛtau /
analyzed: etau dvau vibudha śreṣṭhau prasāda krodha jau smṛtau
translated: These two, the best of the gods, are known as born from grace and wrath.

original: tadādarśitapanthānau sṛṣṭisaṃhārakārakau //
analyzed: tad ādarśita panthānau sṛṣṭi saṃhāra kārakau
translated: Following the path shown by him, they perform creation and dissolution.

original: iti / antarātmatayāvasthitanārāyaṇadarśitapathau brahmarudrau sṛṣṭisaṃhārakāryakarāv ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti antarātma tayā avasthita nārāyaṇa darśita pathau brahma rudrau sṛṣṭi saṃhāra kārya karau iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that Brahmā and Rudra, following the path shown by Nārāyaṇa who abides as the inner Self, perform the functions of creation and dissolution.

original: nimittopādānayos tu bhedaṃ vadanto vedabāhyā eva syuḥ /
analyzed: nimitta upādānayoḥ tu bhedam vadantaḥ veda bāhyāḥ eva syuḥ
translated: But those who speak of a difference between the instrumental cause and the material cause would be outside the Vedas.

original: janmādyasya yataḥ prakṛtiś ca pratijñādṛṣṭāntānuparodhād ityādi vedavitpraṇītasūtravirodhāt /
analyzed: janma ādyasya yatas prakṛtiḥ ca pratijñā dṛṣṭānta an uparodhāt ityādi veda vid praṇīta sūtra virodhāt
translated: Because it is contrary to the sutras composed by the knowers of the Vedas, such as The origin etc. of this is from the Primordial Nature, because it is not contradicted by the promise and the example.

original: sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ekam evādvitīyam tad aikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti brahmavanaṃ
analyzed: sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam tat aikṣata bahu syām prajāyeya iti brahma vanam
translated: O Somya, this was Being only in the beginning, one only, without a second. It looked about; it desired: 'Let me be many; let me procreate.' It sent forth fire.

original: brahma sa vṛkṣa āsīd yato dyāvāpṛthivī niṣṭatakṣuḥ brahmādhyatiṣṭhadbhuvanāni dhārayan
analyzed: brahma sa vṛkṣaḥ āsīt yatas dyāvāpṛthivī niṣṭatakṣuḥ brahma adhyatiṣṭhat bhuvanāni dhārayan
translated: That Brahman was the tree from which they fashioned heaven and earth. Brahman stood upholding the worlds.

original: sarve nimeṣā jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣādadhi na tasyeśe kaścana tasya nāma mahadyaśaḥ
analyzed: sarve nimeṣāḥ jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣāt adhi na tasya īśe kaścana tasya nāma mahat yaśaḥ
translated: All the twinklings of the eye were born from the Person, the lightning flashes. He has no lord. His name is the Great Glory.

original: neha nānāsti kiṃcana sarvasya vaśī sarvasyeśānaḥ puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ yad bhūtaṃ
analyzed: na iha nānā asti kiṃcana sarvasya vaśī sarvasya īśānaḥ puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam yat bhūtam
translated: Here there is nothing diverse at all. The Person is the controller of all, the lord of all. This entire universe is the Person, whatever has been and whatever will be.

original: yac ca bhavyam utāmṛtattvasyeśānaḥ nānyaḥ panthā ayanāya vidyata ityādisarvaśrutivirodhāc ca /
analyzed: yat ca bhavyam uta amṛta tvasya īśānaḥ na anyaḥ panthāḥ ayanāya vidyate ityādi sarva śruti virodhāt ca
translated: He is the lord of immortality. There is no other path for going. Because it is contrary to all such Vedic statements.

original: itihāsapurāṇeṣu ca sṛṣṭisthitipralayaprakaraṇayor idam eva paratattvam ity avagamyate /
analyzed: itihāsa purāṇeṣu ca sṛṣṭi sthiti pralaya prakaraṇayoḥ idam eva para tattvam iti avagamyate
translated: And in the Itihasa and Puranas, in the sections on creation, sustenance and dissolution, it is understood that this alone is the supreme truth.

original: yathā mahābhārate
analyzed: yathā mahābhārate
translated: As in the Mahabharata:

original: kutaḥ sṛṣṭam idaṃ sarvaṃ jagatsthāvarajaṅgamam /
analyzed: kutas sṛṣṭam idam sarvam jagat sthāvara jaṅgamam
translated: From where was this entire world, with its moving and unmoving beings, created?🔽And how did it perish in the past? And how will it perish in the future?

original: pralaye ca kam abhyeti tan to brūhi pitāmaha //
analyzed: pralaye ca kam abhyeti tat te brūhi pitāmaha
translated: And where does it go at the time of dissolution? Tell me that, O grandfather.

original: iti pṛṣṭo
analyzed: iti pṛṣṭaḥ
translated: Thus asked,

original: nārāyaṇo jaganmūrtir anantātmā sanātana /
analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ jagat mūrtiḥ ananta ātmā sanātana
translated: Nārāyaṇa, the form of the world, the infinite soul, the eternal one,

original: ityādi ca vadati
analyzed: ityādi ca vadati
translated: and so on, he speaks.

original: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā mahābhūtāni dhātavaḥ /
analyzed: ṛṣayaḥ pitaraḥ devāḥ mahābhūtāni dhātavaḥ
translated: The sages, the manes, the gods, the great elements, the minerals,

original: jaṅgamājaṅgamaṃ cedaṃ jagannārāyaṇodbhavam //
analyzed: jaṅgama ajaṅgamam ca idam jagat nārāyaṇa udbhavam
translated: this moving and unmoving world has arisen from Nārāyaṇa.

original: iti ca / prācyodīcyadākṣiṇātyapāścātyasarvaśiṣṭaiḥ sarvadharmasarvatattvavyavasthāyām
analyzed: iti ca prācya udīcya dākṣiṇātya pāścātya sarva śiṣṭaiḥ sarva dharma sarva tattva vyavasthāyām
translated: Thus, by the learned of the east, north, south, west, and all, in establishing all Dharma and all truth,

original: idam eva paryāptam ity avigānaparigṛhītaṃ vaiṣṇavaṃ ca purāṇaṃ janmādy asya yata
analyzed: idam eva paryāptam iti avigāna parigṛhītam vaiṣṇavam ca purāṇam janma ādi asya yata
translated: this alone is sufficient. Thus accepted without dispute, the Viṣṇu Purāṇa, from which the birth and so on of this [universe]

original: iti jagajjanmādikāraṇaṃ brahmety avagamyate /
analyzed: iti jagat janma ādikāraṇam brahma iti avagamyate
translated: is known, it is understood that Brahman is the cause of the birth and so on of the world.

original: tajjanmādikāraṇaṃ kim iti praśnapūrvakaṃ viṣṇoḥ sakāśād bhūtam ityādinā brahmasvarūpaviśeṣapratipādanaikaparatayā pravṛttam iti sarvasaṃmatam
analyzed: tat janma ādikāraṇam kim iti praśna pūrvakam viṣṇoḥ sakāśāt bhūtam ityādinā brahma svarūpa viśeṣa pratipādana eka para tayā pravṛttam iti sarva saṃmatam
translated: That it is the cause of birth and so on, the question being What is that?, it is agreed by all that it is engaged solely in teaching the specific nature of Brahman, beginning with The existent from Viṣṇu.

original: tathā tatraiva
analyzed: tathā tatra eva
translated: Similarly, there itself,

original: prakṛtir yā khyātā vyaktāvyaktasvarūpiṇī /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ yā khyātā vyakta avyakta svarūpiṇī
translated: That which is known as Prakṛti, having the form of the manifest and the unmanifest,

original: puruṣaś capy ubhāv etau līyete paramātmani //
analyzed: puruṣaḥ ca api ubhau etau līyete paramātmani
translated: and also Puruṣa, both of these dissolve into the Supreme Self.

original: paramātmā ca sarveṣām ādhāraḥ parameśvaraḥ /
analyzed: paramātmā ca sarveṣām ādhāraḥ parameśvaraḥ
translated: And the Supreme Self is the support of all, the Supreme Lord.

original: viṣṇunāmā sa vedeṣu vedānteṣu ca gīyate //
analyzed: viṣṇu nāmā sa vedeṣu vedānteṣu ca gīyate
translated: He is sung about in the Vedas and Vedanta by the name of Vishnu.

original: iti / sarvavedavedānteṣu sarvaiḥ śabdaiḥ paramakāraṇatayāyam eva gīyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti sarva veda vedānteṣu sarvaiḥ śabdaiḥ parama kāraṇatayā ayam eva gīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in all the Vedas and Vedanta, he alone is sung about as the supreme cause by all the words.

original: yathā sarvāsu ṣrutiṣu kevalaparabrahmasvarūpaviśeṣapratipādanāyaiva pravṛtto nārāyaṇānuvākas tathedaṃ vaiṣṇavaṃ ca purāṇam
analyzed: yathā sarvāsu ṣrutiṣu kevala para brahma sva rūpa viśeṣa pratipādanāya eva pravṛttaḥ nārāyaṇa anuvākaḥ tathā idam vaiṣṇavam ca purāṇam
translated: Just as the Narayana hymn in all the scriptures is engaged only in teaching the nature of the supreme Brahman, so is this Vaishnava Purana.

original: so 'ham icchāmi dharmajña śrotuṃ tvatto yathā jagat /
analyzed: saḥ ham icchāmi dharma jña śrotum tvattaḥ yathā jagat
translated: O knower of dharma, I wish to hear from you how the world

original: babhūva bhūyaś ca yathā mahābhāga bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: babhūva bhūyas ca yathā mahābhāga bhaviṣyati
translated: came to be and how it will be again in the future, O greatly fortunate one.

original: yanmayaṃ ca jagadbrahmany ataś caitaccarācaram /
analyzed: yad mayam ca jagat brahmani atas ca etat carācaram
translated: In which Brahman, O Brahmana, this world consisting of the moving and unmoving

original: līnam āsīd yathā yatra layam eṣyati yatra ca //
analyzed: līnam āsīt yathā yatra layam eṣyati yatra ca
translated: dissolved and in which it will dissolve again.

original: iti paraṃ brahma kim iti prakramya🔽viṣṇoḥ sakāśād udbhūtaṃ jagat tatraiva ca sthitam /
analyzed: iti param brahma kim iti prakramya  viṣṇoḥ sakāśāt udbhūtam jagat tatra eva ca sthitam
translated: Thus, having begun with the supreme Brahman,🔽the world originated from Vishnu and abides in him alone.

original: sthitisaṃyamakartāsau jagato 'sya jagac ca saḥ //
analyzed: sthiti saṃyama kartā asau jagataḥ sya jagat ca saḥ
translated: He is the controller of the creation and dissolution of this world and is the world itself.

original: paraḥ parāṇāṃ paramaḥ paramātmātmasaṃsthitaḥ /
analyzed: paraḥ parāṇām paramaḥ parama ātma ātma saṃsthitaḥ
translated: He is the supreme of all, the supreme Self, abiding in the Self.

original: rūpavarṇādinirdeśaviśeṣaṇavivarjitaḥ //
analyzed: rūpa varṇa ādi nirdeśa viśeṣaṇa vivarjitaḥ
translated: He is devoid of the particularities of description such as form, color, etc.

original: apakṣayavināśābhyāṃ pariṇāmarddhijanmabhiḥ /
analyzed: apakṣaya vināśābhyām pariṇāma ṛddhi janmabhiḥ
translated: He is free from decrease, destruction, transformation, origination, and birth.

original: varjitaḥ śakyate vaktuṃ yaḥ sad astīti kevalam //
analyzed: varjitaḥ śakyate vaktum yaḥ sat asti iti kevalam
translated: He can only be said to exist as 'that which is',

original: sarvatrāsau samastaṃ ca vasaty atreti vai yataḥ /
analyzed: sarvatra asau samastam ca vasati atrā iti vai yatas
translated: Because He is present everywhere and in everything,

original: tataḥ sa vāsudeveti vidvadbhiḥ paripaṭhyate //
analyzed: tatas sa vāsudeva iti vidvadbhiḥ paripaṭhyate
translated: Therefore, He is called Vāsudeva by the learned.

original: tadbrahma paraṃ nityam ajam akṣayam avyayam /
analyzed: tat brahma param nityam ajam akṣayam avyayam
translated: That Brahman is supreme, eternal, unborn, imperishable, unchanging,

original: ekasvarūpaṃ ca sadā heyābhāvāc ca nirmalam //
analyzed: eka svarūpam ca sadā heya abhāvāt ca nirmalam
translated: And always of one form, and free from impurities due to the absence of anything to be renounced.

original: tad eva sarvam evaitadvyaktāvyaktasvarūpavat /
analyzed: tat eva sarvam eva etat vyakta avyakta sva rūpavat
translated: It is all this, having the form of the manifest and the unmanifest,

original: tathā puruṣarūpeṇa kālarūpeṇa ca sthitam //
analyzed: tathā puruṣa rūpeṇa kāla rūpeṇa ca sthitam
translated: And likewise existing in the form of Purusha and Kala.

original: sa sarvabhūtaprakṛtiṃ vikārān guṇādidoṣāṃś ca mune vyatītaḥ /
analyzed: sa sarva bhūta prakṛtim vikārān guṇa ādi doṣān ca mune vyatītaḥ
translated: O sage, He is beyond the primordial nature of all beings, their modifications, and the faults beginning with the gunas.

original: atītasarvāvaraṇo 'khilātmā tenāstṛtaṃ yad bhuvanāntarāle //🔽samastakalyāṇaguṇātmako 'sau svaśaktileśoddhṛtabhūtavargaḥ /
analyzed: atīta sarva āvaraṇaḥ khila ātmā tena āstṛtam yat bhuvana antarāle  samasta kalyāṇa guṇa ātmakaḥ sau sva śakti leśa uddhṛta bhūta vargaḥ
translated: He is beyond all coverings, the Self of all, and by Him is pervaded that space between the worlds.🔽He is the embodiment of all auspicious qualities, and the group of elements is drawn forth by a mere part of His power.

original: icchāgṛhītābhimatorudehaḥ saṃsādhitāśeṣajagaddhito 'sau //
analyzed: icchā gṛhīta abhimata uru dehaḥ saṃsādhita aśeṣa jagat hitaḥ sau
translated: Having assumed a desired and great body by His will, He accomplishes the welfare of the entire world.

original: tejobalāiśvaryamahāvabodhasuvīryaśaktyādiguṇaikarāśiḥ /
analyzed: tejaḥ bala aiśvarya mahā avabodha su vīrya śakti ādi guṇa eka rāśiḥ
translated: A mass of qualities such as splendor, strength, lordship, great knowledge, excellent valor, power, etc.,

original: paraḥ parāṇāṃ sakalā na yatra kleśādayaḥ santi parāvareśe //
analyzed: paraḥ parāṇām sakalāḥ na yatra kleśa ādayaḥ santi parāvara īśe
translated: In whom the highest of the high, where all afflictions etc. do not exist, in the Lord of the highest and the lowest.

original: sa īśvaro vyaṣṭisamaṣṭirūpo 'vyaktasvarūpaḥ prakaṭasvarūpaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ īśvaraḥ vyaṣṭi samaṣṭi rūpaḥ vyakta svarūpaḥ prakaṭa svarūpaḥ
translated: He is the Lord, in the form of the individual and the whole, of unmanifest form, of manifest form,
