original: nārāyaṇasyāparicchedyajñānānandāmalatvasvarūpavajjñānaśaktibalāiśvaryavīryatejaḥprabhṛtyanavadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇavatsvasaṃkalpapravartyasvetarasamastacidacidvastujātavatsvābhimatasvānurūpaikarūpadivyarūpataducitaniratiśayakalyāṇavividhānaṃtabhūṣaṇasvaśaktisadṛśāparimitānantāścaryanānāvidhāyudhasvābhimatānurūpasvarūpaguṇavibhavāiśvaryaśīlādyanavadhikamahimamahisīsvānurūpakalyāṇajñānakriyādyaparimeyaguṇānantaparijanaparicchedasvocitanikhilabhogyabhogopakaraṇādyanantamahāvibhavāvāṅmanasagocarasvarūpasvabhāvadivyasthānādinityatāniravadyatāgocarāś
analyzed: nārāyaṇasya aparicchedya jñāna ānanda amala tva svarūpavat jñāna śakti bala aiśvarya vīrya tejaḥ prabhṛti anavadhika atiśaya asaṃkhyeya kalyāṇa guṇavat sva saṃkalpa pravartya sva itara samasta cit acit vastu jātavat sva abhimata sva anurūpa eka rūpa divya rūpa tad ucita niratiśaya kalyāṇa vividha ananta bhūṣaṇa sva śakti sadṛśa aparimita ananta āścarya nānāvidha āyudha sva abhimata anurūpa svarūpa guṇa vibhava aiśvarya śīla ādi anavadhika mahima mahi
translated: Like the incomprehensible knowledge, bliss, and purity of Narayana, the knowledge, power, strength, lordship, valor, radiance, and other infinite, superior, innumerable, auspicious qualities, the entire class of conscious and unconscious things that are set in motion by His will, His desired, suitable, single, divine form, His befitting, unsurpassed, auspicious, various, infinite ornaments, His immeasurable, infinite, wonderful, various weapons, His desired, suitable, natural, virtuous, powerful, lordship, and other infinite glories, His desired, suitable, auspicious, knowledge, action, and other innumerable qualities, His retinue of the finite and infinite, His befitting, entire enjoyments, means of enjoyment, and other infinite great riches, His form, nature, divine abode, and other eternal, faultless objects,

original: ca sahasraśaḥ śrutayaḥ santi /
analyzed: ca sahasraśas śrutayaḥ santi
translated: and thousands of such statements are found.

original: vedāham etaṃ puruṣaṃ mahāntam ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt /
analyzed: veda aham etam puruṣam mahāntam āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt
translated: I know this great Person, of the color of the sun, beyond the darkness,

original: ya eṣo 'ntarāditye hiraṇmayaḥ puruṣaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ eṣaḥ ntarāditye hiraṇmayaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: who is the golden Person within the sun.

original: tasya yathā kapyāsaṃ puṇḍarīkam evam akṣiṇī /
analyzed: tasya yathā kapyāsam puṇḍarīkam evam akṣiṇī
translated: His eyes are like the lotus of the monkey-flower tree.

original: ya eṣo 'ntarhṛdaya ākāśas tasminn ayaṃ puruṣo manomayo 'mṛto hiraṇmayaḥ manomaya
analyzed: yaḥ eṣaḥ ntar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ tasmin ayam puruṣaḥ manaḥ mayaḥ mṛtaḥ hiraṇmayaḥ manaḥ maya
translated: This person in the space within the heart, consisting of mind, immortal, golden, consisting of mind

original: iti manasaiva viśuddhena gṛhyata ityarthaḥ sarve nimeṣā jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣād
analyzed: iti manasā eva viśuddhena gṛhyate iti arthaḥ sarve nimeṣāḥ jajñire vidyutaḥ puruṣāt
translated: means that he is perceived by the mind alone, purified. All the twinkling of the eye, the lightnings, were born from the person.

original: adhi vidyudvarṇāt puruṣād ityarthaḥ nīlatoyadamadhyasthā vidyullekheva bhāsvarā madhyasthanīlatoyadā
analyzed: adhi vidyut varṇāt puruṣāt iti arthaḥ nīla toyada madhya sthā vidyut lekhā iva bhāsvarā madhya stha nīla toyadā
translated: From the person of the color of lightning, means from the person. Like a flash of lightning in the midst of a dark cloud, shining, in the midst of a dark cloud

original: vidyullekheva seyaṃ daharapuṇḍarīkamadhyasthākāśavartinī vahnirśikhā svāntarnihitanīlatoyadābhaparamātmasvarūpā
analyzed: vidyut lekhā iva sā iyam dahara puṇḍarīka madhya stha ākāśa vartinī vahniḥ śikhā sva antar nihita nīla toyada ābha paramātma svarūpā
translated: like a flash of lightning, this flame of fire residing in the space in the middle of the small lotus, having the form of the supreme self in the form of a dark cloud hidden within,

original: avāntarnihitanīlatoyadā visyud ivābhātītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: avāntar nihita nīla toyadā visyut iva ābhāti iti arthaḥ
translated: appears as if rising from within a dark cloud hidden within.

original: manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīro bhārūpaḥ /
analyzed: manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ bhā rūpaḥ
translated: Consisting of mind, having life as its body, having the form of light,

original: satyakāmaḥ satyasaṃkalpaḥ /🔽ākāśātmā sarvakāmā sarvakāmaḥ sarvagandhaḥ sarvarasaḥ sarvam idam abhyātto 'vākyānādaraḥ /
analyzed: satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ  ākāśa ātmā sarva kāmā sarva kāmaḥ sarva gandhaḥ sarva rasaḥ sarvam idam abhyāttaḥ vākya anādaraḥ
translated: having true desires, having true intentions,🔽having space as its self, having all desires, having all desires, having all smells, having all tastes, having all this as its object, having speech as its food, having the sky as its garment, and so on.

original: māhārajanaṃ vāsa ityādyāḥ /
analyzed: māhārajanam vāsaḥ ityādyāḥ
translated: These are the verses.

original: asyeśānā jagato viṣṇupatnī /
analyzed: asya īśānā jagataḥ viṣṇu patnī
translated: The wife of Vishnu is the ruler of this world.

original: hrīś ca te lakṣmīś ca patnyau /
analyzed: hrīḥ ca te lakṣmīḥ ca patnyau
translated: And Hri and Lakshmi are your wives.

original: tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padaṃ sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ /
analyzed: tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ
translated: That is the supreme abode of Vishnu, which the wise always behold.

original: kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parāke /
analyzed: kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parāke
translated: Far away from this world of change,

original: yad ekam avyaktam anantarūpaṃ viśvaṃ purāṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt /
analyzed: yat ekam avyaktam ananta rūpam viśvam purāṇam tamasaḥ parastāt
translated: That which is one, unmanifest, of infinite form, all-pervading, ancient, beyond darkness,

original: yo veda nihitaṃ guhāyāṃ parame vyoman /
analyzed: yaḥ veda nihitam guhāyām parame vyoman
translated: He who knows what is hidden in the cave, in the highest heaven,

original: yo 'syādhyakṣaḥ parame vyoman /
analyzed: yaḥ sya adhyakṣaḥ parame vyoman
translated: He who is the overseer of this, in the highest heaven,

original: tad eva tad u bhavyamā
analyzed: tat eva tat u bhavyamā
translated: That alone is that, and it is the auspicious one.

original: idaṃ tadakṣare parame vyoman nityādiśrutiśataniścito 'yam arthaḥ /
analyzed: idam tat akṣare parame vyoman nitya ādi śruti śata niścitaḥ yam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning ascertained by hundreds of eternal Vedic passages, in the highest heaven of the imperishable one.

original: tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padam iti viṣṇoḥ parasya brahmaṇaḥ paraṃ padaṃ sadā paśyanti sūraya iti vacanāt sarvakāladarśanavantaḥ paripūrṇajñānāḥ kecana 🔽santīti vijñāyate /
analyzed: tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam iti viṣṇoḥ parasya brahmaṇaḥ param padam sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ iti vacanāt sarva kāla darśanavantaḥ paripūrṇa jñānāḥ kecana  santi iti vijñāyate
translated: By the statement That is the supreme abode of Vishnu, the supreme abode of Vishnu, the supreme Brahman, is always beheld by some wise ones, it is known that they possess knowledge of all times and are fully enlightened.

original: ye sūrayas te sadā paśyantīti vacanavyaktiḥ /
analyzed: ye sūrayaḥ te sadā paśyanti iti vacana vyaktiḥ
translated: The expression of the statement is Those who are wise always behold it.

original: ye sadā paśyanti te sūraya iti vā /
analyzed: ye sadā paśyanti te sūrayaḥ iti vā
translated: Or Those who always behold it are wise.

original: ubhayapakṣe 'py anekavidhānaṃ na saṃbhavatīti cet / na /
analyzed: ubhaya pakṣe pi aneka vidhānam na saṃbhavati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in both cases, the injunction of many kinds is not possible, it is not so.

original: aprāptatvāt sarvasya sarvaviśiṣṭaṃ paramasthānaṃ vidhīyate /
analyzed: aprāpta tvāt sarvasya sarva viśiṣṭam parama sthānam vidhīyate
translated: Because everything is not attained, the supreme abode, which is superior to everything, is enjoined.

original: yathoktaṃ tadguṇās te vidhīyerann avibhāgād vidhānārthe na ced anyena śiṣṭā iti /
analyzed: yathā uktam tad guṇāḥ te vidhīyeran avibhāgāt vidhāna arthe na ced anyena śiṣṭāḥ iti
translated: As it is said, those qualities mentioned would be enjoined, because of non-distinction, for the purpose of injunction, if not enjoined by another.

original: yathā yadāgneyo 'ṣṭākapāla ityādikarmavidhau karmaṇo guṇānāṃ cāprāptatvena sarvaguṇaviśiṣṭaṃ
analyzed: yathā yat āgneyaḥ ṣṭākapālaḥ iti ādi karma vidhau karmaṇaḥ guṇānām ca aprāpta tvena sarva guṇa viśiṣṭam
translated: Just as in the injunction of the rite beginning with Agneya Ashtakapala, since the rite and its qualities are not obtained, the rite qualified by all the qualities is

original: karma vidhīyate tathātrāpi sūribhiḥ sadā dṛśyatvena viṣṇoḥ paramasthānam aprāptaṃ
analyzed: karma vidhīyate tathā atrā api sūribhiḥ sadā dṛśya tvena viṣṇoḥ parama sthānam a prāptam
translated: enjoined, so also here, since Vishnu is always seen by the wise, the highest abode which is not obtained

original: pratipādayatīti na kaścid virodhaḥ /
analyzed: pratipādayati iti na kaścid virodhaḥ
translated: is presented, so there is no contradiction at all.

original: karaṇamantrāḥ kriyamāṇānuvādinaḥ stotraśastrarūpā japādiṣu viniyuktāś ca prakaraṇapathitāś
analyzed: karaṇa mantrāḥ kriyamāṇa anuvādinaḥ stotra śastra rūpāḥ japa ādiṣu viniyuktāḥ ca prakaraṇa pathitāḥ
translated: The mantras used as instruments, which are restatements of what is being done, which are in the form of hymns and prayers, which are employed in japa and other rituals, which are recited in the context,

original: cāprakaraṇapathitāś ca svārthaṃ sarvaṃ yathāvasthitam evāprāptam aviruddhaṃ brāhmaṇavad
analyzed: ca a prakaraṇa pathitāḥ ca sva artham sarvam yathā avasthitam eva a prāptam a viruddham brāhmaṇa vat
translated: and which are not recited in the context, all their meaning, which is as it is, not obtained, and not contradictory, like the Brahmana,

original: bodhayantīti hi vaidikāḥ /🔽pragītamantrasādhyaguṇaguṇiabhimānaṃ stotram /
analyzed: bodhayanti iti hi vaidikāḥ  pragīta mantra sādhya guṇa guṇi abhimānam stotram
translated: they indeed enlighten, say the Vedantins.🔽A hymn is that which has as its purport the glorification of the qualities and the possessor of qualities accomplished by the recited mantras.

original: apragītamantrasādhyaguṇaguṇiniṣṭhaguṇābhidhānaṃ śastram /
analyzed: a pragīta mantra sādhya guṇa guṇi niṣṭha guṇa abhidhānam śastram
translated: A prayer is that which expresses the qualities belonging to the possessor of qualities accomplished by the unrecited mantras.

original: niyuktārthaprakāśanāṃ ca devatādiṣv aprāptāviruddhaguṇaviśeṣaprtipādanaṃ viniyogānuguṇam eva /
analyzed: niyukta artha prakāśanām ca devatā ādiṣu aprāpta aviruddha guṇa viśeṣa prtipādanam viniyoga anuguṇam eva
translated: And the presentation of the not obtained and not contradictory special qualities in the deities etc., which is the manifestation of the employed meaning, is indeed in accordance with the application.

original: neyaṃ śrutir muktajanaviṣayā /
analyzed: na iyam śrutiḥ mukta jana viṣayā
translated: This Vedic text is not about liberated souls.

original: teśāṃ sadādarśanānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: teśām sadā adarśana anupapatteḥ
translated: Because it is not possible for them to see it always.

original: napi muktapravāhaviṣayā /
analyzed: mukta pravāha viṣayā
translated: Nor is it about the stream of liberated souls.

original: sadā paśyantīty ekaikakartṛkaviṣayatayā pratīteḥ śrutibhaṅgaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sadā paśyanti iti ekaika kartṛka viṣayatayā pratīteḥ śruti bhaṅga prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it is understood to refer to each individual soul, and if it referred to the stream of liberated souls, the Vedic text would be split.

original: mantrārthavādagatā hy arthāḥ kāryaparatve 'pi siddhyantītyuktam /
analyzed: mantra arthavāda gatāḥ hi arthāḥ kārya paratve
translated: It has been said that the meanings found in mantras and arthavadas are established even when they have a purpose to be accomplished.

original: kiṃ punaḥ siddhavastuny eva tātparye vyutpattisiddha iti sarvam upapannam /
analyzed: kim punar siddha vastuni eva tātparye vyutpatti siddhe iti sarvam upapannam
translated: Moreover, when the purpose is only about an established thing, the derivation of the meaning is established. Thus everything is reasonable.

original: nanu cātra tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padam iti parasvarūpam eva paramapadaśabdenābhidhīyate /
analyzed: nanu ca atra tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam iti para svarūpam eva parama pada śabdena abhidhīyate
translated: But here, in the phrase that is the supreme abode of Vishnu, the supreme nature itself is referred to by the word supreme abode.

original: samastaheyarahitaṃ viṣṇvākhyaṃ paraṃ padam ityādiṣv avyatirekadarśanāt /
analyzed: samasta heya rahitam viṣṇu ākhyam param padam ityādiṣu avyatireka darśanāt
translated: Because in passages such as the supreme abode called Vishnu, free from all that is to be discarded, non-difference is seen.

original: naivam /
analyzed: na evam
translated: It is not so.

original: kṣayantam asya rajataḥ parāke /🔽tadakṣare parame vyoman /
analyzed: kṣayantam asya rajataḥ parāke  tad akṣare parame vyoman
translated: His glory diminishes in the distance.🔽In that imperishable, supreme heaven.

original: yo asyādhyākṣaḥ parame vyoman /
analyzed: yaḥ asya adhi akṣaḥ parame vyoman
translated: He who is the overseer of this, in the supreme heaven.

original: yo veda nihitaṃ guhāyāṃ parame vyoman nityādiṣu paramasthānasyaiva darśanam /
analyzed: yaḥ veda nihitam guhāyām parame vyoman nitya ādiṣu parama sthānasya eva darśanam
translated: He who knows what is hidden in the cave, in the supreme heaven, in passages such as eternal, the supreme abode itself is seen.

original: tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padam iti vyatirekanirdeśāc ca /
analyzed: tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam iti vyatireka nirdeśāt ca
translated: And because in the phrase that is the supreme abode of Vishnu, difference is indicated.

original: viṣṇvākhyaṃ paramaṃ padam iti viśeṣaṇād anyad api paramaṃ padaṃ vidyata iti ca tenaiva jñāyate /
analyzed: viṣṇu ākhyam paramam padam iti viśeṣaṇāt anyat api paramam padam vidyate iti ca tena eva jñāyate
translated: And from the qualification the highest state called Viṣṇu, it is understood by that [statement] itself that there is another highest state.

original: tad idaṃ parasthānaṃ sūribhiḥ sadādṛśyatvena pratipādyate /
analyzed: tat idam para sthānam sūribhiḥ sadā adṛśya tvena pratipādyate
translated: This highest place is taught by the wise as always being unmanifest.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati kvacitparasthānaṃ paramapadaśabdena pratipādyate /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati kvacid para sthānam parama pada śabdena pratipādyate
translated: This is what is said: In some places, the highest place is taught by the word highest state.

original: kvacitprakṛtiviyuktātmasvarūpaṃ /
analyzed: kvacid prakṛti viyukta ātma svarūpam
translated: In some places, it is the nature of the self separated from prakṛti.

original: kvacidbhagavatsvarūpam /
analyzed: kvacid bhagavat svarūpam
translated: In some places, it is the nature of the Lord.

original: tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padaṃ sadā paśyanti sūraya iti parasthānam /
analyzed: tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ iti para sthānam
translated: The wise always see that highest state of Viṣṇu. This is the highest place.

original: sargasthityantakāleṣu trividhaiva pravartate /
analyzed: sarga sthiti anta kāleṣu trividhā eva pravartate
translated: It operates in three ways at the times of creation, maintenance, and dissolution.

original: guṇapravṛttyā paramaṃ padaṃ tasyāguṇaṃ mahat //
analyzed: guṇa pravṛttyā paramam padam tasya aguṇam mahat
translated: The highest state of that [prakṛti] is the great one devoid of qualities due to the activity of the qualities.

original: ityatra prakṛtiviyuktātmasvarūpam /
analyzed: iti atra prakṛti viyukta ātma svarūpam
translated: Here, it is the nature of the self separated from prakṛti.

original: samastaheyarahitaṃ viṣṇvākhyaṃ paramaṃ padam /
analyzed: samasta heya rahitam viṣṇu ākhyam paramam padam
translated: Devoid of all that is to be abandoned, it is the highest state called Viṣṇu.

original: ityatra bhagavatsvarūpam /🔽trīṇy apy etāni paramaprāptatvena paramapadaśabdena pratipādyante /
analyzed: iti atra bhagavat svarūpam  trīṇi api etāni parama prāpta tvena parama pada śabdena pratipādyante
translated: Here, it is the nature of the Lord.🔽All these three are taught by the word highest state as the highest attainment.

original: kathaṃ trayāṇāṃ paramaprāpyatvam iti cet /
analyzed: katham trayāṇām parama prāpya tvam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how the three are the highest attainment,

original: bhagavatsvarūpaṃ paramaprāpyatvād eva paramaṃ padam /
translated: The nature of the Lord is the supreme goal itself, because it is the highest attainment.

original: itarayor api bhagavatprāptigarbhatvād eva paramapadatvam /
translated: Even the other two are the supreme goal, because they are essentially the attainment of the Lord.

original: sarvakarmabandhavinirmuktātmasvarūpāvāptir bhagavatprāptigarbhā /
translated: The attainment of the nature of the self, which is free from all bondage of action, is essentially the attainment of the Lord.

original: ta ime satyāḥ kāmā anṛtāpidhānā iti bhagavato guṇagaṇasya tirodhāyakatvenānṛtaśabdena svakarmaṇaḥ pratipādanam /
analyzed: te ime satyāḥ kāmāḥ anṛta apidhānāḥ iti bhagavataḥ guṇa gaṇasya tirodhāyaka tvena anṛta śabdena sva karmaṇaḥ pratipādanam
translated: These desires are true, but are covered by untruth. The word 'untruth' refers to one's own action, as it obscures the multitude of qualities of the Lord.

original: anṛtarūpatirodhānaṃ kṣetrajñakarmeti katham avagamyata iti cet /
analyzed: anṛta rūpa tirodhānam kṣetrajña karma iti katham avagamyate iti ced
translated: If it is asked how it is understood that the concealment of the form of untruth is the action of the knower of the field,

original: avidyā karmasaṃjñānyā tṛtīyā śaktir iṣyate /
analyzed: avidyā karma saṃjñā anyā tṛtīyā śaktiḥ iṣyate
translated: It is accepted that the third power is called ignorance and action.

original: yathā kṣetrajñaśaktiḥ sā veṣṭitā nṛpa sarvagā //
analyzed: yathā kṣetrajña śaktiḥ sā veṣṭitā nṛpa sarvagā
translated: O king, that power of the knower of the field is enveloped, yet all-pervading.

original: saṃsāratāpān akhilān avāpnoty atisaṃtatān /
analyzed: saṃsāra tāpān akhilān avāpnoti ati saṃtatān
translated: One attains all the torments of worldly existence, which are extremely intense,

original: tayā tirohitatvāc ca
analyzed: tayā tirohita tvāt ca
translated: And because of being concealed by that,

original: ityādivacanāt /
analyzed: iti ādi vacanāt
translated: As stated in such passages.

original: parasthānaprāptir api bhagavatprāptigarbhaiveti suvyaktam /
analyzed: para sthāna prāptiḥ api bhagavat prāpti garbhā evā iti su vyaktam
translated: The attainment of the supreme abode is also clearly essentially the attainment of the Lord.

original: kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parāka iti rajataḥśabdena triguṇātmikā prakṛtir ucyate kevalasya rajaso 'navasthānāt /
analyzed: kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parākaḥ iti rajataḥśabdena triguṇa ātmikā prakṛtiḥ ucyate kevalasya rajasaḥ nava sthānāt
translated: The destruction of this rajas is the highest. The word 'rajas' refers to primordial matter, which consists of the three qualities, because mere rajas does not persist.

original: imāṃ triguṇātmikāṃ prakṛtim atikramya sthite sthāne kṣayantam vasantam ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: imām triguṇa ātmikām prakṛtim atikramya sthite sthāne kṣayantam vasantam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he abides in the place beyond this Nature consisting of the three qualities.

original: anena triguṇātmakāt kṣetrajñasya bhogyabhūtād vastunaḥ parastād viṣṇor vāsasthānam iti gamyate /🔽vedāham etaṃ
analyzed: anena triguṇa ātmakāt kṣetrajñasya bhogya bhūtāt vastunaḥ parastāt viṣṇoḥ vāsa sthānam iti gamyate  veda aham etam
translated: By this it is understood that Vishnu's abode is beyond the object which is the experiencer of the three qualities.🔽I know this great Person, having the color of the sun, beyond darkness.

original: puruṣaṃ mahāntam ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastād ityatrāpi tamaḥśabdena saiva prakṛtir ucyate /
analyzed: puruṣam mahāntam āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt iti atra api tamaḥ śabdena sā eva prakṛtiḥ ucyate
translated: Here also, that very Nature is referred to by the word darkness.

original: kevalasya tamaso 'navasthānād eva /
analyzed: kevalasya tamasaḥ nava sthānāt eva
translated: Because mere darkness does not endure.

original: rajasaḥ parāke kṣayantam ityanenaikavākyatvāt tamasaḥ parastād vasantaṃ mahāntam ādityavarṇaṃ puruṣam ahaṃ vedety ayam artho 'vagamyate /
analyzed: rajasaḥ parāke kṣayantam iti anena ekavākyatvāt tamasaḥ parastāt vasantam mahāntam āditya varṇam puruṣam aham veda iti ayam arthaḥ vagamyate
translated: By the connection in one sentence with abiding beyond passion, the meaning I know the great Person, having the color of the sun, abiding beyond darkness is understood.

original: satyaṃ jñānam anantaṃ brahma /
analyzed: satyam jñānam anantam brahma
translated: Truth, knowledge, infinite Brahman.

original: yo veda nihitaṃ guhāyāṃ parame vyoman /
analyzed: yaḥ veda nihitam guhāyām parame vyoman
translated: He who knows what is hidden in the cave, in the highest heaven.

original: tadakṣare parame vyomann iti tatsthānam avikārarūpaṃ paramavyomaśabdābhidheyam iti ca gamyate /
analyzed: tad akṣare parame vyoman iti tat sthānam avikāra rūpam parama vyoma śabda abhidheyam iti ca gamyate
translated: It is understood that its abode is referred to by the word highest heaven, which means unchanging form.

original: akṣare parame vyoman nityasya sthānasyākṣaratvaśravaṇāt kṣararūpādityamaṇḍalādayo na paramavyomaśabdābhidheyāḥ /
analyzed: akṣare parame vyoman nityasya sthānasya akṣara tva śravaṇāt kṣara rūpa āditya maṇḍala ādayaḥ na parama vyoma śabda abhidheyāḥ
translated: In the highest imperishable heaven, because the abode of the eternal is heard to be imperishable, the sun-disk etc. in the form of perishable things are not denoted by the word 'highest heaven'.

original: yatra pūrve sādhyāḥ santi devāḥ /
analyzed: yatra pūrve sādhyāḥ santi devāḥ
translated: Where the gods who are to be accomplished dwell.

original: yatra rṣayaḥ prathamajā ye purāṇā ityādiṣu ca ta eva sūraya ity avagamyate /
analyzed: yatra ṛṣayaḥ prathama jāḥ ye purāṇāḥ ityādiṣu ca te eva sūrayaḥ iti avagamyate
translated: And in passages such as 'where the sages, the first-born, the ancient ones', it is understood that they are the same sages.

original: tadviprāso vipanyavo jāgṛvāṃsaḥ samindhate viṣṇor yatparaṃ padam ityatrāpi viprāso medhāvinaḥ /
analyzed: tat viprāsaḥ vipanyavaḥ jāgṛvāṃsaḥ samindhate viṣṇoḥ yat param padam iti atra api viprāsaḥ medhāvinaḥ
translated: Even here, in 'the wise, the discerning, the watchful ones kindle the highest abode of Vishnu', the wise ones are the intelligent ones.

original: vipanyavaḥ stutiśīlāḥ /
analyzed: vipanyavaḥ stuti śīlāḥ
translated: The discerning ones are those who are inclined to praise.

original: jāgṛvāṃsaḥ askhalitajñānās ta evāskhalitajñānās tadviṣṇoḥ paramaṃ padaṃ sadā stuvantaḥ samindhata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: jāgṛvāṃsaḥ askhalita jñānāḥ te eva askhalita jñānāḥ tat viṣṇoḥ paramam padam sadā stuvantaḥ samindhate iti arthaḥ  /
translated: The watchful ones are those whose knowledge is unerring. The meaning is that they, whose knowledge is unerring, always praise and kindle the highest abode of Vishnu.

original: eteṣāṃ parijanasthānādīnāṃ sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ityatra jñānabalāiśvaryādikalyāṇaguṇagaṇavatparabrahmasvarūpāntarbhūtatvāt
analyzed: eteṣām parijana sthāna ādīnām sat eva somya idam agre āsīt iti atra jñāna bala aiśvarya ādi kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇavat para brahma svarūpa antarbhūta tvāt
translated: Of these attendants, abodes, etc., it is understood that they are included within Brahman, because they are included within the nature of the highest Brahman, which possesses the multitude of auspicious qualities such as knowledge, power, lordship, etc., in the passage 'This world, O dear one, existed in the beginning as Being alone'.

original: sad evaikam evādvitīyam iti brahmāntarbhāvo 'vagamyate /
analyzed: sat eva ekam eva advitīyam iti brahma antarbhāvaḥ vagamyate
translated: It is understood that they are included within Brahman, as 'Being alone, one, without a second'.

original: eṣām api kalyāṇaguṇaikadeśatvād eva sad eva somyedam agra āsīd ity atredam iti śabdasya🔽karmavaśyabhoktṛvargamiśratadbhogyabhūtaprapañcaviṣayatvāc ca sadā paśyanti sūraya🔽iti sadādarśitvena ca teṣāṃ karmavaśyānantarbhāvāt /
analyzed: eṣām api kalyāṇa guṇa eka deśa tvāt eva sat eva somya idam agre āsīt iti atra idam iti śabdasya  karma vaśya bhoktṛ varga miśra tad bhogya bhūta prapañca viṣaya tvāt ca sadā paśyanti sūraya  iti sat ādarśi tvena ca teṣām karma vaśyā anantarbhāvāt
translated: And because these also are only a part of the good qualities, therefore, in the passage, 'This was indeed existent in the beginning, as Sat' (Ch. 6.2.1), the word 'this'🔽And because the wise always see it,🔽because they are not included among those who are subject to the fruits of their actions, by virtue of their being shown as Sat.

original: apahatapāpmetyādy apipāsa ityantena salīlopakaraṇabhūtatriguṇaprakṛtiprākṛtatatsaṃsṛṣṭapuruṣagataṃ
analyzed: apahata pāpmā ityādi apipāsaḥ iti antena salīla upakaraṇa bhūta triguṇa prakṛti prākṛta tad saṃsṛṣṭa puruṣa gatam
translated: By the passage beginning with 'free from evil' and ending with 'free from thirst', all that is to be abandoned, which is in the three qualities of Prakṛti that are the instruments of play, in the Prakṛti that is the enjoyer, in the universe that is its object of enjoyment,🔽and in the Puruṣa that is mixed with that, is denied. By the phrase 'whose desires are true',

original: heyasvabhāvaṃ sarvaṃ pratiṣidhya satyakāma ityanena svabhogyabhogopakaraṇajātasya🔽sarvasya satyatā pratipāditā /
analyzed: heya svabhāvam sarvam pratiṣidhya satyakāmaḥ iti anena sva bhogya bhoga upakaraṇa jātasya  sarvasya satyatā pratipāditā
translated: the truth of all that is the object of one's own enjoyment and the instruments of enjoyment is taught.

original: asatyāḥ kāmā yasyāsau satyakāmaḥ /
analyzed: asatyāḥ kāmāḥ yasya asau satya kāmaḥ
translated: He whose desires are not false is one whose desires are true.

original: kāmyanta iti kāmāḥ /
analyzed: kāmyante iti kāmāḥ
translated: Desires are that which is desired.

original: tena pareṇa brahmaṇā svabhogyatadupakaraṇādayaḥ svābhimatā ye kāmyante te satyāḥ nityā ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tena pareṇa brahmaṇā sva bhogya tad upakaraṇa ādayaḥ sva abhimatāḥ ye kāmyante te satyāḥ nityāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Those desires that are desired by that Supreme Brahman as its own objects of enjoyment and instruments are true, eternal, is the meaning.

original: anyasya līlopakaraṇasyāpi vastunaḥ pramāṇasaṃbandhayogyatve saty api vikārāspadatvenāsthiratvād tadviparītaṃ sthiratvam eṣāṃ satyapadenocyate
analyzed: anyasya līlā upakaraṇasya api vastunaḥ pramāṇa saṃbandha yogya tve sati api vikāra āspada tvena asthira tvāt tad viparītam sthira tvam eṣām satya padena ucyate
translated: Even though other objects, which are mere playthings, are fit to be related to valid cognition, their stability is said to be the opposite of that, by the word 'sat', because they are the basis of modification and are unstable.

original: satyasaṃkalpa ityeteṣu bhogyatadupakaraṇādiṣu nityeṣu niratiśayeṣv ananteṣu satsvapyapūrvāṇām aparimitānām arthānām api saṃkalpamātreṇa siddhiṃ 🔽vadati /
analyzed: satya saṃkalpaḥ iti eteṣu bhogya tad upakaraṇa ādiṣu nityeṣu niratiśayeṣu ananteṣu satsu api apūrvāṇām aparimitānām arthānām api saṃkalpa mātreṇa siddhim  vadati
translated: He declares the accomplishment of even unlimited objects by mere resolve, in the case of these eternal, unsurpassed, infinite realities, which are the objects of enjoyment and their instruments, etc.

original: eṣāṃ ca bhogopakaraṇānāṃ līlopakaraṇānāṃ cetanānām acetanānāṃ sthirāṇām asthirāṇām ca tatsaṃkalpāyattasvarūpasthitipravṛttibhedādi sarvaṃ vāti
analyzed: eṣām ca bhoga upakaraṇānām līlā upakaraṇānām cetanānām acetanānām sthirāṇām asthirāṇām ca tad saṃkalpa āyatta svarūpa sthiti pravṛtti bheda ādi sarvam vāti  /
translated: And of these instruments of enjoyment and play, whether sentient or insentient, stable or unstable, everything such as the difference in their nature, existence, and activity, depends on his resolve.

original: satyasaṃkalpa iti /
analyzed: satya saṃkalpaḥ iti
translated: This is what is meant by 'satya-saṃkalpa'.

original: itihāsapurāṇayor vedopabṛṃhaṇayoś cāyam artha ucyate
analyzed: itihāsa purāṇayoḥ veda upabṛṃhaṇayoḥ ca ayam arthaḥ ucyate
translated: This meaning is stated in the Itihāsas and Purāṇas, which are supplements to the Vedas.

original: tau te medhāvinau dṛṣṭvā vedeṣu pariniṣṭhitau /
analyzed: tau te medhāvinau dṛṣṭvā vedeṣu pariniṣṭhitau
translated: Having seen those two intelligent ones perfected in the Vedas,

original: vedopabṛṃhaṇārthāya tāv agrāhayata prabhuḥ //
analyzed: veda upabṛṃhaṇa arthāya tau agrāhayata prabhuḥ
translated: the Lord made them grasp the Itihāsas and Purāṇas for the purpose of supplementing the Vedas.

original: iti vedopabṛṃhaṇatayā prārabdhe śrīmadrāmāyaṇe
analyzed: iti veda upabṛṃhaṇa tayā prārabdhe śrīmat rāmāyaṇe
translated: In the glorious Rāmāyaṇa, which was begun as a supplement to the Vedas,

original: vyaktam eṣa mahāyogī paramātmā sanātanaḥ /
analyzed: vyaktam eṣa mahā yogī parama ātmā sanātanaḥ
translated: It is clear that this is the great yogi, the supreme self, the eternal one.

original: anādimadhyanidhano mahataḥ paramo mahān //
analyzed: an ādi madhya nidhanaḥ mahataḥ paramaḥ mahān
translated: Without beginning, middle, or end, greater than the great,

original: tamasaḥ paramo dhātā śaṅkhacakragadādharaḥ /
analyzed: tamasaḥ paramaḥ dhātā śaṅkha cakra gadā dharaḥ
translated: The supreme creator beyond darkness, holding a conch, discus, and club,

original: śrīvatsavakṣā nityaśrīr ajayyaḥ śāśvato dhruvaḥ //
translated: With the mark of Śrīvatsa on the chest, eternally glorious, unconquerable, eternal, and stable.

original: śārā nānāvidhāś cāpi dhanur āyatavigraham /
analyzed: śārāḥ nānāvidhāḥ ca api dhanuḥ āyata vigraham
translated: Various kinds of arrows and a bow with an extended body

original: anvagacchanta kākutsthaṃ sarve puruṣavigrahāḥ //
analyzed: anvagacchanta kākutstham sarve puruṣa vigrahāḥ
translated: Followed Kakutstha, all in the form of men.

original: viveśa vaiṣṇavaṃ tejaḥ saśarīraḥ sahānugaḥ //
analyzed: viveśa vaiṣṇavam tejaḥ sa śarīraḥ saha anugaḥ
translated: With his body and followers, he entered the radiance of Vishnu.

original: śrīmadvaiṣṇavapurāṇe
translated: In the glorious Vaishnava Purana

original: samastāḥ śaktayaś caitā nṛpa yatra pratiṣṭhitāḥ /
analyzed: samastāḥ śaktayaḥ ca etāḥ nṛpa yatra pratiṣṭhitāḥ
translated: O king, all these powers are established there,

original: tadviśvairūpyaṃ rūpam antyaddharer mahat //
analyzed: tat viśvairūpyam rūpam antyat hareḥ mahat
translated: That is the supreme form of Hari, the great one, with the universe as its form.

original: mūrtaṃ brahma mahābhāga sarvabrahmamayo hariḥ //
analyzed: mūrtam brahma mahābhāga sarva brahma mayaḥ hariḥ
translated: O greatly fortunate one, Hari, the embodied Brahman, is full of all Brahman.

original: nityaivaiṣā jaganmātā viṣṇoḥ śrīr anapāyinī /
analyzed: nityā eva eṣā jaganmātā viṣṇoḥ śrīḥ anapāyinī
translated: This eternal mother of the world, Shri of Vishnu, is never absent.

original: yathā sarvagato viṣṇus tathaiveyaṃ dvijottama //
analyzed: yathā sarva gataḥ viṣṇuḥ tathā evā iyam dvijottama
translated: O best of Brahmins, just as Vishnu is all-pervading, so is she.

original: devatve devadeheyaṃ manuṣyatve ca mānuṣī /
analyzed: deva tve deva dehā iyam manuṣya tve ca mānuṣī
translated: In divinity, she has a divine body; in humanity, a human form.

original: viṣṇor dehānurūpāṃ vai karoty eṣātmanas tanum //
analyzed: viṣṇoḥ deha anurūpām vai karoti eṣā ātmanaḥ tanum
translated: She assumes a form for herself in accordance with Vishnu's body.

original: ekāntinaḥ sadā brahmadhyāyino yogino hi ye /
analyzed: ekāntinaḥ sadā brahma dhyāyinaḥ yoginaḥ hi ye
translated: Those who are one-pointed, always meditating on Brahman, and yogis,

original: teṣāṃ tatparaṃ sthānaṃ yad vai paśyanti sūrayaḥ //
analyzed: teṣām tat param sthānam yat vai paśyanti sūrayaḥ
translated: That is their supreme abode, which the wise ones see.

original: kalāmuhūrtādimayaś ca kālo na yadvibhūteḥ pariṇāmahetuḥ //
analyzed: kalā muhūrta ādi mayaḥ ca kālaḥ na yad vibhūteḥ pariṇāma hetuḥ
translated: And time consisting of kalās, muhūrtas, etc. is not the cause of transformation of His manifestation.

original: mahābhārate ca
analyzed: mahābhārate ca
translated: And in the Mahābhārata:

original: divyaṃ sthānam ajaraṃ cāprameyaṃ durvijñeya /
analyzed: divyam sthānam ajaram ca aprameyam durvijñeya
translated: The divine abode, which is ageless, immeasurable, difficult to know,

original: cāgamair gamyamādyam /
analyzed: ca āgamaiḥ gamyam ādyam
translated: and is to be reached by means of the Vedas.

original: gaccha prabho rakṣa cāsmān prapannān kalpe kalpe jāyamānaḥ svamūrtyā //
analyzed: gaccha prabho rakṣa ca asmān prapannān kalpe kalpe jāyamānaḥ sva mūrtyā
translated: Go, O Lord, and protect us who have taken refuge in you, being born in your own form in every kalpa.

original: kālaḥ sa pacate tatra na kālas tatra vai prabhuḥ /
analyzed: kālaḥ sa pacate tatra na kālaḥ tatra vai prabhuḥ
translated: Time cooks there, but time is not the master there.

original: iti / parasya brahmaṇo rūpavattvaṃ sūtrakāraś ca vadati antas taddharmopadeśād iti
analyzed: iti parasya brahmaṇaḥ rūpavat tvam sūtrakāraḥ ca vadati antar tad dharma upadeśāt iti
translated: Thus. And the author of the aphorisms says that the supreme Brahman has form: Because of the teaching of its attributes within.

original: yo 'sāv ādityamaṇḍalāntarvartī taptakārtasvaragirivaraprabhaḥ sahasrāṃśuśatasahasrakiraṇo🔽gambhīrāmbhaḥsamudbhūtasumṛṣṭanālavikaravikasitapuṇḍarīkadalāmalāyatekṣaṇaḥ subhrūlalāṭaḥ
analyzed: sau āditya maṇḍala antarvartī tapta kārtasvara giri vara prabhaḥ sahasra aṃśu śata sahasra kiraṇaḥ  gambhīra ambhaḥ samudbhūta sumṛṣṭa nāla vikara vikasita puṇḍarīka dala amala āyata īkṣaṇaḥ su bhrū lalāṭaḥ
translated: He who dwells within the orb of the sun, with the splendor of the best of heated gold mountains, with a thousand million rays,🔽with eyes as pure as the petals of a fully blossomed white lotus rising from deep water, with beautiful eyebrows and forehead,🔽with a fine nose, with lips as red as coral and a beautiful smile, with cheeks that are very lovely and smooth, with a neck like a conch, with shoulders that are raised and adorned with beautiful divine ear-lobes that hang down,

original: sunāsaḥ susmitādharavidrumaḥ surucirakomalagaṇḍaḥ kambugrīvaḥ samunnatāṃsavilambicārurūpadivyakarṇakisalayaḥ
analyzed: su nāsaḥ su smita adhara vidrumaḥ su rucira komala gaṇḍaḥ kambu grīvaḥ samunnata aṃsa vilambi cāru rūpa divya karṇa kisalayaḥ
translated: with a chest that is broad and firm like the yoke of a strong chariot, with arms that are long and thick like the trunk of an elephant, with fingers and toes that are long, copper-colored, and beautiful, with a body that is well-proportioned and straight, with knees that are long and beautiful, with feet that are well-formed and have prominent heels,

original: pīnavṛttāyatabhujaś cārutarātamrakaratalānuraktāṅgulībhir alaṃkṛtas tanumadhyo viśālavakṣaḥsthalaḥ🔽samavibhaktasarvāṅgo 'nirdeśyadivyarūpasaṃhananaḥ snigdhavarṇaḥ prabuddhapuṇḍarīkacārucaraṇayugalaḥ🔽svānurūpapītāmbaradho 'malakirīṭakuṇḍalahārakaustubhakeyūrakaṭakanūpurodarabandhanādyaparimitāścaryānantadivyabhūṣaṇaḥ
analyzed: pīna vṛtta āyata bhujaḥ cārutara ātamra kara tala anurakta aṅgulībhiḥ alaṃkṛtaḥ tanu madhyaḥ viśāla vakṣaḥ sthalaḥ  sama vibhakta sarva aṅgaḥ nirdeśya divya rūpa saṃhananaḥ snigdha varṇaḥ prabuddha puṇḍarīka cāru caraṇa yugalaḥ  sva anurūpa pīta ambara dhaḥ mala kirīṭa kuṇḍala hāra kaustubha keyūra kaṭaka nūpura udara bandhana ādi aparimita āścarya ananta divya bhūṣaṇaḥ
translated: He had full, round, long arms, adorned with fingers of a more beautiful reddish hue, a slender waist, and a broad chest.🔽His entire body was well-proportioned, his divine form was indescribable, his complexion was smooth, and his two feet were as beautiful as a fully bloomed lotus.🔽He wore appropriate yellow garments, a spotless crown, earrings, necklaces, Kaustubha jewel, armlets, bracelets, anklets, and a chest ornament, and was adorned with countless other divine and wondrous ornaments.

original: śaṅkhacakragadāsiśrīvatsavanamālālaṅkṛto 'navadhikātiśayasaundaryāhṛtāśeṣamanodṛṣṭivṛttir🔽lāvaṇyāmṛtapūritāśeṣacarācarabhūtajāto 'tyadbhutācintyanityayauvanaḥ puṣpahāsasukumāraḥ
analyzed: śaṅkha cakra gadā asi śrīvatsa vanamālā alaṅkṛtaḥ nava adhika atiśaya saundarya āhṛta aśeṣa manaḥ dṛṣṭi vṛttiḥ  lāvaṇya amṛta pūrita aśeṣa carācara bhūta jātaḥ tyadbhuta acintya nitya yauvanaḥ puṣpa hāsa sukumāraḥ
translated: He was adorned with the conch, discus, mace, sword, Shrivatsa mark, and garland of wood-flowers, and his entire form was so captivating that it stole away the attention of all beings.🔽He was filled with the nectar of beauty, and all moving and unmoving beings were filled with it. He was extremely wondrous, inconceivable, and eternally youthful, with a gentle smile.

original: puṇyagandhavāsitānantadigantarālas trailokyākramaṇapravṛttagambhīrabhāvaḥ karuṇānurāgamadhuralocanāvalokitāśritavargaḥ
analyzed: puṇya gandha vāsita ananta diś antarālaḥ trailokya ākramaṇa pravṛtta gambhīra bhāvaḥ karuṇa anurāga madhura locana avalokita āśrita vargaḥ
translated: The space between his eyebrows was filled with the fragrance of merit, and his deep nature was engaged in conquering the three worlds. He looked at those who had taken refuge with eyes of compassion and affection.

original: puruṣavaro darīdṛśyate /
analyzed: puruṣa varaḥ darīdṛśyate
translated: The best of men was seen.

original: sa ca nikhilajagadudayavibhavalayalīlo nirastasamastaheyaḥ samastakalyāṇaguṇagaṇanidhiḥ svetarasamastavastuvilakṣaṇaḥ paramātmā paraṃ brahma
analyzed: sa ca nikhila jagat udaya vibhava laya līlaḥ nirasta samasta heyaḥ samasta kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa nidhiḥ sva itara samasta vastu vilakṣaṇaḥ paramātmā param brahma
translated: And He, who is the sport of the creation, sustenance, and dissolution of the entire world, who has removed all that is to be shunned, who is the treasure of all auspicious qualities, who is unlike all other things, is the Supreme Self, the Supreme Brahman,

original: nārāyaṇa ity avagamyate /
analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ iti avagamyate
translated: is understood to be Narayana.

original: taddharmopadeśāt sa eṣa sarveṣāṃ lokānām īṣṭe sarveṣāṃ kāmānām sa eṣa sarvebhyaḥ pāpabhya udita ityādidarśanāt /
analyzed: tad dharma upadeśāt saḥ eṣa sarveṣām lokānām īṣṭe sarveṣām kāmānām saḥ eṣa sarvebhyaḥ pāpabhyaḥ uditaḥ ityādi darśanāt
translated: Because His qualities are taught - because of such statements as He is the Lord of all worlds, the fulfiller of all desires, He is risen above all sins and so on.

original: tasyaite guṇāḥ sarvasya vaśī sarvasyeśānaḥ apahatapāpmā vijara ityādi satyasaṃkalpa ityantam viśvataḥ paramaṃ nityaṃ viśvaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ harim
analyzed: tasya ete guṇāḥ sarvasya vaśī sarvasya īśānaḥ apahata pāpmā vijaraḥ ityādi satya saṃkalpaḥ ityantam viśvatas paramam nityam viśvam nārāyaṇam harim
translated: His qualities are stated in the passages beginning with He is the controller of all, the Lord of all, free from sin, without old age up to His resolve is true, The Supreme, eternal, all-pervading, all, Narayana, Hari,

original: patiṃ viśvasyātmeśvaram ityādivākyapratipāditāḥ /
analyzed: patim viśvasya ātma īśvaram ityādi vākya pratipāditāḥ
translated: The Lord of the universe, the Self, the Lord and so on.

original: vākyakāraiś caitatsarvaṃ suspaṣṭam āha hiraṇyamayaḥ puruṣo dṛśyata iti prājñaḥ sarvāntaraḥ syāl lokakāmeśopadeśāt tathodayāt pāpmanām ityādinā
analyzed: vākya kāraiḥ ca etat sarvam su spaṣṭam āha hiraṇya mayaḥ puruṣaḥ dṛśyate iti prājñaḥ sarva antaraḥ syāt loka kāma īśa upadeśāt tathā udayāt pāpmanām ityādinā
translated: And all this is stated very clearly by the authors of the Brahmasutras in such statements as The golden person is seen, The wise one should be considered as within all, Because He is taught as the Lord of the desires of the worlds, In the same way, because of the rising above sins and so on.

original: tasya ca rūpasyānityatādi vākyakāreṇaiva pratiṣiddham syāt tadrūpaṃ kṛtakam anugrahārthaṃ
analyzed: tasya ca rūpasya anitya tā ādi vākyakāreṇa eva pratiṣiddham syāt tat rūpam kṛtakam anugraha artham
translated: And the author of the aphorisms himself has refuted the impermanence, etc. of that form, that form would be created for the sake of favor.

original: taccetanānām aiśvaryād ity upāsitur anugrahārthaḥ paramapuruṣasya rūpasaṃgraha iti pūrvapakṣaṃ kṛtvā /
analyzed: tat cetanānām aiśvaryāt iti upāsituḥ anugraha arthaḥ paramapuruṣasya rūpa saṃgrahaḥ iti pūrvapakṣam kṛtvā
translated: And that is by the will of the intelligent ones, thus the form of the Supreme Person is for the sake of favoring the worshipper, having made this prima facie view,

original: rūpaṃ vātīndriyam antaḥkaraṇapratyakṣaṃ tannirdeśād iti /
analyzed: rūpam vā atīndriyam antaḥkaraṇa pratyakṣam tad nirdeśāt iti
translated: or the form is supersensible, perceptible by the internal organ, because it is indicated.

original: yathā jñānādayaḥ parasya brahmaṇaḥ svarūpatayā nirdeśāt svarūpabhūtaguṇās tathedam api rūpaṃ śrutyā svarūpatayā nirdeśāt svarūpabhūtam ityarthaḥ
analyzed: yathā jñāna ādayaḥ parasya brahmaṇaḥ sva rūpa tayā nirdeśāt sva rūpa bhūta guṇāḥ tathā idam api rūpam śrutyā sva rūpa tayā nirdeśāt sva rūpa bhūtam iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as knowledge and other qualities of the Supreme Brahman are inherent in its nature because they are indicated as its nature, so also this form is inherent in its nature because it is indicated as its nature by the scripture, this is the meaning.

original: bhāṣyakāreṇaitad vyākhyātam añjasaiva viśvasṛjo rūpaṃ tat tu na cakṣuṣā grāhyaṃ manasā tv akaluṣeṇa sādhanāntaravatā gṛhyate /
analyzed: bhāṣyakāreṇa etat vyākhyātam añjasā eva viśvasṛjaḥ rūpam tat tu na cakṣuṣā grāhyam manasā tu akaluṣeṇa sādhana antaravatā gṛhyate
translated: This has been explained by the commentator in a straightforward manner: That form of the creator of the universe is not perceptible by the eye, but is grasped by the untainted mind, along with other means.

original: na cakṣuṣā gṛhyate nāpi vācā manasā tu viśuddheneti śruteḥ /
analyzed: na cakṣuṣā gṛhyate na api vācā manasā tu viśuddhena iti śruteḥ
translated: It is not perceptible by the eye, nor by speech, but by the purified mind, according to the scripture.

original: na hy rūpāyā devatāyā rūpam upadiśyate /
analyzed: na hi rūpāyāḥ devatāyāḥ rūpam upadiśyate
translated: For the form of the deity is not taught as having form.

original: yathābhūtavādi hi śāstram /
analyzed: yathābhūtavādi hi śāstram
translated: For the scripture speaks the truth as it is.

original: mahārajanaṃ vāsaḥ vedāham etaṃ puruṣaṃ mahāntam ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastād iti prakaraṇāntaranirdeśāc ca sākṣiṇa ityādinā hiraṇyamaya iti
analyzed: mahārajanam vāsaḥ veda aham etam puruṣam mahāntam āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt iti prakaraṇa antara nirdeśāt ca sākṣiṇaḥ ityādinā hiraṇya mayaḥ iti  /
translated: The garment is dyed with the great lac, I know this person as great, having the color of the sun, beyond darkness, and because it is stated in a different context, as the witness, etc., as golden,

original: rūpasāmānyāc candramukhavat /
analyzed: rūpa sāmānyāt candra mukha vat
translated: and because of the similarity of form, like the moon-faced one.

original: na mayaḍ atra vikāram ādāya prayujyate /
analyzed: na mayaṭ atra vikāram ādāya prayujyate
translated: The suffix maya is not used here to denote a modification.

original: anārabhyatvād ātmana iti /🔽yathā jñānādikalyāṇaguṇagaṇānantaryanirdeśād aparimitakalyāṇaguṇagaṇaviśiṣṭaṃ paraṃ🔽brahmety avagamyata evam ādityavarṇaṃ puruṣam ityādinirdeśāt svābhimatasvānurūpakalyāṇatamarūpaḥ
analyzed: an ārabhya tvāt ātmanaḥ iti  yathā jñāna ādi kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa ānantarya nirdeśāt aparimita kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa viśiṣṭam param  brahma iti avagamyate evam āditya varṇam puruṣam ityādi nirdeśāt sva abhimata sva anurūpa kalyāṇatama rūpaḥ
translated: Because the self is not a modification.

original: parabrahmabhūtaḥ puruṣottamo nārāyaṇa iti jñāyate /
analyzed: para brahma bhūtaḥ puruṣottamaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ iti jñāyate
translated: Just as it is understood that the supreme Brahman is distinguished by immeasurable multitudes of auspicious qualities because of the statement immediately after the multitudes of auspicious qualities such as knowledge, in the same way, from the statement beginning the person having the color of the sun, it is known that the supreme person, Narayana, who is Brahman, is the most auspicious in form, suitable to himself.

original: tathāsyeśanā jagato viṣṇupatnī hrīś ca te lakṣmīś ca patnyau sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ
analyzed: tathā asya īśanā jagataḥ viṣṇu patnī hrīḥ ca te lakṣmīḥ ca patnyau sadā paśyanti sūrayaḥ
translated: Thus, his wife, the goddess of prosperity, is always seen by the wise, as Hri and Shri, the wives of Vishnu, the lord of the universe.

original: tamasaḥ parastāt kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parāka ityādinā patnīparijanasthānādīnāṃ
analyzed: tamasaḥ parastāt kṣayantam asya rajasaḥ parākaḥ ityādinā patnī parijana sthāna ādīnām
translated: And from the statement beginning beyond darkness, he is seen, beyond the end of the rajas, it is understood that the wives, attendants, abode, etc.

original: nirdeśād eva tathaiva santīty avagamyate /
analyzed: nirdeśāt eva tathā eva santi iti avagamyate
translated: exist in the same way.

original: yathāha bhāṣyakāra yathābhūtavādi hi śāstram iti / 🔽etaduktaṃ bhavati yathā satyaṃ jñānaṃ anantaṃ brahmeti nirdeśāt paramātmasvarūpaṃ
analyzed: yathā āha bhāṣyakāra yathābhūtavādi hi śāstram iti  etat uktam bhavati yathā satyam jñānam anantam brahma iti nirdeśāt paramātma svarūpam
translated: As the author of the Bhāṣya says: The Śāstra is a statement of what is as it is.🔽This is what is said: Just as the nature of the supreme self is different from all other things,

original: samastaheyapratyanīkānavadhikānantaikatānatayāparicchedyatayā ca sakaletaravilakṣaṇaṃ🔽tathā yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavit parāsya śaktir vividhaiva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñānabalakriyā🔽ca tam eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvaṃ tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhātītyādinirdeśān niratiśayāsaṃkhyeyāś
analyzed: samasta heya pratyanīka anavadhika ananta eka tāna tayā aparicchedya tayā ca sakala itara vilakṣaṇam  tathā yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva vid parā asya śaktiḥ vividhā eva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñāna bala kriyā  ca tam eva anubhāti sarvam tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti ityādi nirdeśāt niratiśaya asaṃkhyeyāḥ
translated: being indivisible, infinite, and of the nature of pure consciousness, as stated in the Upaniṣads,

original: ca guṇāḥ sakaletaravilakṣaṇāḥ /
analyzed: ca guṇāḥ sakala itara vilakṣaṇāḥ
translated: so also its qualities are of the same nature, being beyond all comparison and number, as stated in the Upaniṣads.

original: tathādityavarṇam ityādinirdeśād rūpaparijanasthānādayaś ca sakaletaravilakṣaṇāḥ svāsādhāraṇā anirdeśyasvarūpasvabhāvā iti /
analyzed: tathā āditya varṇam ityādi nirdeśāt rūpa parijana sthāna ādayaḥ ca sakala itara vilakṣaṇāḥ sva asādhāraṇāḥ anirdeśya svarūpa svabhāvāḥ iti
translated: Just as the Upaniṣads describe the form, retinue, abode, etc. of the supreme self as being different from all other things, as unique, and of an indescribable nature,

original: vedāḥ pramāṇaṃ ced vidhyarthavādamantragataṃ sarvam apūrvam aviruddham arthajātaṃ yathāvasthitam eva bodhayanti /
analyzed: vedāḥ pramāṇam ced vidhi arthavāda mantra gatam sarvam apūrvam aviruddham artha jātam yathā avasthitam eva bodhayanti
translated: so also the Vedas are the means of valid knowledge. If they were the means of valid knowledge, they would convey all the novel and non-contradictory meanings as they stand, whether in the form of injunctions, explanatory passages, or mantras.

original: prāmāṇyaṃ ca vedānām autpattikas tu śabdasyārthena saṃbandha ityuktam /
analyzed: prāmāṇyam ca vedānām autpattikaḥ tu śabdasya arthena saṃbandhaḥ iti uktam
translated: And the authoritativeness of the Vedas has been stated as being due to the eternal connection of words with their meanings.

original: yathāgnijalādīnām auṣṇyādiśaktiyogaḥ svābhāvikaḥ /
analyzed: yathā agni jala ādīnām auṣṇya ādi śakti yogaḥ svābhāvikaḥ
translated: Just as the possession of the power of heat, etc. by fire, water, etc. is natural,

original: yathā ca cakṣurādīnām indriyāṇāṃ buddhiviśeṣajanaśaktiḥ svābhāvikī tathā śabdasyāpi bodhanaśaktiḥ svābhāvikī /
analyzed: yathā ca cakṣuḥ ādīnām indriyāṇām buddhi viśeṣa jana śaktiḥ svābhāvikī tathā śabdasya api bodhana śaktiḥ svābhāvikī
translated: and just as the power of producing a particular cognition is natural in the sense organs like the eye, so also the power of conveying meaning in words is natural.

original: na ca hastaceṣṭādivat saṃketamūlaṃ śabdasya bodhakatvam iti vaktuṃ śakyam /
analyzed: na ca hasta ceṣṭā ādi vat saṃketa mūlam śabdasya bodhaka tvam iti vaktum śakyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the power of conveying meaning in words is based on convention, like the movement of the hand, etc.

original: anādyanusaṃdhānāvicchede 'pi saṃketayitṛpuruṣājñānāt /
analyzed: anādi anusaṃdhāna avicchede pi saṃketayitṛ puruṣa ajñānāt
translated: Because even when the unbroken continuity of beginningless association is present, the convention is not known due to the ignorance of the person who establishes the convention.

original: yāni saṃketamūlāni tāni sarvāṇi sākṣād vā paraṃparayā vā jñāyante /
analyzed: yāni saṃketa mūlāni tāni sarvāṇi sākṣāt vā paraṃparayā vā jñāyante
translated: All those things that are based on convention are known either directly or indirectly.

original: na ca devadattādiśabdavat kalpayituṃ yuktam /
analyzed: na ca devadatta ādi śabda vat kalpayitum yuktam
translated: And it cannot be reasonably imagined like the words Devadatta etc.

original: teṣu ca sākṣād vā paraṃparayā vā saṃketo jñāyate /
analyzed: teṣu ca sākṣāt vā paraṃparayā vā saṃketaḥ jñāyate
translated: And in those cases, the convention is known either directly or indirectly.

original: gavādiśabdānāṃ tv anādyanusaṃdhānāvicchede 'pi saṃketājñānād eva bodhakatvaśaktiḥ svābhāvikī /
analyzed: gavā ādi śabdānām tu anādi anusaṃdhāna avicchede pi saṃketa ajñānāt eva bodhaka tva śaktiḥ svābhāvikī
translated: But in the case of words like cow etc., even when the unbroken continuity of beginningless association is present, the power of conveying meaning is natural itself, because the convention is not known.

original: ato 'gnyādīnāṃ dāhakatvādiśaktivad indriyāṇāṃ bodhakatvaśaktivac ca śabdasyāpi bodhakatvaśaktir āśrayaṇīyā //
analyzed: atas gni ādīnām dāhaka tva ādi śakti vat indriyāṇām bodhaka tva śakti vat ca śabdasya api bodhaka tva śaktiḥ āśrayaṇīyā
translated: Therefore, just as the power of burning, etc. belongs to fire, etc., and the power of revealing belongs to the senses, so the power of revealing must be accepted to belong to words as well.

original: nanu cen indriyavac chabdasyāpi bodhakatvaṃ svābhāvikaṃ saṃbandhagrahaṇaṃ bodhakatvāya kim ity apekṣate /
analyzed: nanu ced indriya vat śabdasya api bodhaka tvam svābhāvikam saṃbandha grahaṇam bodhaka tvāya kim iti apekṣate
translated: If it is argued that just as the senses, so the power of revealing belongs to words by their very nature, and the apprehension of the relation is not required for the power of revealing,

original: liṅgādivad iti ucyate yathā jñātasaṃbandhaniyamaṃ dhūmādyagnyādivijñānajanakaṃ tathā jñātasaṃbandhaniyamaḥ śabdo 'py arthaviśeṣabuddhijanakaḥ
analyzed: liṅga ādi vat iti ucyate yathā jñāta saṃbandha niyamam dhūma ādi agni ādi vijñāna janakam tathā jñāta saṃbandha niyamaḥ śabdaḥ api artha viśeṣa buddhi janakaḥ
translated: it is said that just as smoke, etc., which are known to have a fixed relation, produce the knowledge of fire, etc., so a word, which is known to have a fixed relation, produces the knowledge of a particular meaning.

original: evaṃ tarhi śabdo 'py arthaviśeṣasya liṅgam ity anumānaṃ syāt naivam /
analyzed: evam tarhi artha viśeṣasya liṅgam iti anumānam syāt na evam
translated: If that is so, then a word would be an inference of a particular meaning. It is not so.

original: śabdārthayoḥ saṃbandho bodhyabodhkabhāva eva dhūmādīnāṃ tu saṃbandhāntara iti tasya saṃbandhasya jñānadvāreṇa buddhijanakatvam iti viśeṣaḥ
analyzed: śabda arthayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ bodhya bodhka bhāvaḥ eva dhūma ādīnām tu saṃbandha antare iti tasya saṃbandhasya jñāna dvāreṇa buddhi janaka tvam iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: The relation between a word and its meaning is only the relation of the revealer and the revealed. But the relation of smoke, etc., is different. Therefore, the power to produce knowledge is through the knowledge of that relation. This is the difference.

original: evaṃ gṛhītasaṃbandhasya bodhakatvadarśanād anādyanusaṃdhānāvicchede 'pi saṃketājñānād bodhakatvaśaktir eveti niścīyate /
analyzed: evam gṛhīta saṃbandhasya bodhaka tva darśanāt anādi anusaṃdhāna avicchede pi saṃketa ajñānāt bodhaka tva śaktiḥ evā iti niścīyate
translated: Thus, because the power of revealing is seen in one who has grasped the relation, even when the beginningless continuity of memory is uninterrupted, it is ascertained that the power of revealing is due only to the knowledge of the convention.

original: evaṃ bodhakānāṃ padasaṃghātānāṃ saṃsargaviśeṣabodhakatvena vākyaśabdābhidheyānām uccāraṇakramo yatra puruṣabuddhipūrvakas te pauruṣeyāḥ śabdā
analyzed: evam bodhakānām pada saṃghātānām saṃsarga viśeṣa bodhaka tvena vākya śabda abhidheyānām uccāraṇa kramaḥ yatra puruṣa buddhi pūrvakaḥ te pauruṣeyāḥ śabdāḥ
translated: Thus, those collections of words that are expressive, which are denoted by the word 'sentence' because they express a particular combination, and whose utterance sequence is preceded by human intellect, those are human words.

original: ity ucyante /
analyzed: iti ucyante
translated: Thus, those collections of words that are expressive, which are denoted by the word 'sentence' because they express a particular combination [of meanings], are said to be 'human words' when their utterance sequence is preceded by human intellect.

original: yatra tu taduccāraṇakramaḥ pūrvapūrvoccaraṇakramajanitasaṃskārapūrvakaḥ sarvadāpauruṣeyās te ca vedā ityucyante /
analyzed: yatra tu tad uccāraṇa kramaḥ pūrva pūrva uccaraṇa krama janita saṃskāra pūrvakaḥ sarvadā apauruṣeyāḥ te ca vedāḥ iti ucyante
translated: It is said that those [words] whose utterance sequence is preceded by the impressions produced by the sequence of previous utterances are always non-human, and they are called the Vedas.

original: etad eva vedānām apauruṣeyatvaṃ nityatvaṃ ca yatpūrvoccāraṇakramajanitasaṃskāreṇa tam eva kramaviśeṣaṃ smṛtvā tenaiva krameṇoccāryamāṇatvam
analyzed: etat eva vedānām apauruṣeya tvam nitya tvam ca yat pūrva uccāraṇa krama janita saṃskāreṇa tam eva krama viśeṣam smṛtvā tena eva krameṇa uccāryamāṇa tvam
translated: This alone is the non-human origin and eternality of the Vedas, that they are uttered in the same sequence by remembering that particular sequence produced by the impressions generated by the sequence of previous utterances.

original: te cānupūrvīviśeṣeṇa saṃsthitā akṣararāśayo vedā ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvabhedabhinnā anantaśākhā vartante /
analyzed: te ca ānupūrvī viśeṣeṇa saṃsthitāḥ akṣara rāśayaḥ vedāḥ ṛk yajuḥ sāma atharva bheda bhinnāḥ ananta śākhāḥ vartante
translated: And those collections of syllables arranged in a particular sequence, the Vedas divided into the Rg, Yajur, Sama and Atharva Vedas, exist with infinite branches.

original: te ca vidhyarthavādamantrarūpā vedāḥ parabrahmabhūtanārāyaṇasvarūpaṃ tadārādhanaprakārādhitāt phalaviśeṣaṃ ca bodhayanti /
analyzed: te ca vidhi arthavāda mantra rūpāḥ vedāḥ para brahma bhūta nārāyaṇa svarūpam tad ārādhana prakāra ādhitāt phala viśeṣam ca bodhayanti
translated: And those Vedas in the form of injunctions, explanatory passages and mantras reveal the form of Narayana who is the supreme Brahman, the way to worship Him, and the specific results of that worship.

original: paramapuruṣavat tatsvarūpatadārādhanatatphalajñāpakavedākhyaśabdajātaṃ nityam eva /
analyzed: parama puruṣa vat tad svarūpa tad ārādhana tad phala jñāpaka veda ākhya śabda jātam nityam eva
translated: The collection of words called the Vedas, which indicate the nature of the Supreme Person, His worship, and their fruits, are eternal, just like the Supreme Person Himself.

original: vedānām anantatvād duravagāhatvāc ca paramapuruṣaniyuktāḥ paramarṣayaḥ kalpe kalpe
analyzed: vedānām ananta tvāt duravagāha tvāt ca parama puruṣa niyuktāḥ parama ṛṣayaḥ kalpe kalpe
translated: Because the Vedas are infinite and difficult to comprehend, the great sages appointed by the Supreme Person, in each Kalpa age,

original: nikhilajagadupakārārthaṃ vedārthaṃ smṛtvā vidhyarthavādamantramūlāni dharmaśāstrāṇītihāsapurāṇāni ca cakruḥ /
analyzed: nikhila jagat upakāra artham veda artham smṛtvā vidhi arthavāda mantra mūlāni dharma śāstrāṇi itihāsa purāṇāni ca cakruḥ
translated: remember the meaning of the Vedas for the benefit of the entire world, and compose Dharma Shastras, Itihasas, and Puranas, based on injunctions, explanatory passages, and mantras.

original: laukikāś ca śabdā vedarāśer uddhṛtyaiva tattadarthaviśeṣanāmatayā pūrvavat prayuktāḥ pāraṃparyeṇa prayujyante /
analyzed: laukikāḥ ca śabdāḥ vedarāśeḥ uddhṛtya eva tad tad artha viśeṣa nāmatayā pūrvavat prayuktāḥ pāraṃparyeṇa prayujyante
translated: And worldly words are also used by derivation from the mass of Vedas, as specific names for those meanings, just as before, and are used by tradition.

original: nanu ca vaidika eva sarve vācakāḥ śabdāś cec chandasyaivaṃ bhāṣāyām evam iti lakṣaṇabhedaḥ katham upapadyate /
analyzed: nanu ca vaidike eva sarve vācakāḥ śabdāḥ ced chandasya evam bhāṣāyām evam iti lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ katham upapadyate
translated: But if all expressive words are Vedic only, how can the distinction of meter, language, and so on be justified?

original: ucyate teṣām eva śabdānāṃ tasyām evānupūrvyāṃ vartamānāṃ tathaiva prayogaḥ /
analyzed: ucyate teṣām eva śabdānām tasyām eva ānupūrvyām vartamānām tathā eva prayogaḥ
translated: It is said that the usage of those very words in that very sequence is just like that.

original: anyatra prayujyamānānām anyatheti na kaścid doṣaḥ /
analyzed: anyatra prayujyamānānām anyathā iti na kaścid doṣaḥ
translated: There is no fault in using them differently elsewhere.

original: evam itihāsapurāṇadharmaśāstropabṛṃhitasāṅgavedavedyaḥ parabrahmabhūto nārāyaṇo nikhilaheyapratyanīkaḥ
analyzed: evam itihāsa purāṇa dharma śāstra upabṛṃhita sāṅga veda vedyaḥ para brahma bhūtaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ nikhila heya pratyanīkaḥ
translated: Thus, Nārāyaṇa, who is the Supreme Brahman, who is known through the Vedas with their auxiliaries, which are expanded by Itihāsa, Purāṇa, and Dharmaśāstra, who is the counteragent to all that is to be abandoned,

original: sakaletaravilakṣaṇo 'paricchinnajñānānandaikasvarūpaḥ svābhāvikānavadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇagaṇākaraḥ
translated: who is unlike all others, whose nature is solely of unlimited and unmeasured knowledge and bliss, who is the source of the naturally unlimited and immeasurable multitudes of auspicious qualities,

original: svasaṃkalpānuvidhāyisvarūpasthitipravṛttibhedacidacidvastujāto 'paricchedyasvarūpasvabhāvānantamahāvibhūtir
analyzed: sva saṃkalpa anuvidhāyi svarūpa sthiti pravṛtti bheda cit acit vastu jātaḥ paricchedya sva rūpa svabhāva ananta mahā vibhūtiḥ
translated: whose infinite and great glory is of an unfathomable nature, whose manifold and unfathomable creation of conscious and unconscious beings is differentiated into the categories of existence, action, and quality, which are in accordance with His own will,

original: nānāvidhānantacetanācetanātmakaprapañcalīlopakaraṇa iti pratipāditam /
analyzed: nānāvidha ananta cetana acetana ātmaka prapañca līlā upakaraṇaḥ iti pratipāditam
translated: who is the instrument of the play of the manifold and infinite universe consisting of conscious and unconscious beings, has been established.

original: sarvaṃ khalv idaṃ brahma aitadātmyam idaṃ sarvaṃ tat tvam asi śvetaketo
analyzed: sarvam khalu idam brahma aitadātmyam idam sarvam tat tvam asi śvetaketo
translated: All this is indeed Brahman. All this has that as its Self. You are that, O Śvetaketu.

original: enam eke vadanty agniṃ maruto 'nyo prajāpatim /
analyzed: enam eke vadanti agnim marutaḥ prajāpatim
translated: Some call Him Agni, others the Maruts, still others Prajāpati.

original: indram eke pare prāṇam apare brahma śāśvatam //
analyzed: indram eke pare prāṇam apare brahma śāśvatam
translated: Some Indra, others the vital breath, and others the eternal Brahman.

original: jyotīṃṣi śuklāni ca yāni loke trayo lokā lokapālās trayī ca /
analyzed: jyotīṃṣi śuklāni ca yāni loke trayaḥ lokāḥ lokapālāḥ trayī ca
translated: The luminous white things in the world, the three worlds, the world guardians, the three Vedas,

original: trayo 'gnayaś cāhutayaś ca pañca sarve deva devakīputra eva //
analyzed: trayaḥ gnayaḥ ca āhutayaḥ ca pañca sarve deva devakīputre eva
translated: The three fires, and the five oblations - all of them are indeed the son of Devakī, O god.

original: tvaṃ yajñas tvaṃ vaṣaṭkāras tvam oṃkāraḥ paraṃtapaḥ /
analyzed: tvam yajñaḥ tvam vaṣaṭkāraḥ tvam oṃkāraḥ paraṃtapaḥ
translated: You are the sacrifice, you are the exclamation Vashat, you are the syllable Om, O scorcher of enemies.

original: ṛtudhāmā vasuḥ pūrvo vasūnāṃ tvaṃ prajāpatiḥ //
analyzed: ṛtu dhāmā vasuḥ pūrvaḥ vasūnām tvam prajāpatiḥ
translated: You are the season, the lord of wealth, the first of the Vasus, and the lord of creatures.

original: jagatsarvaṃ śarīraṃ te sthairyaṃ te vasudhātalam /
analyzed: jagat sarvam śarīram te sthairyam te vasudhā talam
translated: The entire universe is your body, the firmness is your earth.

original: agniḥ kopaḥ prasādas te somaḥ śrīvatsalakṣaṇaḥ //
analyzed: agniḥ kopaḥ prasādaḥ te somaḥ śrīvatsa lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Your anger is fire, your grace is the moon, you are the one marked with the srivatsa.

original: jyotīṃṣi viṣṇur bhuvanāni viṣṇur vanāni viṣṇur girayo diśaś ca /
analyzed: jyotīṃṣi viṣṇuḥ bhuvanāni viṣṇuḥ vanāni viṣṇuḥ girayaḥ diśaḥ ca
translated: Vishnu is the luminaries, Vishnu is the worlds, Vishnu is the forests, Vishnu is the mountains and the directions.

original: nadyaḥ samudrāś ca sa eva sarvaṃ yad asti yan nāsti ca vipravarya //
analyzed: nadyaḥ samudrāḥ ca saḥ eva sarvam yat asti yat na asti ca vipra varya
translated: The rivers, the oceans, and all that exists and does not exist, O best of Brahmins, is all Vishnu.

original: ityādisāmānādhikaraṇyaprayogeṣu sarvaiḥ śabdaiḥ sarvaśarīratayā sarvaprakāraṃ brahmaivābhidhīyata iti coktam /
analyzed: ityādi sāmānādhikaraṇya prayogeṣu sarvaiḥ śabdaiḥ sarva śarīra tayā sarva prakāram brahma eva abhidhīyate iti ca uktam
translated: Thus, in the passages of co-reference beginning with this, it is said that Brahman alone is denoted by all the words as having all the bodies and in all ways.

original: satyasaṃkalapaṃ paraṃ brahma svayam eva bahuprakāraṃ syām iti saṃkalpyācitsamaṣṭirūpamahābhūtasūkṣmavastu
analyzed: satya saṃkalapam param brahma svayam eva bahu prakāram syām iti saṃkalpya acit samaṣṭi rūpa mahābhūta sūkṣma vastu
translated: The supreme Brahman, whose resolve is true, having resolved I shall be manifold, having dissolved into itself the aggregate of all beings in the form of the subtle elements of the great elements,🔽and the group of enjoyers, having divided itself from that subtle element of existence,

original: bhoktṛvargasamūhaṃ ca svasmin pralīnaṃ svayam eva vibhajya tasmād bhūtasūkṣmād vāstuno
analyzed: bhoktṛ varga samūham ca svasmin pralīnam svayam eva vibhajya tasmāt bhūta sūkṣmāt
translated: from that subtle element of existence,

original: mahābhūtāni sṛṣṭvā teṣu ca bhoktṛvargātmatayā praveśya taiścid adhiṣṭhitair mahābhūtair
analyzed: mahābhūtāni sṛṣṭvā teṣu ca bhoktṛ varga ātma tayā praveśya taiḥ cit adhiṣṭhitaiḥ mahābhūtaiḥ
translated: Having created the great elements, and having entered them as the essence of the group of experiencers, and by those great elements presided over by consciousness,

original: anyonyasaṃsṛṣṭaiḥ kṛtsnaṃ jagad vidhāya svayam api sarvasyātmatayā praviśya paramātmatvenāvasthitaṃ
analyzed: anyonya saṃsṛṣṭaiḥ kṛtsnam jagat vidhāya svayam api sarvasya ātma tayā praviśya paramātma tvena avasthitam
translated: having created the entire world through their mutual mixture, and having entered even itself as the essence of all, it remains as the supreme self.

original: sarvaśarīraṃ bahuprakāram avatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: sarva śarīram bahu prakāram avatiṣṭhate
translated: It abides in many ways in all bodies.

original: yad idaṃ mahābhūtasūkṣmaṃ vastu tad eva prakṛtiśabdenābhidhīyate /
analyzed: yat idam mahābhūta sūkṣmam vastu tat eva prakṛti śabdena abhidhīyate
translated: That subtle entity of the great elements is called prakriti.

original: bhoktṛvargasamūha eva puruṣaśabdena cocyate /
analyzed: bhoktṛ varga samūhaḥ eva puruṣa śabdena ca ucyate
translated: And the group of experiencers themselves is called purusha.

original: tau ca prakṛtipuruṣau paramātmaśarīratayā paramātmaprakārabhūtau /
analyzed: tau ca prakṛti puruṣau paramātma śarīra tayā paramātma prakāra bhūtau
translated: And those two, prakriti and purusha, are of the nature of the supreme self's body, and are of the nature of the supreme self.

original: tatprakāraḥ paramātmaiva prakṛtipuruṣaśabdābhideyaḥ /🔽so 'kāmayata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tatsṛṣṭvā tad evānupraviśat tad anupraviśya sac
analyzed: tad prakāraḥ paramātmā eva prakṛti puruṣa śabda abhideyaḥ  sā u kāmayata bahu syām prajāyeya iti tat sṛṣṭvā tat eva anupraviśat tat anupraviśya sac
translated: That of which they are the nature is the supreme self itself, denoted by the words prakriti and purusha.

original: ca tyac cābhavan niruktaṃ cāniruktaṃ ca nilayanaṃ cānilayanaṃ ca vijñānaṃ cāvijñānaṃ
analyzed: ca tyad ca abhavat niruktam ca a niruktam ca nilayanam ca a nilayanam ca vijñānam ca a vijñānam
translated: It desired, 'Let me be many. Let me be born.' Having created that, it entered into it. Having entered into it, it became both existent and non-existent, defined and undefined, with a resting place and without a resting place, with knowledge and without knowledge,

original: ca satyaṃ cānṛtaṃ ca satyam abhavad iti pūrvoktaṃ sarvam anayaiva śrutyā vyaktam /
analyzed: ca satyam ca anṛtam ca satyam abhavat iti pūrva uktam sarvam anayā eva śrutyā vyaktam  /
translated: And the truth and the untruth became truth. All that was said before is made clear by this very Vedic text.

original: brahmaprāptyupāyaś ca śāstrādhigatatattvajñānapūrvakasvakarmānugṛhītabhaktiniṣṭhāsādhyānavadhikātiśayapriyaviśadatamapratyakṣatāpannānudhyānarūpaparabhaktir 🔽evetyuktam /
analyzed: brahma prāpti upāyaḥ ca śāstra adhigata tattva jñāna pūrvaka sva karma anugṛhīta bhakti niṣṭhā sādhya anavadhika atiśaya priya viśadatama pratyakṣa tā āpanna anudhyāna rūpa para bhaktiḥ  eva iti uktam
translated: And the means of attaining Brahman is said to be supreme devotion in the form of meditation that has attained the state of being free from obstruction, of having the highest degree of love, and of being clear and bright, which is to be accomplished by the culmination of devotion aided by one's own actions, preceded by the knowledge of the truth obtained through the scriptures.

original: bhaktiśabdaś ca prītiviśeṣe vartate /
analyzed: bhakti śabdaḥ ca prīti viśeṣe vartate
translated: And the word devotion is used for a special kind of love.

original: prītiś ca jñānaviśeṣa eva /
analyzed: prītiḥ ca jñāna viśeṣaḥ eva
translated: And love is nothing but a special kind of knowledge.

original: nanu ca sukhaṃ prītir ityanarthāntaram /
analyzed: nanu ca sukham prītiḥ iti anartha antaram
translated: But isn't pleasure and love synonymous?

original: sukhaṃ ca jñānaviśeṣasādhyaṃ padārthāntaram iti hi laukikāḥ /
analyzed: sukham ca jñāna viśeṣa sādhyam padārtha antaram iti hi laukikāḥ
translated: And worldly people say that pleasure, which is to be accomplished by a special kind of knowledge, is a different kind of thing.

original: naivam /
analyzed: na evam
translated: It is not so.

original: yena jñānaviśeṣeṇa tatsādhyam ity ucyate sa eva jñānaviśeṣaḥ sukham /
analyzed: yena jñāna viśeṣeṇa tat sādhyam iti ucyate saḥ eva jñāna viśeṣaḥ sukham
translated: That very special kind of knowledge by which it is said to be accomplished is that very special kind of knowledge which is pleasure.

original: etad uktaṃ bhavati viṣayajñānāni sukhaduḥkhamadhyasādhāraṇāni /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati viṣaya jñānāni sukha duḥkha madhya sādhāraṇāni
translated: This is what is meant: The cognitions of objects are common to pleasure, pain, and indifference.

original: tāni ca viṣayādhīnaviśeṣāṇi tathā bhavanti /
analyzed: tāni ca viṣaya adhīna viśeṣāṇi tathā bhavanti
translated: And they have those particularities dependent on the objects.

original: yena ca viṣayaviśeṣeṇa viśeṣitaṃ jñānaṃ sukhasya janakam ity abhimataṃ tadviṣayaṃ jñānam eva sukhaṃ /
analyzed: yena ca viṣaya viśeṣeṇa viśeṣitam jñānam sukhasya janakam iti abhimatam tad viṣayam jñānam eva sukham
translated: And the knowledge which is qualified by a particular object, and is accepted as the cause of pleasure, that knowledge of that object itself is pleasure.

original: tadatireki padārthāntaraṃ nopalabhyate /
analyzed: tad atireki padārtha antaram na upalabhyate
translated: No other thing apart from that is perceived.

original: tenaiva sukhitvavyavahāropapatteś ca /
analyzed: tena eva sukhi tva vyavahāra upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because the usage of being pleased is possible with that itself.

original: evaṃvidhasukhasvarūpajñānasya viśeṣakatvaṃ brahmavyatiriktasya vastunaḥ sātiśayam asthiraṃ ca /
analyzed: evaṃvidha sukha sva rūpa jñānasya viśeṣaka tvam brahma vyatiriktasya vastunaḥ sa atiśayam asthiram ca
translated: The qualification of the nature of pleasure of that kind belongs to a thing other than Brahman, which is with excess and unstable.

original: brahmaṇas tv anavadhikātiśayaṃ sthiraṃ ceti /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ tu anavadhika atiśayam sthiram ca iti
translated: But of Brahman it is unlimitedly excessive and stable.

original: ānando brahmety ucyate /
analyzed: ānandaḥ brahma iti ucyate
translated: It is said that bliss is Brahman.

original: viṣayāyattatvāj jñānasya sukhasvarūpatayā brahmaiva sukham /
analyzed: viṣaya āyatta tvāt jñānasya sukha svarūpa tayā brahmā eva sukham
translated: Since knowledge depends on an object, Brahman itself is pleasure, as it is the nature of pleasure.

original: tad idam āha raso vai saḥ rasaṃ he evāyaṃ labdhvānandī bhavatīti brahmaiva sukham iti brahma labdhvā sukhī bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat idam āha rasaḥ vai saḥ rasam he eva ayam labdhvā ānandī bhavati iti brahma eva sukham iti brahma labdhvā sukhī bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: This is what is said: That is the essence, indeed. Having obtained that essence, one becomes blissful. Brahman itself is pleasure. The meaning is: having obtained Brahman, one becomes happy.

original: paramapuruṣaḥ svenaiva svayam anavadhikātiśayasukhaḥ san parasyāpi sukhaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: paramapuruṣaḥ svena eva svayam anavadhika atiśaya sukhaḥ san parasya api sukham bhavati
translated: The Supreme Person, being himself of unlimitedly excessive bliss, becomes the pleasure of another also.

original: sukhasvarūpatvāviśeṣāt /
analyzed: sukha svarūpa tva aviśeṣāt
translated: Because there is no difference in the nature of being pleasure.

original: brahma yasya jñānaviṣayo bhavati sa sukhī bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: brahma yasya jñāna viṣayaḥ bhavati sa sukhī bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: one who has Brahman as the object of knowledge becomes happy.

original: tad evaṃ parasya brahmaṇo 'navadhikātiśayāsaṃkhyeyakalyāṇaguṇagaṇākarasya niravadyasyānantamahāvibhūter
analyzed: tat evam parasya brahmaṇaḥ nava adhika atiśaya asaṃkhyeya kalyāṇa guṇa gaṇa ākarasya niravadyasya ananta mahā vibhūteḥ
translated: Thus, in this way, the Supreme Brahman, the source of an infinite, unlimited, innumerable, excellent, virtuous qualities, free from faults, of infinite, great majesty,

original: anavadhikātiśayasauśīlyasaundaryavātsalyajaladheḥ sarvaśeṣitvād ātmanaḥ śeṣatvāt
analyzed: anavadhika atiśaya sauśīlya saundarya vātsalya jaladheḥ sarva śeṣi tvāt ātmanaḥ śeṣa tvāt
translated: an ocean of infinite, unlimited, excellent, gentle, beautiful, loving qualities, because of being the remainder of all, because of being the remainder of the self,

original: pratibaṃdhitayānusaṃdhīyamānam anavadhikātiśayaprītiviṣayaṃ sat paraṃ brahmaivainam
analyzed: pratibaṃdhi tayā anusaṃdhīyamānam anavadhika atiśaya prīti viṣayam sat param brahma eva enam
translated: being contemplated as limited, being the object of infinite, unlimited, excellent, supreme bliss, the Supreme Brahman

original: ātmānaṃ prāpayatīti /
analyzed: ātmānam prāpayati iti
translated: brings that self to itself.

original: nanu cātyantaśeṣataivātmano 'navadhikātiśayasukham ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: nanu ca atyanta śeṣatā eva ātmanaḥ na vadhika atiśaya sukham iti uktam bhavati
translated: But it is said that the very state of being an infinite, unlimited remainder of the self is of infinite, unlimited, excellent bliss.

original: tad etat sarvalokaviruddham /
analyzed: tat etat sarva loka viruddham
translated: This is contrary to the opinion of all people.

original: tathā hi sarveṣām eva cetanānāṃ svātantryam eva iṣṭatamaṃ dṛśyate /
analyzed: tathā hi sarveṣām eva cetanānām svātantryam eva iṣṭatamam dṛśyate
translated: For thus, the independence of all conscious beings is seen to be most desired.

original: pāratantryaṃ duḥkhataram / smṛtiś ca
analyzed: pāratantryam duḥkhataram smṛtiḥ ca
translated: Dependence is more painful. And there is a smrti:

original: sarvaṃ paravaśam duḥkhaṃ sarvam ātmavaśaṃ sukham /
analyzed: sarvam para vaśam duḥkham sarvam ātma vaśam sukham
translated: Everything under the control of another is suffering, everything under one's own control is happiness.

original: tathā hi
analyzed: tathā hi
translated: Thus it is said:

original: sevā śvavṛttir ākhyātā tasmāt tāṃ parivarjayet /
analyzed: sevā śvavṛttiḥ ākhyātā tasmāt tām parivarjayet
translated: Service is said to be the occupation of a dog, therefore one should avoid it.

original: iti / tad idam anadhigatadehātiriktātmarūpāṇāṃ śarīrātmābhimānavijṛmbhitam /
analyzed: iti tat idam anadhigata deha atirikta ātma rūpāṇām śarīra ātma abhimāna vijṛmbhitam
translated: This is the manifestation of the identification of the body with the self of those who have not understood the self to be different from the body.

original: tathā hi śarīraṃ hi manuṣyatvādijātiguṇāśrayapiṇḍabhūtaṃ svatantraṃ pratīyate /
analyzed: tathā hi śarīram hi manuṣya tva ādi jāti guṇa āśraya piṇḍa bhūtam svatantram pratīyate
translated: For thus the body is perceived as an independent mass which is the substratum of the qualities of the species of man, etc.

original: tasminn evāham iti saṃsāriṇāṃ pratītiḥ /
analyzed: tasmin eva aham iti saṃsāriṇām pratītiḥ
translated: In it, the worldly people have the notion of 'I'.

original: ātmābhimāno yādṛśas tadanuguṇaiva puruṣārthapratītiḥ /
analyzed: ātma abhimānaḥ yādṛśaḥ tad anuguṇā eva puruṣa artha pratītiḥ
translated: The notion of the self is just as it is, and the notion of human goal is in accordance with it.

original: siṃhavyāghravarāhamanuṣyayakṣarakṣaḥpiśācadevadānavastrīpuṃsavyavasthitātmābhimānānāṃ sukhāni vyavasthitāni /
analyzed: siṃha vyāghra varāha manuṣya yakṣa rakṣaḥ piśāca deva dānava strīpuṃsa vyavasthita ātma abhimānānām sukhāni vyavasthitāni
translated: The pleasures are well-established for those who have the notion of the self as a lion, tiger, boar, man, yaksha, rakshasa, pisacha, god, demon, woman, or man.

original: tāni ca parasparaviruddhāni /
analyzed: tāni ca paraspara viruddhāni
translated: And those are mutually contradictory.

original: tasmād ātmābhimānānuguṇapuruṣārthavyavasthayā sarvaṃ samāhitam /
analyzed: tasmāt ātma abhimāna anuguṇa puruṣa artha vyavasthayā sarvam samāhitam
translated: Therefore, everything is included by the well-established human goal that is in accordance with the notion of the self.

original: ātmasvarūpaṃ tu devādidehavilakṣaṇaṃ jñānaikākāram /
analyzed: ātma svarūpam tu deva ādi deha vilakṣaṇam jñāna eka ākāram
translated: But the nature of the self is different from the bodies of gods, etc., and is of the form of knowledge alone.

original: tac ca paraśeṣataikasvarūpam /
analyzed: tat ca para śeṣa tā eka svarūpam
translated: And that is of the form of being the remainder of the supreme self.

original: yathāvasthitātmābhimāne tadanuguṇaiva puruṣārthapratītiḥ /
analyzed: yathā avasthita ātma abhimāne tad anuguṇā eva puruṣa artha pratītiḥ
translated: When the notion of the self is as it is, the notion of the human goal is in accordance with it.

original: ātmā jñānamayo 'mala iti smṛter jñānaikākāratā pratipannā /
analyzed: ātmā jñāna mayaḥ malaḥ iti smṛteḥ jñāna eka ākāra tā pratipannā
translated: By the smrti statement 'the self is of the nature of knowledge and pure', the form of being knowledge alone is understood.

original: patiṃ viśvasyetyādi śrutiguṇaiḥ paramātmaśeṣataikākāratā ca pratītā /
analyzed: patim viśvasya ityādi śruti guṇaiḥ paramātma śeṣa tā eka ākāra tā ca pratītā
translated: By the Vedantic statements beginning with 'the lord of the universe' etc., the form of being the remainder of the supreme self is also understood.

original: ataḥ siṃhavyāghrādiśarīrātmābhimānavat svātantryābhimāno 'pi karmakṛtaviparītātmajñānarūpo veditavyaḥ /
analyzed: atas siṃha vyāghra ādi śarīra ātma abhimāna vat svātantrya abhimānaḥ pi karma kṛta viparīta ātma jñāna rūpaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, like the notion of the self in the bodies of lions, tigers, etc., the notion of independence should also be understood as a distorted knowledge of the self created by karma.

original: ataḥ karmakṛtam eva paramapuruṣavyatiriktaviṣayāṇāṃ sukhatvam /
analyzed: atas karma kṛtam eva parama puruṣa vyatirikta viṣayāṇām sukha tvam
translated: Therefore, the happiness of objects other than the Supreme Person is created only by karma.

original: ata eva teṣām alpatvam asthiratvaṃ ca paramapuruṣasyaiva svata eva sukhatvam /
analyzed: atas eva teṣām alpa tvam asthira tvam ca paramapuruṣasya eva svatas eva sukha tvam
translated: For this very reason, they are limited and unstable, while the happiness of the Supreme Person is inherent in Him alone.

original: atas tad eva sthiram anavadhikātiśayaṃ ca kaṃ brahma khaṃ brahma ānando brahma satyaṃ jñānam anantaṃ brahmeti śruteḥ /
analyzed: atas tat eva sthiram anavadhika atiśayam ca kam brahma kham brahma ānandaḥ brahma satyam jñānam anantam brahma iti śruteḥ
